Her test is very difficult, since the type of questions in the test paper is beyond our expectation! Most of the questions ask us to write down the definition, which is too much difficult. The sample of the test she gives has no related to the real test. Also, her lecture is awful, since her logic is strange and most time I have to learn by myself.

One of those stupid writing/discussion classes you thought you'd avoid as STEM major where you have no idea how you're even being graded. Chip away at the assignments (something due almost every day) and jump when she says jump and you'll get your A though. Do detailed peer reviews, those are graded tough

Midterms and Final go deep in depth in a breadth heavy course. Lectures and test review go rush through the breadth and go into the technical minutiae of how to solve certain problems for only handful of major things -- the majority is not but its there staring at you on the timed final. Average grade was an F on the final. There's a curve.

Tests were made from random parts of the text book and not usually relate to the review session. Often time, there were many typos on the tests. Not really accessible after class. Scheduled review session a night before the test.

Do not take. She will kill your GPA. Midterm and Final had questions that were never talked about within lecture. To do well in the class, you HAVE to read the text book and memorize all of the minute details of every concept. Good luck to you, if you do decide to take her!

The midterm and the final are badly made and the averages are extremely low. Labs and homework are fine and as long as you do them correctly you can get full credit. Midterm and the final is what killed the class.
Exams are made from random parts of the book and have nothing to do with what is taught or what was told to learn. Complete gamble on grades.

Please beware, after the curve, your grades might goes DOWN! E.X. If you got a 75% which is a C in normal curve, you might get a D or F instead at the end. So please plan accordingly, if you have to take this class with her. And Good luck!!
Really poorly constructed class. Professor is really unprofessional. I think she is only a lecturer, not a professor in the department. Now, I know why.
For example, Taking her class was like you learn college intro class level knowledge during the lecture. Then, you encounter Nobel prize level problems in the exam.

Don't trust what she says will be on exams. Most of it consists of small details that serves no purpose to what we do in lecture. In fact, we barely saw the things we spent so much tine learning. Although she seems like a nice person, but her actions say otherwise. So save yourself the misery and take it with someone else

The rating here on RMP speaks itself. The class were extremely unorganized. The structure of exam basically test you the memorization of the textbook. You should also expect something that never been mentioned by her shows on your exams. Midterm and final average were low 40%. You Shouldt expect a curve even though the whole class didnt do well.

ICS 51 was the first class, where I studied extremely hard, but failed both midterm/final. However, Professor Alfaro has put in more effort at teaching, by creating mini-lectures and holding review sessions. She also created a slack channel for us to ask all our questions in real-time, which was helpful.

Yes, for sure the lecture will help you on midterm and final, but maybe roughly only 1% up for each. Last two labs were extremely confusing. In general,Midterm and final will demolish your overall grade. If you have an option, Ill suggest you go with other options.

Had no clear vision on what I was supposed to be learning for the majority of the class, except a few major concepts. Studying for exams felt like a shot in the dark, since the "major concepts" were hardly tested on -- feels like you need to memorize the tiny details in the book to do well on exams. And by "do well on exams", I mean pass.

The class feels extremely disorganized. At no point did I feel like I knew what I should be learning. I thought I did in the beginning but the midterm made me realize that what they expect you to know is not what was presented in class. The book is your best friend. Dont mess up Labs or Homework because the midterm and final are going to ruin you.
Final was insane. Had material that we didnt go over. Doesnt tell you what will be on the final so you never know what to study. Just avoid her and save yourself the stress.
Made everything so confusing and always tests something that never mentioned in the lecture.

She is a nice person, but makes the class extremely confusing. You wont really know what or how to study for the class. She makes her exams the night before so anything could be on them. Just have to pray your cheat sheet contains information relevant to the test.

She really can't lecture. She uses a lot of fluff and big buzzwords which even i question that she knows. Assembly portion was taught by TA's which did a better job teaching. She teaches architecture alone, and doesn't use the book which means you gotta listen to her lectures and hope you get the best out of them. M She's a really nice lady though.

Her test is really pointless. Understanding the material will not get you a high score. Only if you write a perfect cheat-sheet will bring you a high score. In her testing, she is asking spellings and other things that are trivial.

It's an overview of all layers of computing. So the entire course in general is a giant complex lump of vague concepts. She does her best to go over it all quickly. She cares and helps you at office hours. However, had to drop her rating to 2 since she made the midterm the night before and didn't tell anyone what to study accurately. average 50%ish

ICS 51 covers a massive amount of material and she does her best to move through it at a brisk pace. Study hard for the midterm and final because those are what really count -- the final especially. The assembly section on the final was quite rough and our class average was 56% (no curve granted).

ICS 51 in general is a hard class to teach/learn. Make sure to go to class because there will be pop quizzes (mostly group). The labs are disjoint from lectures, so it def feels like a 6 unit class. Read the book for the midterm. Assembly on the final was killer, dropped my grade rip. Overall, Alfaro is nice and passionate about the subject.

To be honest, it's not nearly as bad as I thought it would be given her reputation. The book is really dense, but you really don't have to read all of it. The class itself is going to be hard no matter who is teaching, but Alfaro does a decent job of explaining some harder concepts in an understandable way.

In my opinion, I personally thought that the class was fair for a 6 unit class, and you really do need to work for an A. Architecture and low level design isn't my cup of tea, and is probably why I got the grade that I got. I thought lectures were pretty average, but Alfaro genuinely tries her best, but sometimes doesn't explain it well enough.
Honestly, she is not good at teaching although she has that passion. My suggestion is to go to her office hour and discussions and read textbook. What a pity.
The only difference between she and a tape recorder is she don't need electricity, but I'm not here to save power for the world, so do u guys. Don't take it unless u already know everything.

Spends all her time on describing the assignments, reading aloud for the sake of hearing her own voice, and has us fill in the rest. There is NO teaching being done, merely reading. The assignments are well documented and a good resource for self-teaching, but so not worth the 1000$. Lecture is pretty fun - she stares at the sky all class.

She gives a decent amount of work, but definitely manageable. What I really hated about her class was the fact that she didn't follow her grading rubric on assignments. She'd take off points for things not specified in the grading rubric. What was especially frustrating was the fact that I lost points for things done in her provided examples.

Pretty interesting class. The projects are cool. I'm sure in other writing classes you have to write super long (maybe boring) papers, but the stuff we do in this class is actually very helpful. As a business major, I highly recommend this class. Very responsive. Nice. You should show up to every lecture, but discussions aren't mandatory.

The class isn't hard especially if you follow the examples she goes through. If you follow that format you're likely to get a good grade. I don't really feel like I've learned anything though since most of class time is used for peer review and she hardly lectures. There are two presentations and no final.

Textbook is very dense, loses sight of context, long, requires multiple readings. Lectures are not detailed enough to replace the book, but also do not offer new content. The already-moderate difficulty of course content is compounded. Overall a difficult and confusing class. But Alfaro is friendly and makes an effort to teach.

Best professor in UCI, here is why. Amazing lectures, very clear & organized. She goes through materials slowly and explains them really well. Labs, readings & lectures are well connected, and reading amount is minimal. Very easy exams, plus she gives clear study guides for them. And most important--She curve the course grade!!! I'm not lying
Extremely disorganized and confusing; no curves at all. Avoid her while you can

The worst class I've ever taken at UCI so far.  Does not go over enough material in lecture to prepare for midterm or final. Exams are extremely detailed.  Has assignments due during finals week, and didn't even give the answer key for them. Sample final had typos so some of the correct answers were not available.  Overall worse professor I've had.
EXTREMELY unorganized. She is very unclear about when assignments are due. She still hasn't graded stuff from the beginning of the quarter. Do not recommend.

She's disorganized: posts information randomly between Piazza, Email, and class website. Knowing lecture material isn't enough to get As  must read textbook. She also doesn't really teach that well  very confusing. Lastly, there was a ton to do in this class: HWs, labs, pop quizzes, midterm, and final. She even had assignments due in finals week

She is unforgiving of any error. Going to office hours is a waste of time. Class is setup on a strict 20 pt per project score,and 2 pts per peer review. If you miss a class you will be double jeapordized and lose points twice without any possibility of recovery.

Can be very confusing in lecture (esp. in 2nd half), but very helpful in office hours. Expects reading of the book before coming to class. (Group) pop quizzes. Announced we can use a cheat sheet a week before midterm. HW/labs are indv. work, lowest grades dropped. Lab rules got inconsistent since head TA was replaced. What to study for is confusing

Terrible lecturer. She doesn't post her in class notes online and she goes through them too quickly to actually write them down. The only way you could copy most of it is by printing out the notes and writing over them as she goes over it in lecturer. Very unclear and messy. She will not grade something for weeks. A lot of self study.

Her lectures are boring and unclear. Her demonstrations are confusing and she doesn't communicate well. Her assignment document allowed partners but, during lecture she said partners were forbidden all the while her TA's said partners were allowed. Very confusing.
Worst class i have ever had in UCI

Her writing class is really really easy. Everything is graded by a rubric that is given to you at the beginning of the quarter. She also gives many good, fair and bad student samples.  I took ICS 139W during summer and I got an A. DON'T TAKE OTHER CLASSES, BUT DO TAKE HER WRITING CLASS.

Definitely not respected by students. Not responsive through email or in person. When you ask her for help, she gave a "find it yourself" answer. Disorganized course, especially with grading. One homework point changed my grade from 88% to 82%. Labs are what we spent time on most, and each lab didn't even affect  your grade that much. No curve.
She makes Klefstad look like a good professor.

This teacher is hilariously bad. Wait, I would not even call her a teacher. She ruined my ICS 51 experience through her horrendous planning and organizing. She did not follow her lecture schedule, passed out a final with many typos without even being there for it, and puts tremendous expectations on students. Easily the worst "professor" ever.
Labs, lectures, homeworks, quizzes, and finals are 5 completely separate things.

Extremely disorganized, doesn't care for her students, blatantly doesn't give out review session notes because its "her course". Tries her best to teach, giving us "big-picture" concepts then skips all the details and go straight to specifics without filling any information in between. Overall, terrible professor, wouldn't recommend taking her.

Alfaro is a really kind individual and wants the best for her students. However, she's also lazy with regards to keeping the TAs on the same page as her with grading requirements, takes a long time to answer emails, and has vague grading rubrics to follow. If you have really good TAs, you'll be fine - more likely than not, though, avoid her.

The way the prof organizes the class just isn't effective at making  you learn the material. Homework answers and quiz answers were never released which left me with no idea whether I knew what I was doing. The coding portion of the class was alright. If you know how to google and read stackoverflow, like any other coding class, you can do fine.

Alfaro is a clear lecturer who knows what she's talking about, but the topics are very hard to understand. She tells you to read the textbook, but the textbook is long, extremely boring, and even more confusing than her lectures. Lab topics are totally different from what she teaches in lecture, so you have to teach yourself C and assembly.

I personally found this professor challenging to learn from. The lectures are very interactive and theatrical, which can be engaging, but they didn't clearly explain the material. The class had many quizzes and readings, which made it difficult to keep up at times. Overall, I didn't enjoy the learning process as much as I hoped.

Raymond Klefstad is not very good at teaching. Lectures are rambling, I'd say roughly 50%+ of class time is spent on irrelevant material or jokes only he finds funny. If you don't troll the ed discussion you will fail his absurdly specific weekly quizzes. His teaching style was outdated 20 years ago.

Avoid taking a class with him at all costs.
Great professor, had him for 46 in the spring, and he was super engaging. Definitely come to class even though it's not mandatory. Weekly quizzes instead of midterms, final MCQ.

Prof Klefstad, the most hyped professor at UCI is actually not that great. Sure he is a good communicator, but he hardly communicates useful things. I went to lectures and realised that he didn't really teach me anything except useless anecdotes. Also his class structure is the most annoying structure I have ever experienced.

Very good at lecturing and explaining concepts. Workload is very manageable if you're good at reading/studying. The first homework assignment is super long and challenging, but after that the homework assignments are very doable in an afternoon or two. Let's you know what will be on the weekly quizzes a couple days before so you can study for it.

he's a funny guy, but he has a huge ego about his own coding skills and says some weird stuff. his weekly quizzes started really hard, and his grading concept (you fail if you have a failing score on quizzes/final) was a bit scary, but it honestly was not a super hard class. autograded homeworks and just one exam, and he's a decent lecturer too.

Klefstad is funny and passionate. You can't expect to learn everything from lecture, but such is life. You get as much out of this class as you put into it. The projects are quite easy, quizzes are easy, and the final was fair.
Awful course design in general and bro has the highest ego on earth

Not sure why Prof. Klefstad has a lot of negative reviews on here. This is actually my second time taking ICS 46 after failing with Shindler last quarter. Klefstad is way better for ICS 46 and his lectures are fun. Some may complain about his "repeat after me" thing but when do you ever get these kind of professors? Workload is not too heavy imo.

Weekly, reading, quizzes, hw, as expected. Clearly lots of reading for in-depth knowledge, because 3hrs/week of lecture can't cover all material in-depth. HW is basic implementation. Quiz topics are revealed in class, and test fundamentals, nothing tricky. Not a sweaty, dedicate majority of your time class. The final was basic, nothing tricky.

Honestly I love him, I took him for both 45C and 46, and really enjoy his teaching. He talks about the real-world application of the CS you are learning in class. Overall, I think he is a fair teacher who is very understanding about his students. Take him if you can!

I think the low ratings are definitely biased.  He very clearly cares about students' learning and puts in both the time and effort to help students succeed.  He gives great career and professional advice, and although he assigns lots of work and gives difficult tests, it's an invaluable experience for those who take advantage of this opportunity

If your already decent programmer, thats familiar with the basics + the type to code on your off time. This class is a waste of your time. The hardest part is the busy work "Homework" that gets assigned each week. The homework's will eat up at a minimum a day of your time. To enthusiastic, but give him props for keeping 300+ youngins engaged.

An auto grader was used to score homework and we had multiple attempts for submission. There are in-lecture quizzes every week which I feel like helped me stay on track with the course material. Klefstad wants his students to succeed so homework and quizzes play a big part in your overall grade which helps when it comes to the final.

I love his enthusiasm in lecture that got me thinking he wants students to succeed. Course topics are well-organized imo, but for some of his slides, he gives off code to the rest of the students to boost student progression especially if you have a busy schedule. Be sure to attend lecture every Thursday b/c of quiz.

lectures are engaging but the course is not up to the rigor a DSA class is meant to be. you implement the base functionality of many data structures, which he just gives you the pseudo code for, but not enough problem solving. I can only recommend him with this much busy work if you need to get (any of his) classes out of the way as a prereq

Homeworks will consume a lot of your time, but ends up being a huge plus by boosting grades. Professor also not very organized (materials always posted late and/or inconsistent weekly) but very understanding of your circumstances. A lot of work, including reading, test is fair. Overall nice guy, but he'll hunt your entire family tree if you yawn.

Very enthusiastic. Teaches okay. You have to do reading online outside of class to fully understand the material. Homework is fun enough and uses an autograder that you can submit multiple times to. Homework instructions aren't the most clear but still doable. Overall a manageable, interesting class.
Once you get used to his personality, I thought his teaching was pretty understandable and weekly homework/quizzes makes sure you are keeping up with the class/understanding the material

Prof Klefstad is a really cool professor and I feel like I learned a lot in this class about DS and C++. He really does care about his students. Its true that he gets off topic very easily but I personally didn't mind because we always got through the material. The course wasn't the hardest out of the other profs, but it was a good experience.
He is a great professor. He cares about his students and wants them to succeed professionally. His lectures are very engaging and easy to understand.

Graded on weekly homework (30%), weekly quizzes (40%), and final (30%). Final is difficult. Homeworks are disorganized, sometimes unclear criteria. Klefstad'a a great lecturer and I believe he is trying to rectify some issues people have had with him this course, but disorganization remained and autograders were often terrible. Overall not bad.

Klefstad isn't the best the ICS department has to offer, but taking ICS 46 with him is doable as long as you have the time to invest in keeping up with the weekly programming assignments. Class moves at a pretty brisk pace--there's two short quizzes a week, so don't think about skipping. The final was a breeze.

HW is straight forward implementation of data structures. He is good at teaching the first half of the class (data structures), but not useful for the second half (sorting/graph algorithms, the more theoretical stuff). Easy to get a high grade because majority of grade is quizzes spread out over the term, and HW is graded leniently.
Time management is important. Take good notes in class and you will do fine.
taking a class with this guy is a great choice if you enjoy confusion, suffering, and sadness. solid choice if thats what youre looking for

First homework assignment was tough and time consuming, so make sure to start early. For 46, his lectures were great. Data structures is an important concept and Klefstad teaches the material well. Quizzes every lecture (labeled lecture and hw quiz). Would you rather take midterms worth 20% each or have quizzes worth 2% each?
shocking how bad this class was and the other class I took with him was. I didn't think classes could be so disorganized
Worst CS teacher I've ever had Mistakes galore in his slides You will learn nothing from lecture despite his constant bragging about being a good teacher

He's good at giving lectures, and I feel like I'm really learning in his class, but his homework assignments are pretty vague and frustrating to do. The unclear instructions he gives for them is the main reason why I'm giving him a lower score. Otherwise, I think he's a pretty good professor (for ICS 46 at least).

A strange & contradictory professor. He's respected and known by big CS companies and people, but produces inconsistent/unclear homework write-ups like an amateur. Then, everyone repeats questions on Piazza because of it. His lectures can get annoying because of his over-excitement and loudness. Means well but there are better options.

You will have a full size HW due after only 2 lectures that asking you to implement string structures . BUT the thing is First lecture, he talked about his life and a little bit syllables staffs. Second lecture he only mentioned what is T(N) is. So he didnt teach anything at all. But you have to finish the HW. Is this UCI style or his style?

He insults other majors, Universities.... He mentioned few times during the lecture that employers won't be impressed by a CAL-STATE degree which is extremely inappropriate. He always try to show off and telling us he knows more than 13 languages. SO WHAT? Nobody cares. Would you please start teaching and stop talking all those non-sense.
impossible class combined with disorganized staff, FUN STUFF!!!!
It's bad when the TA's have to rewrite assignments for better understanding for the students. Mandatory 8AM class with quizzes each class.
There was so much work per week, quiz every lecture and homework every week. Having him at 8 am was the worst thing of my life "JUST SAY YES"! How about no.

Klefstad's ICS 53 is a lot of work, but you will learn so much about systems programming. He is truly knowledgeable in this topic, but as per usual with Klefstad courses you will have to sit through many rants and raves during lecture. The course grading scheme is fair, but be prepared for mandatory labs and discussions (weekly quiz).
Very engaging and funny, but the lectures don't teach much and homework is kind of vague. Easy content, though

Not a fan of him, but he is a nice guy. Pros: grading lenient, hw helps you understand material, not too much work. Cons: lectures notes and hw vague, don't learn much in lecture, sometimes lectures on the day the hw is due so self-study beforehand, didn't really teach pointers well. Self-study and you should be able to get A.

He is very humorous, enthusiastic and professional in C++. However, he sometimes deviate from the course notes and starts talking about unrelated things during lecture. 9 hw and 7 quizzes and each quiz is based on the previous hw. Anyway, it's a safe choice to take his 45C. As long as you work hard, you will be good.

He is probably my favorite lecturer at UCI so far; his lectures are funny and engaging. But I don't feel as though I learned a ton in his lectures. The lectures were also a few days behind the homework assignments, so I basically had to teach myself most of the class. Towards the end, I started learning more when he did (optional) live quizzes.

Alot of assignments, so good practice to become a better programmer. You learn by doing. Lecture time not useful. prof very opinionated, not afraid to humiliate students. its his room, his time. he said i love you students but I came to not believe this. fine, its hard to stand in front of a crowd everyday. somewhat scary behind smile. judgement
Klefstad's lectures are always interesting and fun. The class is also fairly easy, as most of the grade comes from your quizzes and the homeworks.

Klefstad tends to not teach us how to do the homework until the last minute. We're currently writing our own C++ iterators and it seems that a lot of people are confused. He is quite inactive on Piazza as well, only adding to the confusion. Take Thornton for 45C if you can; you will learn C++ better, and learn more problem-solving skills.

Kleftstad is a really good lecturer, and his homeworks and labs teach you a lot. He goes at a good pace. However, he spends way too much time talking about his hobbies and his family. It would be better if he spent that time actually explaining the concepts better. You end up having to learn most of the material yourself, online.

Not sure why Klefstad doesn't have a higher rating. Yes, his lectures often get sidetracked. But he's forgiving with late credit, his homeworks are good and reinforce the material, he doesn't make you take midterms or finals, and his quizzes are fair and easy to study for. He's the dream professor if you don't need to be taught how to learn.

Not sure why so many people hate Klefstad. I took him for 45C and learned alot. His notes aren't great, but he gives you enough info to figure out how to do everything. His homework was HARD sometimes, but they are pretty much 100% if you complete them (unlike Thornton). He teaches of C++, so when I took Thornton's 46 it was relatively easy.

Took 3 classes with him already (31, 45C, 46) Instructions on assignments may be unclear, but I think that's only because he just started teaching 46 (at least after a long time). I find his teaching very enjoyable. Grading is pretty fair. Quizzes every lecture/week with lowest dropped allows a lot of opportunity to get a good grade. You'll learn.

Lecture quizzes are open notes so take good notes in class, esp on what he says. Homework quizzes are very similar to the lab. The class was poorly managed at times, but he was dealing with students ranging in C++ skill and was trying to make the class fair for everyone. Hes caring enough to set up a review session for those needed more help
Easily one of the most poorly managed classes I've taken

Take him if u wanna feel lost in requirement. You will spent more time on reports than actually doing the hw. I found algorithms and graphs are cool stuff from my cc's data structure class, but UCI wont transfer it, thanks btw. and how he taught it made this class boring and unclear even though I pay more tuition ;)
Just Say Yes.

Klefstad is funny, likable, and extremely knowledgeable about C++. He just is not good at conveying the information to the student. He goes quickly in lectures and basically just reads off of notes(which are large, difficult to read). Quizzes and HW are not bad, but sometimes in HW you feel lost cuz things were not gone over in lecture.

I wanna to focus on discipline. Throughout the quarter, I sent him 2 emails (2nd week and 6th week, diff topics),  neither of them received a response. I went to his office 1 week after I sent him the first email, he made up an (awful)excuse that his gmail didn't work properly.  When my 2nd email got ignored, I know he is not the right prof.

Professor could benefit the class by organizing lecture notes and giving guides to learn from for the homework assignments. Kleftstad does not understand the value of learning efficiency. Encouraging students to google answers to solve problems is a really bad habit to pass off to students, one that already has cost the software industry.

Professor Klefstad makes you work very hard, but it's for good reason. You'll figure out how good of a programmer you are in his class, but in any case you'll leave a better one. Also this is one class where you won't want to miss class, not just because of the regular lecture, but because he tells the best stories.

You pretty much teach yourself the whole class. He passes this off as preparing you for the real world, and it does, but the same can be said for any class where the prof doesn't teach and you have to google everything.  Worst part is though he doesn't give the solution, so if you didn't get the answer you'll leave just as confused as you came.

He is passionate but it seems most of him. I'm going to learn things but not going to fight with sleepy, however, he can do much well in second task than first one. Although he says Stackoverflow is waste of time but at least there arent much off-topic words as exists in his lecture. Tons of hw and quizs w/n timely feedbacks, so do piazza.

I received more feedback from the T.A.s than from him. I didn't receive graded homework until the end of the quarter, and even then some didn't get graded until grades were due. I didn't understand his lectures and office hours were even worse. I get that he can't give explicit answers sometimes, but I would have appreciate more help from him.

The class lacked a clear structure because he was constantly changing the format and requirements, which was confusing at times. Other than that, the labs and homework are doable and help prepare you for the quizzes and final. He's really flexible and extends deadlines and is good at implementing student feedback.

It was his first time teaching ICS 31 so the structure of the class changed about 2 or 3 times. The assignments difficult also fluctuated about 2 or 3 times as well. As someone who was completely knew to programming, you have to sink a lot of time in order to do well. He makes the class difficult so you would actually learn the material

I was really salty like week0-2 since he basically taught us nothing & threw us into the abyss of compsci but after much self-learning, I appreciated him much more since I learned so much, plus as a person he's nice & lenient, he wanted his students to do well, & tells you what to study for weekly quizzes & put up with a LOT of students complaining

I had no experience in coding going into the class, so I thought the class was hard right from the very beginning. I learned a lot from this class and think it is doable. I just think for a beginner's course it was a lot to take in right from the very beginning.  Labs and hw are worth so much in the grade book, so just do those and you're set.

Class was extremely hard at first as someone with no exp with coding, but Klefstad gives a TON of breaks to his students. He extended deadlines, dropped 2 lowest quizzes, labs/hw were graded very leniently, no midterm, and final was only worth 15% and is a guaranteed A+ if you understand the previous labs/hw. Great course overall, learned a ton.

His class have no midterm no final. HW,labs count50%of your grade, basically you will get full credit if you submit it. Weekly quizzes35%and one final quiz in week10 count15%. Thats it, not an easy A but doable A.   I spent 95% of my study time this quater got A-, I am not CS major.

Always being passionate in his lecture. Even though somebody think he is talking about his own experience much I the lecture, still teaches all the things contained. You don't need to pay much attention to his class, and easily get A. His class has no midterms but only has several quizes which has been explained in the lecture.

I think maybe Klefstad is a good teacher for professional and some students who are perfect in programming. But actually, Klefstad is really not a good teacher for beginner. He taught many basic things on lec. His HW and LAB are literally  DISASTER. You should devote all of your time for his class. But he will extend the ddl of HW/LAB for students.
Not very good at teaching.  His sample code does not run.  He teaches basics in class, but homework and labs are a lot more advanced.  You will have to learn a good amount of stuff on your own.

This guy is a decent teacher but his decisions in regards to homework and labs makes him complete garbage. With Klefstad, expect your lab and hw to take up basically all of your time even if you have outside help. If you don't have outside help then good luck finishing anything.

The workload was a bit heavy for an intro class, but he makes a good point that this class should be hard so we don't get screwed in ICS 32.  My main complaint: his instructions are VERY VAGUE. That's literally all that's keeping me from rating this guy a 4 or even 5/5. Other than that, he's a pretty great teacher. You'll learn a lot for sure.

Pros: Willing to extend deadlines, dropping lowest 2 scores for quiz, no final on finals week (final quiz worth 15%). Cons: Way too difficult for an intro class (We're almost catching up to the lessons in ICS32), Lab and HW instructions are really vague and contradicts itself sometimes.   TLDR: Brutal workload, but you will learn a lot and fast.

really cool person ....... really bad teacher. This was one of those classes where you have to devote all your time to, even if you are taking more important/challenging courses at the same time. He is a really funny and cool guy, but the class was too frustrating and stressful, especially for an intro class.

Klefstad is what everyone says: vague and frustrating. He is, however, doing that with the best intentions. That sounds odd, but it is true. He leaves room for the student to actually use their brain in order to get something done. If you're not passionate about coding, you must really hate this class. Klefstad makes it fun and challenging. 10/10!!

Some quiz,lab,HW problems he never covers in lecture. And his program cannot run when he does examples in front of us during lectures. Finally he just gives up and that means he does not know how to do those questions.

Never boring. Very good speaker. Covers almost everything you need to know, but may throw a curve ball during lab that he forgot to explain. Don't attend lectures anymore because it is an 8am, but he posts all the class materials so class is going well. Grading is homework and lab, so class is an Easy A provided you actually do them. Final only 10%

Klefstad is passionate about computer science but does a bad job at teaching it. In his lectures, he talks more about his personal life/achievements more than teaching python. It's kind of discouraging for those who don't have experience yet. In lab, we're asked to use commands not even covered in lecture! Don't take Klefstad!

Would give a 0 if I could pros: funny person, interesting lectures (meaning: good jokes), chill dude  cons: useless notes: short, unorganized & hardly no explanations lecture: a lot of off topic bs confusing assignments: basically no explanations, vague grading criteria useless office hours  Back to Pattis this quarter, way better in all aspects

Lost tons of sleep with 53, but I learned more than any other CS class at UCI and built foundation for future upper-divs. Klefstad is a hard ass, but he CARES about students and INSPIRES them to give it their all (gets to knowing their names too). Yes, there's gonna be tons of work, but you'll learn so much more than before if you actually try.
Enthusiastic and energetic teacher. Helps solve homework labs in lecture. Provides helpful online lecture notes. My favorite ICS teacher at UCI.

Lectures notes are confusing and unorangized. Says things once and doesn't explain it. He assigns ambiguous assignments and is a harsh grader when you don't meet the expectations. The final was not based on most of the material and the notes did not help. The only things that matter is what he says but he doesn't go in depth.

This was a very fun class! Dr. Klefstad is hilarious, inspirational and gives great lectures. The lectures don't help much with the assignments, but you will never leave class disappointed. I relied heavily on the book and utilized his office hours as much as possible. He is very helpful and will spend a long time explaining concepts. Great class!

Dr. Klefstad is by far the most inspirational professor I have ever had. I always left his lecture motivated and determined to learn as much as I can. That being said, the class isn't exactly straight forward. His slides are confusing; expect to teach yourself a lot. He's truly brilliant though! Amazing professor, tough class, absolutely worth it!
This class is not hard, it really isn't.  He just doesn't know the material well.
Very passionate lecturer and is always willing to provide help as long as you are willing to learn. Class has a lot of work but simply because he cares for his students and wants them to learn.

This was  the most time consuming class I've ever taken. Having said that, I also improved in general programming ability more than I ever have in one quarter. Because of that, I'm glad I took this course with Klefstad. He's hilarious and very passionate about teaching.

His lectures are not that helpful and this class is mostly lip service to its catalog description. He essentially wants to teach C and makes the class fit that goal. To be fair, he does genuinely seem to care about students, but he seems unable to articulate it well. The grader just ran automated test cases, this was abused.

Talk about a complete disregard for students' time. Klefstad isn't kidding when he says he expects you to spend up to 20 hours on homework every week, and that doesn't include his timed labs and quizzes. Not a difficult class per se and he is very helpful during office hours, but you can bet that I won't ever take a class with him ever again.

Whatever you do, do not take Klefstad. The worst teacher I've taken. Quizzes are peer graded, but you have to go into office hours to get it fixed (which you will, "If it seems right then mark it wrong"). Problem is, it would take 2 hours to see him for office hours, so I could never do it because of my class schedule. hw was unreasonable, avoid!!

His first time teaching 53. It was a mess to say the least. He expected way too much time out of us to do his assignments and his instructions for them were usually vague and unclear. Also the quizzes were peer graded, which caused many grading issues He does have good intentions and is a great lecturer but the way he structured this class was bad.

Difficult. HWlabs are always vague. Unless you're a wizard, you will be swamped with work every week consisting of: 1 long hw assignment, 1 lab problem you must complete in 2 hours (as well as another due later), and WRITTEN quizzes. And he doesn't post solutions for anything ever. Office hours are the only help. Good intentions,  bad teacher.

Klefstad is a good lecturer but the lectures will NOT prepare you for the homeworkslabs he assigns. Quizzes are peer graded. Also, his quiz directions are extremely vague and if you get a correct but different solution, he tells the students, "Mark it wrong and they can come to office hours if they want me to fix it." 53 was 1000x harder than 51

WORST PROFESSOR EVER. Took him for ICS 53. He had so much work, couldn't cope up with the class. Hard grader. Assignments are equivalent to 10 classes taken together. If you take 53 with him, you will end up failing all the other classes cause you won't have any time for to work on them.  Doesn't understand students have other classes and a life.

So this class is essentially broken up into two parts - the lectures and the labs. I say two parts because they feel distinct, unlike other ICS classes. I gotta say, Klefstad is great, but sometimes the material isn't explained in the best way. And the labs aren't too bad overall, but they can be frustrating. The Rolodex lab is just TOO LONG.
Great lecturer, extremely disjointed class. I learned more in this class than I have in most of my courses, but be prepared to work for your grade.

Klefstad admitted this was his first time teaching the ICS 51 material, and it showed. Lectures didn't correlate with quizzes and he couldn't even help us with certain things. Thankfully though, he recognized this and slowed down, admitting that it was too hard. So all was good at the end. He is otherwise a great professor and knowledgeable.

When the average for the second quiz is a 35%, you know something is wrong. This class is broken. Dr. Klefstad openly admits that hardware is not his area of expertise, and it shows. His lack of communication with the TA's make studying for exams impossible. It is a shame, since he seems like a very nice guy, just not a very good professor.
The worst class i have ever taken.

Great guy, but his instructions for projects aren't that good, and if you're not careful, you can get messed up by the grading. His grading is based on unit tests, so if you make a tiny mistake in your base code, you're basically just going to get a bad grade.
Excellent lecturer. Very able to readily answer questions. The only test (the final) was worth 38% of the grade. Start on projects early.
best ics professor
He was humorous during the class, and his teaching is good. All the material you need to know is also listed on the course website, along with the lectures.

Cool guy, beware of projects though and ensure that they are perfect. Lots of hidden little mistakes that can get you. Final was easy light my year - and from what my experience, the final will be pretty light if you show up and listen to his lectures.  TAs are great and allow you to request regrades if reasonable.

Really enthusiastic & effective lecturer (w/the caveat of being at late times; my lectures were 6:30-8pm so I was always really tired). Several major and time-intensive projects. The final was what did me in tho, being worth 40% of your grade and relatively difficult imo.
Professor Thornton, although very verbose during lecture, was very funny and much of his notes are well written. His projects are intensive but well written.

This guy is funny and he makes the subject super interesting even if it's just python. The final was mid for me (just actually learn how to code instead of chatgpting everything), and the projects are fairly easy.
Very straightforward professor and will make his expectations clear. His lectures are lengthy but they are good, just make sure to take notes. Grading on projects and final could be harsh.

He provides all the resources you would need to succeed in the class. Biggest advice is to take thorough lecture notes (which can be quite long) before class and try to pay attention during lecture. Do well on projects and reinforcement exercies and take them seriously. Doing bad on one project will make your life a lot more stressful.

I liked taking this professor's class. He explains concepts clearly and often uses examples from his industry experience, which makes lectures more engaging. His notes are detailed and very helpful for studying. The workload is project-based and can be time-consuming, but if you stay on top of it and prepare for the final, the class is manageable.

boring professor, kinda mean to students. thinks very highly of himself and not a very pleasant person to talk to. final was unnecessarily hard...ig i learned python though (all of this class can be self taught)

goated professor. he lectures very well and explains all the material in depth. his class is also extremely organized and everything is posted on his website. the final was pretty tough because it covered everything from the quarter. highly recommend anyone to take his class; you will definitely learn a lot :3

Absolutely goated lecturer and the course is structure is very organized. His course notes are very comprehensive if you have to miss lecture, but everything he expects you to know for the projects and final are fair if you're actually engaged with the course material.

Prof. Thornton's very enthusiastic in class about the content we are learning and it shows. Despite the 6:30pm lectures, his experience from his day job as a software dev definitely adds to the class. Just beware that his projects take a lotta time (start early!!). Final is hard but try to listen to his advice + use Gemini to generate practice Q's.

Professor Thornton is straightforward and efficient. You know exactly what he expects from you, and he will accept nothing less. His lectures are engaging and he's very passionate about the material. Make sure to start early on the projects, and study for the final! It's a tough class but definitely manageable.

DO NOT, I REPEAT, DO NOT, TAKE THIS PROFESSOR UNDER ANY CIRCUMSTANCES. He genuinely might be the worst professor ever in terms of lecturing and teaching. His projects suck and do not help me learn. His final might be the worst type of test ever. MAKE SURE TO GRIND FOR THIS GUYS' FINAL.

No midterm might be the worst part about this entire final. This professor makes this test as hard to get an A  in as possible. He can't stop talking about his stupid dogs and how much he loves them. His pacing during lectures makes his lectures hard to follow. Additionally, he really baits you in the final which is notoriously difficult.
Dr. Thornton's projects are a lot of work. But if you split up the work and don't procrastinate, you will succeed. Overall, a great professor and gives excellent lectures!

goat. sensational lectures and writeups. if you're here to whine about project 3, drop out of cs. final is very fair, make sure to study EVERYTHING. does all this while working 9-5. his code is genuinely the cleanest and most graceful stuff ever. nothing short of inspirational. unironically the lebron of lower div ics coursework.

Honestly, his personality isn't the best. Best described as cool guy unless u really interact with him then can be a d1ck. 5 assignments, hw isnt impossible, but definitely lengthy (but not impossible, but tough projects). Lots of help w lab from TA. Will say that his exam is FAIR, but not easy. Exams mainly hard bc he crams 10 wks into 1 exam.
thornton is actually biggest opp, gives cool math teacher (derogatory)
He really knows his stuff
All notes are published online and pretty much word for word of what he says during lecture. The projects are pretty difficult and just hope he curves your grade well for the final.

His lectures were okay, but felt long. Projects were generally okay, with project 1 being the hardest and project 4 being the easiest. The late policy is fair. The worst part of this class is the final, which is 40% of your grade. Very little information is given out about the exam, and you're left to fend for yourself for test prep.

He's unique in that he lacks the frills other professors have. No study guides, no extra credit, and offers little room to ask questions. It's as if he believes his content cannot be left to interpretation, and to be fair, he tried hard to achieve that. Lectures are great, and he has a great written version of them. Projects are a bit hard though.

Amazing teacher, class is difficult. I learned more than all classes before, you will get out as much as you put in. He knows what he's talking about, the class is really well structured. Easy to be overwhelmed, but it's doable to succeed. The truth is this class is made for those who enjoy CS, if you don't like the major you won't do well.

He has a lot of resources available for students on his website and there is no much work besides weekly exercises and 4 projects. The final is difficult study hard for it. I recommend going to lectures because reading the notes cannot answer questions you might have, but he does. Focus on projects and try to get as close to 100%.

All lecture notes are posted online, you can succeed without attending any lectures if you are willing to read through the online content. Projects 2/3 were the hardest; make sure to start them in advance. The final is difficult, but there is a very generous curve. If you don't procrastinate on homework/studying you will get an A.

Thornton is very inspirational and his projects were interesting (1 and 3 were time-consuming, while 0, 2, and 4 were light). He curves final grades, and the curve depends on the final average for your lecture. The lecture that took the final 2 days before mine got a 38% average, while we got 60%. My final grade was a 85.4%, but it became an A.

4 projects and 9 sets of exercises that'll keep you busy at all times. It's best to start everything early, esp the projects (1 > 3 > 4 > 2 hardest to easiest). The final is extremely hard but is saved by heavy curving. He has comprehensive notes on his website but his lectures are really good so you should attend. I def learned a lot from him.

This class is definitely difficult, and the projects can be a lot of work (start early!!), but you learn so much from it not only about Python, but about core coding concepts. Some of the lectures can be a little dry, but it's all in the notes. Final was heavy, but definitely doable and class ends up curved. Would take again, one of the best profs

Prof. Thornton is probably the most engaging CS professor I've taken. His lectures are comprehensive and the notes on the website are too, so even if you're a bit behind you have available resources. The class is fairly difficult, but with enough effort it isn't too bad. Just beware of the final.

Fair professor, his class gets easier once you get used to the structure of it (coming from H32). Doable projects, but the guides are very wordy, and often disorganized--make sure to read Ed Discussion for any clarifications/edge cases. Didn't go to lecture all that much, just be prepared to READ through his notes (which saved me for the final)!

Prof. Thornton's lectures were very informative and well-structured, however most of its content can be found in the notes he posts online. The final was difficult, so pay attention to the smaller things per category in the notes. Understand each lecture's content when you are assigned the exercise sets to make it easier in preparing for the final.
Thornton teaches the course well; however, the final is pretty bad. There is no practice final or anything for the final and consists of very little thing in the notes.
He's the biggest yapper in the school, and I didn't learn anything from the stuff he was saying and writing on his website about the class content.

I wouldn't want to be friends with him because his ego is more massive than the low taper fade meme, but he is an outstanding professor who know's what he's doing. Just make sure to read project instructions thoroughly and don't be one of those students who asks dumb questions on Ed Discussion because he will get triggered.

Thornton teaches incredibly well, both the content (how to program in python and use libraries), but also useful skills and techniques that help you code more effectively. The projects are pretty difficult if you don't have that much coding experience, and you'll have to balance the doing the reinforcement exercises at the same time.

I thought the class was super clear and well-designed, and I definitely got a lot of Python knowledge out of it. Thornton and the TA's are super understanding that you're a beginner, and the course is very accessible, though a lot of homework via projects. Final exam isn't too bad, but it's worth a lot of the grade relative to the projects.

Thornton is a wonderful lecturer, and he makes you really pay attention to how you structure your code. Projects were time consuming but were graded leniently. The final wasn't curved this last quarter as the average was a C+, higher than his usual average of 60-70%. The final dropped my grade from a 97% to a 89.74%, which was bumped up to an A-.

For people with years of Python experience, try to take credit by exam. If you missed the deadline like me: Some projects took up to 6 hours to complete, so do not procrastinate too much. He has a specific programming style he wants you to adopt, make sure to read through his code and notes to understand what he expects in projects and the final.
NOT STRAIGHT TO THE POINT AT ALL!! It's impossible to filter out the important things from his lectures and online notes.

The final is worth 40 percent of your grade and just make sure you know what your doing, projects and stuff r hard yea but it dont matter cause that final will mess ur grade up even if u got a 100 before. This q, the average was a 37 percent on the final(not jk).There is a really nice curve tho dpnding on the average of final(10%ish) so dont choke.

Honestly a great lecturer but the projects can be hard/tedious. Go to lab because there will be angels in there that can help you with any issue you might have. What ever you do, make sure you're walking into that final with an A- or above. 
Project difficulty rating: (hard to easy) 1 > 4 >= 3 > 2
It's a lot of work. Typically, if you do it and give it an honest effort, you'll be graded decently. Lectures are important, the lab is optional.
This class is really fun and his enjoys teaching ALOT. There is a lot of HW but he makes you excited to learn and grow as you start your journey in this field.

ONE OF THE BEST CS PROFFS! He's def rly hard with projects so make sure you start early to get feedback. Office hours are a great place to get help! He's very respected and his lectures are actually so helpful
I took his ics33, it was amazing, even though i cried for 5 days when i was writing pj1. I wish I can take his ics45c class, because nadia ahmed is making me cry every single day.
Amazing professor, highly recommend showing up to lectures even if course material seems easy because of how great his lectures are.

Definitely start preparing for the final early as it is 40% of your grade. While projects were time consuming, they honestly kind of saved my grade. Start on the projects early and write lots of tests to ensure that your program actually works. Thornton is also quick at responding to ed discussion posts which is great when students have questions.

good lecturer; explains clearly and is engaging, though INCREDIBLY visibly arrogant. projects are way easier than most say, especially if you start on time, and other hw is basically nonexistent. however, final is impossible to study for, daunting, and ruins most grades. treat the class as final prep, and don't get offended by his slack replies.
very very difficult course, the final is 40% of ur grade.. but very decent curve at the end b/c the averages are low. START EARLY on projects!! u do learn a lot from him tho.
you can tell this professor knows his stuff. VERY challenging class but you really do get to learn a lot from him.

Amazing professor, & absolutely engaging. The first & fourth project, & the final are THE WORST (he does curve the final grade slightly though). Try to spend projects with others if you don't get concepts (no code copying of course), & in emergency, it's possible to finish projects in 2-3 days (this may require all nighters & a strong work ethic).

Professor Thornton is without a doubt one of the best lecturers in the ICS department. Every lecture is well thought out and is packed with useful information. Most of the problems with the class are with the rough grading and with his personality itself. Simply put, he's not very nice to talk to, but I guess that's the tradeoff for good teaching?

He's not that bad but it is stressful. I did bad on project 1 ( < 50%, not too hard if you start early), but did well on everything else, including the final. Make sure to study everything: go through every single sentence in his notes and understand it; I found it helpful to recode his examples. Try to start latest a week before the final.

Easily the hardest class out of the ICS 30 series but the lectures are great, especially if you like dogs. Final is pretty rough, as its common for class averages to be 50% or less, but projects and exercises are doable if started early- emphasis on the start since that really is the hardest part of most of the projects. Great teacher and class.
Don't talk to him, bad personality

The class WILL be hard. But if you take the time to learn the material, you will be okay. Thornton does not get enough credit for answer almost every question in his EDD. His lectures are amazing, and he does get quite inspirational, especially in the final lecture. Thornton knows his stuff, just get ready to put in some work to learn the content.

Took 32A, class is good and lectures engaging but good lord be sure to time manage and work ahead with projects. Reinforcement exercises also annoying. Try to collaborate with peers as much as possible and get ahead as much as you can. Keep afloat with projects and exercises, final usually has decent curve

Thornton was an amazing professor who is passionate about python and teaching in general. It's sometimes hard to pay attention in class but when you do, studying for the final is a lot easier since his tests truly reflect his notes. Try to pay attention in class and skim his lecture notes after. Projects are really long though so plan well.

If you care about your GPA, you shouldn't take his class. You will need to spend much more time than you expect to get a good grade on his projects and assignments. The final exam worth 40% and the average grade for the final exam of last semester is about 50%.

I miss Thornton. He was a blessing compared to everyone else in the ICS department. The first project and the fourth were 100% the most difficult, everything else was doable but start those early. Make sure to not fall behind lectures from week 6-10 bc those were the most important parts  of the class. The final was definetely incredibly hard..

Good lecturer. Work is kind of heavy but late policy is lenient and he is super active on ed. If you have programming experience the projects are really easy but the instructions are super long (time reading/digesting is comparable to time actually coding). He gives enough online notes for you to comfortably skip lec as long as you catch up

Having taken 32A with Thornton, 33 didn't seem too bad. Project 1 was quite hard, but the rest were easy. His project write-ups are really long, so it takes a while to figure out exactly what to do. He answers questions on Ed by telling you to read the write-up. Lectures are fun, especially with the pictures of Boo and/ or Chance at the beginning.

Projects are reasonable, reinforcements are easy if you read the notes and pay attention. Exam was by far the most difficult I've taken (I'm writing this over a year after having taken the exam). Most questions about projects are answered in writeup if you read it carefully -- yes it's dense but it's comprehensive. Attend his OH if you need help :)

Very good lectures that keep you engaged, though if you cant attend all his notes are on the website. Reinforcement exercises annoying but manageable. Work on projects well before and take advantage of lab hours to verify. Final is a bit difficult but long as you keep up with the rest of the class should be good. Also love boo :)

Great lecturer and professor. His lecture is just him going over his notes, so If you have trouble visualizing his notes go to lecture. 4 projects, first one will make you crazy. Overall he's a really really good teacher but his answers to Ed discussion questions are just him quoting his website and he changes requirements to projects unexpectedly.

Thornton is a really fun professor! His lectures never disappoint and you will definitely learn well with him. The class itself isn't too difficult. As long as you start projects early and spend an adequate amount time on them, go to lab if you need help, and truly understand the material you will be fine.

One of the best lecturers I've ever had, he makes it very engaging and clearly explains topic in interesting manners. His projects are a lot of work, and can be very difficult and unforgiving, but they are very well thought out nonetheless.

Great lectures. He explains things thoroughly and clearly. There are comprehensive notes on the course website for your reference. Projects are fun and helped to develop my coding skills. Final is the only exam, but that's how college classes are sometimes. Overall amazing professor.
DONT TAKE HIM IF YOU DONT WANT TO RUIN YOUR GPA AND SCHOOL YEAR

I am not the best at coding and this class is very difficult but if you put in the work and attend labs you will do fine. The final exam was very difficult but the curve was amazing. The notes go very in depth so if you are ever stuck on something you can usually find a way to solve it in the notes.
The final is 38% which drops your grade at the end of the quarter after having A for the whole quarter!

Class moves fast, especially if you've never used Python before. Projects are pretty big & exercise sets every week, but you get a lot of time for them. Lectures are good but skippable, since his notes basically cover everything from lectures. Regularly check Ed Discussion since he will post clarifications or answers to edge cases for projects.

One of the few CS professors I've had who knows how to teach, extremely prepared and enthusiastic towards teaching. Although the projects and assignments are tough you learn a lot from it and I would suggest starting ASAP. My only main gripes  was the feedback given for projects were vague and sometimes the instructions were a lot to read through.

Loved the class until end. When released the grades, apparently I got an A- because they had to "equalize" project grades and it lowered my scores. I got 30/30 on every project, and this was the difference for an A & A-. Of course its a stupid & specific thing to care about, don't mind me -- do great with the knowledge & don't let grades scare u!

Do read everything he says because he leaves a lot of hints for what he's expecting, it's just hard to sift through the jumble. You need to be on Ed all the time because even though he writes movie scripts instead of instructions, he will still leave out key things he is planning to grade on. Overall, nice guy who is obsessed with his dogs.
Tooooooooooo muchhhhh work!!!!! Even after doing all of it, you get a lower grade on the final, which is 38%, and drop everything down because it is too difficult.

Thornton is likely the most respected lecturer in UCI's CS department. The homework and projects are always informative, and there are lots of things to learn in the class even for those who are experienced in Python. Most importantly, he clearly enjoys teaching his students.
Be prepared to have a lot of projects and an extremely hard final at the end of the quarter that is worth almost half your grade...
most people in their have body odor and don't shower to stay up working on the projects. they are really difficult projects tho

Nothing made me more stressed than running to the labs at 8am for the TA's to help fix my project.... he treats projects as essays basically. So much to read and very unclear... He always talks about his dog which is adorable. The lectures are clear, but dont get behind and work on the project during class or you're screwed.

Interesting guy. Great lectures, great notes, very knowledgable about software, and I definitley learned lots about software design principles from his class. HOWEVER, his project instructions either have you sticking your face into the screen to find specifics, and sometimes they are vague. Keeping up to date with Ed Discussion is a MUST.

Thornton is a great lecturer. Prolly the most well-prepared and informative lecturer I've ever encountered on campus yet. His projects and weekly exercises are quite time consuming, so be prepared to do a lot of work. As long as you put in the effort and do the best you can, you'll do great! He's also a very funny guy!

Expect to camp EdDiscussion 24/7 because his directions on projects (or homework) is NEVER CLEAR! He will perpetually add more and more requirements that weren't originally elucidated and screw you over last minute (guaranteed :D ).

he dims the light in lectures which makes it really easy to fall asleep.
LOTS of homework, get ready to code a lot...

He is quite an engaging and fun professor! I really enjoyed his lectures and his explanations were quite clear, his side stores were also great. The only thing is his projects are quite difficult so start early on them. Also, his notes are extremely comprehensive, so if you were to miss a lecture, then you won't really be missing much information.

Professor Thorton does a great job in explaining lectures and notes for ICS 33 course. However, the instructions for his assignments are rather vague and lengthy, which makes it quite stressful to complete within a limited timeframe. Grading criteria is also terribly strict, so I'd recommend avoid taking this class for your own sake.

Good lecturer, concepts are clear and you learn a lot. Would rate the class as a 5, but he always seems extremely rude in one on one with students asking questions after class. Maybe hes just tired, but do yourself a favor and dont talk to him after class to preserve a good image of him in your mind

The first great CS professor I have taken here. Project guidelines are super wordy but the criteria for what you are to accomplish is made super clear. Lectures are awesome and extremely informative. You will learn A LOT in this course. The class is tough and be ready to reserve plenty of time for it.

The GOAT. I would go to his lectures purely for the sake of his dog Boo, but it turns out that his lectures are also very helpful. Projects are very doable in a reasonable amount of time, reinforcement exercises are tough but helpful, and don't expect to do amazing on the final. Although the final average is low, he "curves" very heavily.

great lectures/communication with accessible notes and help directly from the professor online. the exercises best help you prepare for the difficult final while the projects have long reading prompts with no feedback whatsoever. there is enough leniency (big curve, one-time late project with no penalty) to make him a fair and respected professor.

Good lectures and projects. Though I wish we got better feedback since course material is freely available and all of our tuition goes toward grading. Feedback is usually "you failed a test" or "you got this error." Exercises were weirdly more difficult than projs. And I wish he was more patient in interactions with students. But I did learn a lot.

Just a good professor overall. I definitely learned a lot in this class. Readings provided on his website are pretty engaging. 
Final is notoriously hard. Honestly bank on the curve. I got a 47% on the final after studying for a week straight (and somehow still ended up with a B)
pulled the fattest curve after the final. W professor that gives clear instructions on all assignments.

VERY crystal clear instructions and VERY responsive to student questions outside of class. START YOUR PROJECTS EARLLLYYY. Also very generous in late policy and probably one the best cs lecturers. Class is hard but it is meant to be. If you survive this class then your golden.

8 Reinforcement exercises that were very difficult. Project 1 was the hardest project that I have ever done (I did not finish it). Start studying for the final early as it is known to be difficult. If you take this class, make sure to start projects very early and stay on top of the readings.
Just one the best professor you could ever met. The class is hard but you are learning a lot if you pay enough attension.

You definitely learn a lot in Thornton's class and come out with more knowledge than you go in with. He is extremely tough, but fair. The class will be tough, you just need to put in the hours for the projects. My one complaint is that the walls of text of the project writeup led to me losing points by a requirement only mentioned in one sentence.
Great guy, definitely makes you put in some work, but he's very thorough in what he teaches and you'll walk out with a really good basis of python. His class also prepares you really well for ICS 33.
comprehensive lecturer, and i will say the projects demand a significant amount of your time but the learning that you get out of them is phenomenal. common goatton W

Great professor, extremely passionate, and funny lectures. Gave the biggest curve(whole letter grade) at the end of the quarter, and was able to pass as a result. 

Final is extremely difficult, this quarter's average was 50%, and the one before was 40%.

Start projects and homework sets early!

Definitely recommend taking him! The class can be tough, but you truly grow your knowledge. Compared to other professors that teach ICS 32/ICS 33, he passionately teaches you the material during his lectures, along with plenty of open labs/opportunities to answer questions. He's funny too.
He's great. His lectures are really helpful and fun, but aren't mandatory by any means because all of his (quite comprehensive) notes are online.
unmatched.

The online notes are very helpful
Exercises and projects use automatic tests so you can't regrade them, making me very nervous when submitting them.
No quiz and midterm, no reviewing material for the final, though it's actually very easy

sometimes the lectures would be pretty slow because they are 80 minutes. The projects take a TON of time, but the rubric is clear and you don't have midterms. Start early so that even if you don't code much in the start, you give yourself time to start thinking of solutions for the projects. Final was not bad if you did the projects. Tough but fair
Thronton the goat, I thought I was going to fail, but that man pulled the fattest curve I have ever seen. Love you Thornton, and Boo.

Thornton gets a lot of hate for being very difficult. While it is true, the amount you'll learn in the class will be well worth it and he is a great professor. There are 4 projects and 8 hws and all are quite time-consuming so start early! His lectures weren't mandatory and I his notes were more than enough. They were very concise.

Leaving this because I had no idea how to study for the test: study the small stuff, like what if you added two list variables that had brackets? Or what would produce certain data types? Can you str a bool? Can you bool an str? Is BooMan appropriate python naming? Hoping this helps!

Great notes on his website. Ample directions, his lectures are cool, he responds pretty fast if you email him. But i dunno he just seemed grouchy answering students' questions and often told us to just look harder instead of  helping. Which I mean I get but it did not feel very friendly. Lectures took me a long time to read and projects were tough.

I won't lie, his class is extremely difficult like BEYOND anything I have ever taken. However, that is the beauty of this class, its a big challenge to get through, probably the biggest. His projects are hard and so is everything else in the class. It only prepares us for what's coming. This class made me confident in my future classes; did not ace
get an another professor

Weekly homework is not doable last minute. Projects are time consuming (3 days average) but not difficult. You're going to need a LOT of time for projects, plan it out, it helps. Be ready to code 300-600 lines per project. Try to account for all scenarios. Average homework takes around 2-6 hours. Make friends, perspective helps a lot

Professor Thornton is a very unique professor. You will have projects that have very little grading criteria and somewhat vague incstructions. However, his teaching style and ability to convey information during lectures is great. If you want to learn from someone who is passionate about what he does, take Thornton.

The coursework is WAY beyond college level material. Thornton has no heart. The projects are not comparable to 31 or 32 and it is outright ridiculous. This is the one course that is really discouraging and makes me worry about having to change my major, which is honestly so messed up. Don't trust the "awesome" reviews on this page...beware.

Absolutely no rubric, Ed Discussion, where you can ask questions to the professor is overflowing with an insane amount of questions that he answers just by quoting the instructions. But the reason why we use ED is cuz the instructions make no sense. Docked points for reasons we didn't even know about till it's too late. Project writeups unclear

The way he teaches the class and assigns homework/projects is almost as if he thinks we already took this class. Exercises that sometimes make no sense and projects that include 4-5 topics we learned in class are assigned weekly. However, more often than not, we learn 1-2 of these topics 1 or 2 days before the due date, making it very difficult

ICS 33 is pretty difficult with him. That being said, he provides all his detailed lecture notes online (which are incredibly helpful imo), is accessible on ED discussion (and gives well-thought-out answers most of the time), and is incredibly passionate. He's great if you want to be challenged and learn, but terrible if you want an easy grade.

yes it is VERY HARD and CHALLENGING, but be aware, CS major is not easy and not for everyone, if you found it hard and can not pass, think about switching to a social major. Professor Thornton is one of the best professors I ever had, simply because I learned 10x more with him than with another professor.

This class in particular is a mess. He expects us to be fullstack engineers and we never have enough knowledge to begin on these projects, exercises almost have nothing to do with the projects, like be fr Thornton, please. And those stories at the beginning of his project writeups are absolutely unnecessary, and no one reads them or has the time.

ICS 33 is practically torture, with no room to breathe given the reinforcement exercises and the projects. Definitely manageable, but you have to start as soon as possible. Notes are basically reemphasized in the lectures. Thornton thinks we have no other class to take aside from his and puts the workload at full steam.

33 isnt as bad as RMP makes it sound. Prof is enthusiastic, has good lectures, responds quickly on Ed. Projects are reasonably difficult; start early, ask questions, go to lab. 4-5 HW problems per week (can be vague but are good practice). Thornton's 33 is time consuming so take 12 units or 16 easy units.

Please replace Thornton with Ali, he doesn't even teach us, The Teacher Assistants are literally doing his job for him. No clear rubric and the teacher gate keeps the criteria, so how do we even know what we're doing? Worse cs professor I've had, and extremely unfair. This man has no heart, colder than ice.

I've taken Thornton in prior years, and he's always been rude and irritable in office hours. God forbid you step out of line or he singles you out and berates you loudly. Looking at how he's teaching ICS 33 this qtr, I'm glad his terrible personality and bad-temper is finally getting exposed.

No clear grading criteria for these hard projects, and then they fail you because you didn't meet every single little case that needs to be handled (even though we legit don't know what the rubric is, even the TA's don't know and aren't sure). Extremely hard projects, that aren't even taught enough about the information we need to do them.

Grading criteria is very vague for complex projects. Directions for projects are long, and ambiguous. TA attempt to help, but their individual attention is very limited. Im constantly stressed and frustrated. Do yourself a favor and don't take him if he's teaching ICS33!!
Ridiculous project design. He just expects students  attending lab for whole day , but  there  are not enough TAs in the lab. On average  if one spends  90mins in lab, he may get 3 mins help from TA.

Poor assignment descriptions and instructions. Spent at least 3 days a week on assignments for this class. Projects are unrelated to the class content and when you encounter a part you don't know, you have to spend a lot of time asking others because per Lab is only assigned 1 LT!!! You may have to wait 1 hour to ask LT!!!

Very inaccessible lectures (6-7:50), the last train leaves at 5:24 so anyone commuting by train cannot attend. The grading is terrible as the rubric is a mystery (one q had a mean of 29%)
The first project is nothing on the actual material, completely irrelevant  
We are learning 3 different stuff in one week (python, SQL, and O notation)
Terrible.

Excellent course. Graded by weekly reinforcement exercises, 5 projects, and a final. Projects require ample time to finish and test well, Final is difficult and largely based on deep understanding of the notes. While difficult, this class is curved and teaches data structures very very well. Great lectures and excellent notes. Will set you up well.

Class is composed of projects/hw/final

HW was very fair and helpful. 

Projects were a bit hard but doable and manageable, not easy but was not bad to the point where I would want to complain.

Final was worth 33%. I feel that it was worth way too much, so even if you do well on all hw/proj, if you do ehhh on final, say bye bye to that A ahahah

Looking back, learning C++ with Thornton was ideal. I liked how he coded in class to thoroughly introduce a concept. He is great at explaining things and goes into conceptual things such as "why" things work. His online notes are sized well *cough cough Pattis* and his typing speed is really fast. Only gripe is that the lectures were kinda long.
A+++++++ for Thornton and his booo!! best in ICS.

I found his projects to be fun and engaging to complete, but they required a ton of time, and unit tests. The Final was 33% of the grade, and even though it was fair it was extremely difficult. I relied mostly on his (very well crafted, and detailed) notes, as I found myself just reading them during the lecture anyways.
It was online and pretty easy. Lectures aren't mandatory so you can just use the notes if you want, but I do think his lecture give you valuable insights. And everyone loves Boo!
One of the best professors. Really teaches you to appreciate the "why" behind computer science. A fun and captivating lecturer. UCI needs more Thornton. Workload is super manageable and practical.
