Super chill professor, does basically everything online. Explains the programming concepts very well and makes them easier to grasp. Projects are tough and time-consuming but also fairly interesting.

Thornton teaches 45C well. His notes&lectures are detailed and you learn about C++ and foundational knowledge. However, the grading criteria for projects is unclear. I try really hard to make my projects well written and designed just to get a B or C for something small like using the wrong data structure and to be told my grade cannot be disputed.

Great notes and a solid straightforward lecture style. Get started early with projects if possible. Project could get decently challenging but you will learn a lot. Highly recommend - he definitely deserves his high rating.

Thornton is an amazing teacher, always clearly explaining concepts and answering questions with full patience and never making someone feel like they're less than for not knowing something, I hope to take more classes with him. Projects and homeworks are very manageable as long as you start early, and the final project was the easiest of all.
Great lecturer, understands how to keep students buckled in and excited. Start projects early and youll 100% be fine.
All lectures pre-recorded, accessible OH and labs. I had to retake this class. To succeed, you need to time manage and don't fall behind on assignments. Watch lectures to do the weekly exercise sets.

My favorite professor in the ICS department! His lectures are amazing and easy to digest despite the challenging subject material. He is very accessible outside of class and the difficulty level of the projects and exercise sets were perfect. Learned a lot and was able to build off ICS31 really well. Definitely recommend taking him for 32!
Best teacher I've had for coding, even if I didn't do too well in the class.

Do not take this class if you are not proficient in at least 1 programming language or took APCSA. I took CSP & wasn't prepared for the class. Class gets fast & content heavy after week 2 (drop deadline). Fun lectures, but tons of projects. Optional labs, but GO TO LABS!! TAs & LAs will help you. Can go to any lab, no matter which one u enroll for.

He's a great overall professor. There is nothing you have to do in person. Your grade is made up of a few practice exercises, 6 projects, and 1 final project. The 6 projects are time-consuming, but if you start early there's nothing to stress about. The final project was the easiest out of all of them.

Great Professor! His lecture videos are very engaging and helps to lead you through his thought process in writing programs. Whenever someone asks a conceptual question, he always makes sure to start from the root of the question and answer those questions thoroughly. Exercise Sets and Projects are fun and apply concepts from lec vids thoroughly.

If you mess up early on in the class, your grade will be screwed as every single assignment matters. So don't slack off in the beginning and work consistently and incrementally (even though it's difficult to do with all of our other classes courseload lol).

The class was very well organized and contained a lot of good information. There are a lot of important concepts, so make sure you pay attention and learn through the reinforcement exercises. Projects were difficult at times but staff was there to help you. Overall would definitely recommend!
Everything made sense in this class and his notes were straight to the point. The difficulty and length of his projects vary greatly from project to project. Just make sure you start early.

Thorton's class is well designed, but it forces you to be running straight out of the gate. Projects hit you back to back, with a few days to rest in between. For COVID online class, he had "reinforcement exercises" every week as homework. Material is decently hard, but he has good notes that can help you. Prepare for testing hella edge cases.

Thornton is an amazing teacher and is perfect for the lower division ICS classes. His lectures are very clear and very interesting. The reinforcement exercises are great for filling gaps in your knowledge. The projects can take a large amount of time, but are interesting. My favorite was project 3.

Thornton, though rigorous, is often VERY detailed & clear. His lectures perfectly coincide with his notes (down to his examples). You can survive off the notes, but the lectures are super helpful for visual learners. Programming projects are fun, though sometimes it's uncertain if your implementation will work to specifications (what he's testing)
Great teacher overall, responsive and understanding

You will really learn a lot from Thorton and his lectures. There's no need to read his notes if you watch the lectures. He will teach you everything you need to do the projects, so don't feel intimidated by them. Weekly exercise sets are not too bad either. He also responds to questions super quickly, which is a big plus. Best professor for ICS 32!
No exams for online classes. Projects and exercises are complex but doable. Excellent notes and lectures.

He is overall a pretty good professor, but the class would be a bit challenging for new coming freshmen with a little experience in Python. I did learn a lot from this class. No tests during online class, only programming assignments (not very hard), five projects (take time), and a final project(It is basically a large programming assignment)

Took his class that was adapted for covid-19. It was definitely easier since there were no exams. He's a really great lecturer and teaches you how to write better code. The projects were fun to do, and most of them were straightforward. Couldn't have asked for a better professor and class.

I never went to a single lecture but his notes explain the programming concepts really well and in a concise manner, only had to refer to the official documentation a handful of times. Too bad he wouldn't let us use more advanced programming concepts not taught to us on the final but it was still easy. Otherwise he's a pretty good professor.

Thornton is awesome. He codes alongside his lectures and explains his process in a way that makes sense. His notes are kinda dense, but they're helpful and align with his lectures in a way that helps reinforce stuff that may not have made sense upon first reading them. He gives a reasonable amount of work too. I really can't complain about him.

Definitely a tough class but if you like programming hard projects you'll enjoy it. He's very clear with what he wants in each project and you could honestly get by without asking him a single question for clarification. He also has a nice voice and is generally cheerful :)

I took ICS45c during COVID-19 when we shifted to online learning and it was a lot easier because exams were replaced by weekly exercise sets. You still learn though! He prerecords lots of lecture videos, provides detailed online notes, and uses live lecture times as office hours. Very responsive on Piazza and tutors/TAs are helpful.

Very good online lectures and interesting projects. He takes forever to grade assignments, though, so you never really know where you stand in the class and his grading requirements are unclear. Overall good professor and I feel I learned a lot about C++ programming.

Took him during COVID so my take might be different. What makes Thornton much different from other ICS profs is that he is really good at teaching. We had weekly exercises that were easy and then 4 projects with 1 being optional. The only bad thing Id say is that the projects can take much longer than you think. But unforgettable experience it was

Kind and hilarious professor. Have had him for 32A and 45C, did well in 32A and would have done better in 45C if I had turn in my assignments on time. What you would expect out of a CS class, as long as you do your work, it's not hard to get an A. Not super tests heavy, projects take up a good portion of your grades. Definitely take him when u can.
The lecture is in general enjoyable. Some of the materials are not explained but can be found on public sources. Projects rubric is unclear so be mindful. PS his side stories are great.

By far the best professor in the ICS department. I feel like this class really teaches you a lot. There's a major curve at the end and it's fairly easy to do well as long as you score well on the projects.

He rambles a lot and it's hard to tell where you stand in the class due to the massive curve, but he's overall pretty good. His notes are good, if a bit wordy. Projects and tests are hard, but there is a large curve and I thought they were pretty fun. Fair late policy. I recommend using the 99hr extension on project 3 or waiting untill the end.

I'm a transfer student and so far I've spent so much time trying to teach myself CS concepts/languages. I took 45C at UCI and it was more of the same. But now in Thornton's ICS 46, I'm learning so much and his lectures and notes are so clear and helpful. I've spent the majority of my time this quarter on this class but it's worth. highly recommend.
Professor thornton is really good. He is always there to help students and he really curves a lot.

Thornton is overrated as a professor and other professors like Pattis are way better. His projects take way too much time and when I went to his office hours he kept being rude to people who asked him questions. Such temperamental people should not be teaching.

Be prepared for him to get off topic quite a bit. You most definitely don't need to waste your time in lecture, if you are willing to carefully read through his notes. His notes are his midterm/final. Projects are tough, but labs make it easier. Do the labs well, it will save your grade.

Pretty easy class if you just try a little. He sometimes has bad days (everyone does) so don't let it get to you. He's a good lecturer. The second half of the class was quite a bit more boring than the first. Crazy curve (A- cutoff was 82). Tests make you apply concepts in C++ so understand them well. A bit overhyped but still a GREAT professor!!

Thornton has become overrated- I expected greatness, but all I found was a professor better than some of his peers. His material/projects are top notch, but he is boring as a lecturer and moody on some days. Don't get me wrong, he's a good professor, but he's not as great as everyone says he is. There's a large curve, and tests are difficult.
I do believe Thornton's 32A should be taught after 33. He teaches you how to become a proper programmer in the industry.

Thornton's a good lecturer, although I didn't really go to class for the most part because 45C is a pretty straight forward course. Even project 3/4 are not really that difficult - I never used my 99 hr late pass. Just start a little bit early and you'll be fine.

After the second half of the quoter, His lecture gets super heavy for C++ beginners. I did horribly bad on the midterm. I spent hours reading his notes and examples. I even recorded his voice to review lectures. Took Notes. I spend hours to read/code compile/debug and guess what I was not able to submit project3 and 4!! Not good for amateurs!

He can be very rude when you ask him questions. If he's having a bad day, he shouldn't take it out on students by being unwelcoming when people just want to ask a question. One time, he accused me of being lazy when I just wanted to know if I could reuse his sample code for a part of my project.

lectures are interesting but if you learn fine from notes don't bother showing up; midterm and final are hard, he asks about all the small stuff you would never think of trying out yourself; start projects early & don't use 99 hr extension till project 3/4
Thornton might be a good lectures, but he seems very unwilling to help in office hour, and there is no piazza for this class. Ridiculous procedure for exam viewing.

A gem of the UCI CS department. Runs very organized classes, with well-designed projects with the right amount of challenge. Could do better on transparency with viewing exams and such but overall excellent, teaches well.

Many people sing praises of Alex. I get it. Hes funny, insightful and organized in lecture, but I cant say the same about the rest of the class. He seems very unwilling to help when I came to his office hour, and he only let you see the graded midterm if you turn in your student ID to him and put way phones? Who does that?

Best professor ever at UC Irvine, much much much much better than Shannon. Project 4 was the hardest and costed lots of time, be sure to start early. The exams was pretty easy, just read, understand his notes, and try itself on the computer, you should be fine.
his projects 3,4, and 5 are way too hard. His midterm and final are so difficult and the average on them is usually a C or less.
Best CS professor at UCI. His lectures are interesting and I can sit through them without getting distracted. Some of his projects are hard, and so are his tests, but you will learn.

A professor that actually teaches. Project 4 is the most tough project yet. We are given less time for it and nothing in the notes provide any hints except the the connect four module from away back. The previous three projects are light work compared to this. Start early or you will regret it. I legit spent a a week on it.
I like to do exercises to prepare my exams so I struggle in class. The projects are not very hard but START EARLY ON PROJECT 4! Alex is a good professor and his lecture is interesting. rip Boo.

Thornton is a good professor. However, Its not good idea to set up a overwhelming project (Project 4) for ICS 32 student. It could make students have no idea where to start and reduce ICS 32 students passion and confidence.

Lectures are pretty interesting, both because of the topics covered and how Alex talks (he's quite loud and expressive). There are 4 projects, with the 3rd one being the biggest jump in difficulty, but they all get you to practice coding well (functionally & design-wise). Tests are tough and sadly involve writing code. Solid ICS professor!

Great guy but lectures get boring (especially TuThu). Curves everything at end but nothing individually. No need to go to lectures, his notes have everything. Program 4 gets stupid. Midterms are what you'd expect. You learn a lot if you try!
Tests and projects are really hard. I like him and the way that he teaches a lot but oh man I wish he would make his midterm/final easier

Professor Thornton is an amazing lecturer and explains concepts very well. He is also very accessible outside of class and cares about his students. Projects are difficult so make sure to start early and plan out your projects. Exams require a good grasp of concepts and make sure to study all the notes because every topic is fair game.

Professor Thornton is a phenomenal lecturer, and he is able to provide the perspective of a full-time software engineer as well. ICS 46 is by no means an easy course - the projects are time-consuming and the tests difficult. However, Thornton will give you every opportunity to succeed and grow as a programmer. Accessible, caring, entertaining.

Thornton actually TEACHES. Always accessible. I attended class AND read & took notes from online lecture. This class asks for a lot but it is damn worth it. I feel much more confident in my ability to solve problems. Those projects can be crazy fun & hard. Midterm was 2x harder than the final. Aim to be above the average scores.

Gives amazing lectures that make up for ICS 31, assigns projects that are fun to do, grades the harder projects generously, but talks a bit too much about his dog that he sometimes has to rush the end of lecture, which is the most important part. Also, idk if anyone else suffered from the automated tests he uses to grade the projects, but I did.

Best professor at UCI I've had so far. His lectures always flew by since he knows how to teach. When doing coding examples, he always explains WHY he chooses to solve a problem the way he does. Exams were difficult but not impossible. Projects were hard, so make sure to go to another lab section if you feel your current TA isn't helping you.

Thornton is not an easy professor nor the concepts he teaches. So be prepared to spend a lot of time on this class and make sure you START YOUR PROJECTS EARLY. For midterm and final, just make sure you read his notes. EVERYTHING on the midterm and final is mentioned in his notes at some point. Also Be prepared to study yourself. Good Luck!

Thornton is the best teacher at UCI. Had him for 32, and 46 was also a great class. The midterm and final are hard, but curved like crazy. I was able to get an A. Not an easy class but very useful and important. Wouldn't want to take it with anybody else.

The class is a big leap from ICS 31 so be prepared to work a lot harder. The projects are difficult but doable if you start early on them. The midterm and final are very hard and there are no practice exams. Thankfully there is a generous curve at the end. A third of the class received a C- or below, which means they have to retake the class.

Engaging and interesting lectures. Projects can sometimes be tough, and require a lot of attention to detail to ensure correct implementation of data structures. Picky in the grading of them too - runs lots of hidden test cases against your programs to determine your score. Conceptual & detail-oriented exams that can be tricky.

the projects in this class are totally harder than the previous class. I had an A+ on 31 but I think I will fail in this class, and I have to retake this awful class. He won't give any sample for exams.

Thornton is solid! He's quirky and funny and really makes concepts clear. He has online notes that are basically his lectures which are really helpful. His projects are a bit challenging but teach you a lot. Get ready for lectures about his dog and a good time! Edit: No more dog :'( Rip Boo

This class wasn't actually that hard because he covered basic/simple topics in a concise/easy-to-understand way. But the midterm and final in his class were extremely difficult. To succeed, read his lecture notes carefully, work hard on the projects and try to do well on them. Professor Thornton curves so bad grades on tests won't screw you over.
Really nice class would take again

Prof. Thornton is an amazing instructor. I wish more CS classes were taught by him. It's not every quarter you come across such an inspirational professor. Get ready to program some 300-500+ lines of code per program.

One of the best ICS lecturers at UCI. Also one of those rare lecturers where every lecture was almost full. Unlike most ICS professors, he didn't just teach some new programming concepts, but he also provided insight on how to go about programming something interesting.
This man is the best of the CS Department of UCI. If I could I would take him all 4 years. God bless you Alex Thornton

Savor this class before you take 33. Make the most your free time now b/c Pattis bouta make your free times only one line. To prep for final just read his notes on his website and make sure you understand it well by testing on python shell.
His programming projects are challenging, but not too hard to solve. His midterm and final are not too hard, but you must be careful with those minor details of Python.

TOOK ICS32A! Though lecture isn't mandatory GO, it helps you for the projects & Thornton tries to be interesting. One midterm & final, 5 projects. Got a 59% on the midterm & a high 60 on the final but only got one B on the 1st project & A's for the rest, so don't worry if you're not the best tester, just do well on the projects & you should pass!

Thornton is a great lecturer! He kept it interesting and fun. The programming assignments were difficult, but I enjoyed them. I highly recommend going to all the lectures but labs are just free coding time, so you don't necessarily need to go. I only went to one lab the entire quarter. Overall, I enjoyed his class and I hope to have him again.

amazing instructor in ICS department. challenging, but doable. You learn a lot of real-world programming technique. tests are tricky so make sure to understand his notes and understand why things work. Interesting lecture you wont feel bored. I wish he teaches some upper divs as well.

This is the course you DO NOT want to make a single mistake. If you didn't pay attention, you pay for it with heavy price. And TA Yoshi, he just takes as much points as he can in the project unless you've done everything perfect.

Alex Thornton teaches good programming and design through intuitive projects. Lectures are amazing, notes and instructions are concise and focused. Just show up to lecture, review the notes, and start the projects early. Go to office hours if you're struggling with design or concepts. He'll be happy to offer resources or re-explain.

Projects aren't nearly as hard as people make them out to be. You might be forced to pull an all nighter at some point in the quarter but what else can you expect from an accelerated CS class. Thornton is reasonable and provides clear grading guidelines. Overall great class and great introduction to university level programming.

Projects weren't as hard as people claim but the grading is atrocious. Uses automated tests to grade homework so one deviation from the write up can fail multiple tests and bomb your project score even when 99% works. Midterm and final make up half your grade and writing code on paper is not a good way to test programming knowledge. Useless Lab.

He might be a good programmer, but for sure not a good teacher. He did not organize the class schedule well which left us had no enough time to finish the last two projects. The projects are extremely complicated and the two tests are extremely hard. Always publish his notes really late and not really useful for the tests.

Great professor, very good at teaching concepts and explaining them, and also humorous. The pacing really in the accelerated 32A class is no issue for most. Projects are mostly easily, except for one that was extremely time consuming. Tests are on the difficult side, but overall, the class was enjoyable.

I think the whole idea of 32A is bad because they try to teach you python during the first week, which is not only a lot of facts thrown at you at once but puts you behind schedule because, which is what happened this time. I disliked the class, projects were hard, notes weren't published on time, and he isn't very approachable for questions

This class really depends on you. It is a very serious class and you should expect to have a lot of work. It might be hard for someone who has just started programming, and someone who is experiencing python for the first time. Thornton is a tough grader and projects are not easy; however, they force the students to come to the lectures.

There can be bad teachers who teach easy classes, and good teachers who teach hard classes. This is an example of a great teacher who teaches a difficult class. He is vibrant, engaging, and is really responsive when you ask for help. You will have to work very hard in this class, but Thornton does everything to help you enjoy doing so.

Honestly think that while the course is difficult by nature, Thornton tries hard to keep the lectures interesting and applicable. The final projects were a bit too difficult to finish given the time constraints, but the overall difficulty is manageable with lecture attendance.

He gave the crazy long, hard project and wanted student to finish within few days. Assuming the students already knew everything and the lectures weren't related to project too much. You have to hand write code in the exam and the exams are crazy hard. The notes always came out late and almost never catch up with lectures.

Expects you to know everything ahead of time and if you don't know a topic, makes you feel bad about it when you ask for help. Labs are very open ended and doesn't help in office hours. Lectures are 90% focused about his dog and last 20 minutes of class are used teach relevant topics that are covered on the midterm and final (which are really hard)

Professor Thornton is easily one of the best CS professors at UCI. His lectures are clear and thorough and he has a good sense of humor. However, his lab assignments are pretty difficult and they do take a long time to figure out. In addition, his exams are ridiculously hard. Luckily he accounts for this with a big curve.
Focus on so many little things. The projects are crazy long and complicated. Very difficult!

Alex is one of the best professors I've ever had. His lectures are amazing! He is good at explaining things. He clearly knows where we need to get in this class. You can learn a lot from the projects he assigns. It's not hard to get a good grade as long as you really do your work. He's good at what he does and can make you love what you learn.
Favorite professor thus far at UCI. I highly respect and recommend Thorton.

Not only does he know his stuff he knows how to transfer that knowledge to his students. Great lecturer, solid examples in class. Exams are detail driven. Exams are not so much about your ability to program (that's tested with projects), more if you understand the minor details about the language.

Incredible professor. You definitely need to work hard for this class though, but thorntons enthusiasm I think makes his students enjoy the work enough that they'd be willing to spend time and effort on it. Huge curve at the end too, the final was very hard, I got a D but still ended up with an A in the class. An 83% overall grade was still an A.

Similar with grading and organization as ics32. Thornton does his best to make lectures interesting. If you miss lecture, notes are online. Projects are difficult but doable and you get a good amount of time to complete them. The midterm and final are super hard (averages were 50-60). But the curve was really good

As in ICS 32, Thornton is an excellent professor for ICS 46. Lectures were clear and engaging on fundamental data structure concepts. The projects were interesting, mixing both implementation and real-world applications of data structures/algorithms. Exams can be somewhat difficult/tricky - very conceptual with little C++ coding. And curves well.

Go Boo! Thornton's very informative live coding, along with detailed notes online, will ensure that you'll have all you need to do the projects. If you're coming in as a new programmer like many, you'll be in good hands. He teaches great coding practice, and the projects are just difficult enough to be good mediums to apply what he teaches you.

A real genuine professor that understands the student's to a very great extent. His lectures were really helpful towards his programming assignments, and he makes sure to make each lecture as lively as possible. Missing lecture isn't that big of a deal, since he posts his notes online, but I find that it's best to read the notes no matter what.

Like in ics 32, his lectures were conceptually great. Unfortunately, he sometimes took too long and had to rush some things during lecture, and wasn't as good as in 32 because of this. With this drawback, he's still really good. I would recommend him, but you need to make sure you stay up to date or else you will fall behind.
An eccentric and warm-hearted person who makes his intentions clear with his teaching. Class is reasonably difficult, and guy gives good lectures without making you fall asleep.

Thornton gives AMAZING lectures. He live-codes in lecture from scratch so you know exactly what he's doing. He also posts his lecture code online, along with very detailed information about the lecture material that day.  His projects get progressively more difficult, so make sure you know your ICS31 concepts. Also, be prepared for his dog, Boo.

I know a lot of people say this but it's true it is a HUGE step up from ICS31. The projects and midterm/final are a lot harder and really require you to know your stuff. He's a good professor, very engaging and clearly knows what he's talking about. There is a generous curve too.
Thorton was easily one of the best professors I've ever had.
Alex has fantastic and engaging lectures.  Computer science has never been this interesting before.

Thornton is very popular and extremely knowledgeable. His projects are doable. His exams are challenging and tricky. He does not pass back exams, so you cannot learn and study from them-- which is the only complaint I have about Thornton, because I, for one, learn a lot from my exams. Huge curve at the end of the course.
Top notch professor. Speechless. You will look forward to going to lectures!

Professor Thornton is a great lecturer and, at least from what I have been able to gather, always has well thought-out courses. Yes, the programming assignments are rather difficult and frustrating at times, but you do learn a lot. Beware of his tests. They are very difficult. But this class is curved and the curve is amazing.

Thornton is a brilliant professor - his lectures are insightful, informative, and entertaining ; you won't be bored. The projects require a fair amount of work but are fun and definitely interesting. His exams are difficult, and contain conceptual and coding questions. However, he curves the class generously at the end. Boo and him are great!

Thornton's lectures manage to be genuinely funny and interesting at the same time. He emphasizes his labs over his tests, because he knows just as much as we do that CS tests are kinda bullshot, and he mostly curves them out of the overall grade to make sure that the majority of the people will pass, or about 4/5 of the class in my case.

Labs are doable and fun(it depends on you. For me, they were easy but my peers didn't really love them). Exams are tricky. A lot of readings and practice to get concept. Very good and enthusiastic lecturer.

His lectures are important because concepts he mentions in class come up on the midterm and final. The midterm and final are tricky including matching sections as well as code and concepts. He curves pretty decently. The labs are fairly difficult so start early. Lectures were amazing, really great at getting you into the subjects.
The best professor.
Great professor

Written tests may have a few tricky questions so make sure to study the notes. Keep procrastination to a minimum on programs, especially when it comes to anything Othello. He talks about his son/dog Boo a lot, but you'll get used to it.

I kind of like him, but at the same time I kinda don't. He is definitely a passionate and helpful lecturer, but he can go on talking about irrelevant things sometimes. He also types really fast so it's a bit hard for me to keep up during lectures, however, he is still a good instructor. The labs are a huge jump from 31, and they are pretty hard.

Thornton's lectures were very interesting and you don't have to take notes since he posts them online with comments. This class took a hood portion of my time but if you don't procrastinate on the labs then it's not bad at all. The labs were awesome and graded fairly! Read his notes very carefully. He asks questions about little details from notes.

Pro. Thornton is definitely one of the interesting and responsible professors I've met. He can always give us inspiration especially at the beginning of  our CS study. And the final grade turns out great even if u feel bad about final.

HUGE jump from ICS 31. However, coming from someone with no experience other than that first class, I found ICS 32 to be manageable and rewarding. The projects are long, but interesting; make sure you don't put them off to the last minute! Thornton is a great and hilarious professor, I would definitely take another class with him (and Boo!).

ICS 32 is that attention-wanting child that takes too much of your time and you start to neglect other children (classes) if you're not the strongest in coding yet. It's a big jump from 31, but Thornton is a very energetic and helpful guy. You're forced to take little parts of notes and apply it to projects. He's a decent professor, but very tough.

Let's be real. ICS 32 is a giant jump from ICS31. This is going to be very hard compared to what you are used to. However, Alex does a great job at teaching this course and helps you get ready for real world applications in programming. Definitely attend every lecture and alway start your projects ahead a time! He's entertaining and clear.
Best college professor I've had yet! Lectures are long, but he keeps you entertained with a big personality and funny jokes.
Great professor! The projects are really cool and fun, and his lectures were the best.

After taking Alex for ICS 32, I was excited to see him again for 45C. Nothing has changed, great lecturer, explains things clearly, and the lecture notes online are easy to follow. Projects were a bit strenuous because it's C++ and the tests were highly conceptual, making it pretty difficult. Nonetheless, Thornton is awesome! So is Boo.

Thornton is one of my favorite lecturers. He starts his code from scratch and explains everything clearly. If you focus for the full 80 minutes, you'll learn a lot. Labs are difficult, but that's because C++ is so annoying to work with. Tests are even more difficult, but he curves grades at the end so you usually only need about a D to pass.

If you like Thornton, you'll like 45C. Definitely one of the tougher classes I've taken, but a ton of fun to figure out. C++ just sucks in general. I highly recommend you take this class with him, I learned a lot.

I learn a lot in lecture. Haven't needed to use the textbook once. He takes very thorough notes about every topic and uploads them to the website. Freely answers questions in lecture and bonus points for being funny. Overall 9/10.

Great lectures. Missing one is equivalent to missing your favorite TV show, except you actually learn something. Out of all the ICS 30 series professors, his assignments are the most practicaldown-to-earth.

Excellent Lecture, but is not an easy  A. You must attend every lecture and listen to what Alex is talking about to make sure you can do perfect for every project. Midterm avg. is 19 out of 26. Almost half of student may be failed this class. However, Alex is a very  excellent teacher.

If you're going to take ICS 46, do yourself a favor and take it with Thornton. The concepts are not easy, but Thornton spends a lot more time TEACHING you than telling you to go read the 1000-page-long notes (cough Pattis cough). His notes are thorough, but aren't online, so attendance is mandatory. The tests are really hard, but fair (take notes!)

I don't really understand why he's praised. His ics 32 was fine back then, but his ICS46 is pretty bad. I barely learn anything from him. He just goes over the basic concepts during the lecture and pretty much goes "Oh here you go, survive well!". His lecture is confusing and he goes around the bush, yet he doesn't provide any extra study material.

I'm currently getting close to wrapping up my third class taken with Thornton. I'll admit, his class is certainly not an easy A and the tests are pretty difficult. However,  all the credit that might bring your grade down on tests can reasonably be made up by doing well on projects. He teaches in a very life-applicable way, which I value greatly

You learn a lot in this course. Make sure you understand EVERYTHING in the lectures and don't procrastinate on the labs. They will probably take you longer than you think. Make sure to go to lecture too so you know how to do the labs correctly, instead of your own way. Overall he seems like a nice guy.

Best professor teaching me since the beginning of this school year. His lecture si truly interactive and interesting, partially because of his lovely Boo. Humble, humorous and helpful. Lab work spends up plenty of time, and yet sometimes the exams do go tricky. But nice to have it curved. Great pleasure to have him taught me ICS 32.

He is a great lecturer. He is definitely really helpful and responsive, such as in email. Just spend time doing the projects and make sure they do everything you're asked, and you'll get full credit there. Study code examples in full detail for midterm and final, as that is what will help because they are hard. Curve saved my grade.

Be sure to read the code examples and internalize them as soon as they come out, work on the lab little by little and you'll be fine. Do not wait until the last day, it never works, these assignments require your full attention. There is a generous curve, my D+ is a solid C. Also be sure to attend lecture, I missed a final question by ditching.

A very enthusiastic lecturer. Explains the materials very clearly and keeps you engage in lecture. Have a clear grading criteria, tells you exactly what he expects from you. The midterm and final are fairly difficult, make sure you know your subject well enough. However, the curve is pretty generous at the end.

Alex is an amazing CS professor, probably one of the best in the department. His lectures are very enthusiastic, but can sometimes be a bit repetitive. Projects are very interesting, but challenging. Midterms and final were tricky. Alex also works as a software engineer, which made me learn more about the real world, not just programming.

He makes a fundamental programming class really funny and interesting. Quite an energetic personality that makes you look forward to go to class compared to other CS courses. You HAVE to understand and do all the labs in order to do well on his exams which that are tricky. Talks about how boo likes it doggy style all the time for some reason o_o

Very enthusiastic and very fun to listen to! He's a very responsive professor and gives very uplifting speeches. Projects are very hard and require a lot of time. The midterm is very tricky as well. However, there is a generous curve.

Okay. Thornton's classes usually aren't that easy, and 45C is no exception. It can be tricky getting used to C++. His assignments are also challenging. However, it should be worth noting that he is one of the most helpful professors EVER. His office hours are the best, and his assistance will often save you. If you can take 46 with Thornton, do it.

This is my second time having Thornton as a professor, and while many of the things I have said in the past remain true, one thing is for certain: his exams are very tricky. Regardless, he is a great lecturer and his projects are relatively interesting as always. It is no wonder that he is one of the most popular ICS professors at UCI.

He's a good professor. He actually codes in class to show you how things work and it's really helpful. His labs are pretty easy but if you need help don't be afraid to ask for it. He's a nice guy and funny. He talks about his dog a lot but I didn't mind that. I wish he was teaching ICS 33 instead of Pattis.

Thornton's lectures are hilarious and interactive. He's a real chill, go-with-the-flow type of guy but you definitely learn a lot in this course. Yes, you might have a mild heart attack when you see your first midterm score but the final curve of the class is awesome.

My third course with Professor Thornton (ICS 32, ICS 45C, and ICS 46) and Thornton has continued to the be amazing lecturer he is. Extremely charismatic. Very clear and animated during his lecturing. Extremely professional and prompt at replying to emails. Exams are challenging and ICS 46 is very different from other Thornton courses. Study hard!

This is my 3rd class with Thornton and like always Thornton has been the same charismatic and very intelligent lecturer he is. 46 is a lot different then 45C and 32 keep that in mind. Very concept based. The labs are really hard and the midterm/final were very hard. Study hard and you will pass. Thornton is the best at responding to your emails!
Great professor! Very passionate and humorous. This class was challenging and time-consuming, but it really brought up my interest in CS.
Alex was an amazing professor. I never was bored in his class, his projects were challenging but manageable, and best of all he is a super funny and nice guy. Take the class, you won't regret it!
Possibly the best teacher I've had so far in UCI. I've had him for three classes thus far, and he has been crystal clear throughout in his teaching. Passionate and brilliant.

Professor Thornton tries his best to make a 1.5-hour programming lecture as interesting as possible... but with mixed success. However, he is a very resourceful instructor and will respond to any questions you throw at him in a timely manner. The class itself is not too difficult so long as you understand all the information.

If you read the instructions you can basically ace the projects. He basically spoon feeds you the project core codes during his lectures. Final and midterm are easy if you know how to do your projects.

He's funny, intelligent, and a great lecturer. This class is a HUGE jump from ICS 31 and the projects do require a lot of time. Midterm and final are difficult, so you really need to know your stuff. The curve is generous, but it will not save you if you slack off. Many people end up failing because they underestimate this class' difficulty.

Professor Thornton is quite great. The course, in my opinion, is about exposure to Python's library, and finding the right tools to solve the problem. Professor Thornton does this with interesting projects, and entertaining class meetings. I highly recommend him, just make sure you don't wait till the last minute to do the work.

Good teacher overall. Believe what everyone else tells you in that this class is a leap from 31 in terms of difficulty. You need to know even the briefly talked about concepts like the back of your hand. The labs are also fairly challenging but doable and rewarding. Thankfully he curves the class at the end very generously. You'll learn a lot.

Great sense of humor and fun lectures. However, his exams are no joke-- make sure you REALLY understand the concepts. Code examples on his website are useful, but I'd advise you to attend lectures to know what he emphasizes for tests. Also, beware: even if you breezed through ICS 31, you may struggle here. It's a steep climb in difficulty.

Alex is a funny teacher. He definitely knows how to make fun out of himself and make his lecture vivid and interesting. However, it's really hard for you if you are not that interested in computer science. Labs will kill you if you procrastinate. Midterm will be much harder than your 31 final. If you love cs, take it, or just find another direction
He does not update his website and notes on time. Besides that, he is an interesting teacher.

The class was really challenging, but in a good way. Things we learned in that class appeared really applicable. I would love to have Thornton again for future classes. Since Thornton is a part-time software programmer, he's one of the most knowledgeable professors I have had. The labs were interesting, tests difficult. Definitely study.

/sobbing because I got a C and have to retake/ BUT he was a good professor. He taught things very well and surprisingly I don't mind being in this class again. It'll help me get a better grasp of the concept. The class is fairly difficult, but you will definitely learn something. He also loves his dog, Boo.

Clear speaker, interested and fun professor. Knows a lot about computing and creates an enjoyable and helpful learning environment. He sponsors independent work, meaning labs were a bit challenging and fun to complete, but requires a lot of effort from the student. There is a huge gap between ICS 31 and 32, so be prepared!

His class is definitely challenging. Do NOT procrastinate on the labs, or they will end up killing you. This class definitely consumes most of your time. The midterm and the final were no joke. You need to know your stuff.

Very good professor. He is a passionate lecturer with lots of funny jokes. He focuses more on practical teaching rather than theory. He's a professional software developer in the real world so he applies that to his teaching. His labs are very hard but very fun. You will learn so much.

Prof. Thornton is DEFINITELY a pretty difficult CS professor. His projects are no joke and require a lot of outside research, refined logic, and TIME. Don't start his projects late, because it's so easy to underestimate just how much time a project will take. His lectures are very informative, and he's smart and knows the CURRENT computing world.

HORRIBLY organized class. Unlike anything I've seen at UCI before. Everything is on google drive, and so much nuanced information that's important to the class is just expected of you to assume from the  limited info he gives you. TA's and LA's are essentially just as lost as you and are really no help at all. Find someone else if available.

Class felt disorganized, but lots of extra credit on exams (esp the midterm). The labs were easy but not very helpful, I think the weekly quizzes helped the most in actually learning data structures. Not too hard to do well in the class though, take advantage of the extra credit and prepare to self study outside of lecture
A complete hypocrite. Very passive aggressive and dismissive

Offered a huge amount of extra credit to try to balance out the inevitable disastrous grades.Tests are the main problem. Tested material before lecturing about it, including on the midterm; Ambiguous wording, the hardest part of any test was trying to guess what he wanted, and furthermore tried to trick you with the instructions on the final

Professor Yeh is unorganized and doesn't teach. Has labs that aren't even posted on Canvas. Test are way to difficult, like how are we supposed to do the tests if you can't teach. Doesn't post anything on canvas till the end of the quarter. Doesn't care about his students and can't get in contact with him during office hours.

I previously took Professor Yeh for ICS 32, and at the time I thought he was a pretty average professor. Now that I took ICS 46 with him, the difference (lack of) organization in his class versus other professors is obvious. He's also an unremarkable lecturer, and the in-class activities are very tedious. His tests are also difficult in a bad way.

Yeh's class is one of the worst I have taken so far at UC Irvine It became clear that once the new content came, Thomas Yeh does not know how to teach and reads of slides If I hadn't studied material before the course i wouldn't have understood anything His projects and finals were confusingly worded and vague.he is easy but u wont learn, dont take
Get ready for tricky autograder grading. Yeh's very organized but you need to know where to find the resources. Easy A if you actually put in the expected effort

Yeh's lectures, labs and projects are disorganized. In the lectures, he sometimes skips over slides that I would consider important because he runs low on time. The directions given for the labs are not always clear, meaning you'll either be doing trial and error or asking TAs for help to pass the autograder's test cases.

Even though Yeh's class was disorganized (first time teaching 46) and quizzes were a gamble, the course truly improved my DSA skills. Labs and exams often involved creating new, improved hybrid data structures. He showers you with extra credit opportunities (I legit had a 105% before the final), and he drops the two lowest quizzes/homeworks/labs.
Skip this prof and the course until you can find another prof
don't take him even if you have to just wave your classes and take it sometime else
he aight 👍
You can do everything right and he doesn't know how to teach and will try to hurt you in every way possible.

Avoid if possible. Gives ambiguous exam/quiz questions, and refuses to accept other correct answers. Makes mistakes in slides, and immediately gets defensive when called out, always trying to blame the students for his course management shortcomings. Wish I could've had ANYONE else. Got an A, but it's kinda shallow since I didn't learn that much.

Probably the most ambiguous person you'll ever come across. If you ask a clarifying question during quizzes or exams, he's pretty much programmed himself and his TA's/LA's to say, "If it was in the slides, you should know." He'll never give you a straightforward answer even in ed. Like bro if I knew the answer I have better things to do than ask u.

Very unclear, doesn't know course material well, will not listen to any feedback and doubles down on mistakes. Questions are incredibly vague and TAs cannot help clarify as they don't know it either, don't take if you value your sanity. Labs are semi-AI generated as well

Spent 3 weeks reviewing 45C content which made him behind on teaching actual 46 content in the remaining 7 weeks. Instead of trying to write clear quiz/test questions, he made you "state your assumptions" instead and leaves you confused. Fixes this with a few percent of extra credit so your grade looks better while your knowledge of DSA isn't.

Very difficult class. failed the midterm, did decent on the final w/ a D+ to pass. i wish he would listen to student feedback and write better questions. gave extra credit to help alleviate some damages but yeah i wouldn't recommend. had to do a lot of self studying. quizzes every wk and hard labs. as a cc transfer, i got cooked. have fun!!!!

Despite getting an A, I don't think I learned data structures well enough for CS 161, as I don't think Yeh knows them himself. It's his first time with ICS 46, but he's too Java-pilled to know C++, gives boring, misleading lectures, writes unclear questions for quizzes/exams (state your assumptions 🥺), and is unreceptive to Ed discussion feedback.

Assignment instructions for the labs and HW felt rushed and unorganized, lectures weren't the most engaging, and tests often had ambiguous questions that could have resolved if he made a greater effort proofreading his exams. This was his first time teaching the class at UCI, so maybe he'll improve next quarter, but wouldn't take again if I could.

A student asked on ed if a topic would be on the quiz. He edited the slide on the spot and responded to the ed post claiming it was on the slides, trying to gaslight us. He failed to realize that we had access to the pdf unedited version of the slide. 
Very defensive when given feedback. Tries to gaslight students. Can't be clear to save his life.

Professor Yeh is genuinely an awful cs prof. Yeh is always behind on everything. His lectures are incredibly stale. His "teaching" is reading off the slides word for word and then failing to answer questions in class. He procrastinates too; he thought of the final exam topics during the final review session, three days before the exam.

The people that say Yeh isn't that bad are the people that were already proficient in data structures. You'll do great in this class if you've been leetcoding for many years and are not a beginner. If you are a beginner you will really struggle in this class. Final was 20 pages double sided. Teach yourself data structures before taking him.

Even though it is his first time teaching this course, Yeh is SO closed off to feedback. He responds to student feedback and questions very defensively, and occasionally gaslights us (said he'd provide a practice final, then later claimed he said no such thing). Content is fine, expect at least one really hard question in midterm/final.

Nah this professor is really not it bro. Idk what ADULTS are taking this course, but the ones I know actually know how to spell "adult". Btw its adult, not audit. wait till klefstad. 22 page final btw, gl to the next cohort

He is not the best professor and is not organized at all. But u guys are also complaining too much. Use this time to study more. Act like audits and take responsibility. If you are not ready, then why would you pay this much tuition to complain? Just give up college.

Doesn't seem to know much about C++ despite it being a C++ heavy class. Instructions are often vague and changed at the last minute. Lectures are somewhat useful but sometimes over/underexplained. Would not recommend.
Trash ahh professor

Professor Yeh fails to properly teach you concepts and falls further and further behind in his own schedule. If you can't figure out how to solve problems using concepts he doesn't teach in class, your grade will suffer. He tries to use extra credit to fix this, but it doesn't help if you aren't given a good chance to succeed in future classes.
he yaps way too much and never actually explains things

This quarter being his first time teaching ICS46 doesn't excuse how disorganized this class has been. Labs are a guessing game of figuring out what he wants. Quizzes/exams have included content hardly covered, occasionally not yet at all. Also gave out attendance EC for ONLY the lecture before thanksgiving when most students will be absent. Avoid.

The lecture notes were unorganized and not clear. Some of the code snippets in them were incorrect. The quizzes are also difficult even if you show up to lecture as they can cover a wide range of DSA topics. Be sure to learn everything you can about sorting, abstract data structures, and their time/space complexities(Best, average, and worst).

Unclear material, expectations, and overall very disorganized. LAs have no idea whats going on, he doesn't know how to write labs. No matter how you prepare, you WONT be ready for what he asks. Writes ambiguous questions then says people get it wrong because no one comes to lecture when in fact about 95% of the class is full every lecture. gl lol
Literal joke. Do not take this guy's class.

(Fall 2025) Class is very disorganized. Unclear what will even be on exams. Some requirements for labs aren't in the instructions so you only discover then in the test cases after submitting on Gradescope. Has changed what he says will be on the quiz the day of the quiz, and quizzed on topics from lecture two days prior.
Very unorganized, TA/LA's don't help clarify information during quizzes at all, and horrible lecturer (just reads off the slides).
Hardest class I've ever took , I do not recommended.

taught in riddles. lab docs do not mention ~80% of tests gradescope performs. pensive classwork is full of confusing formatting issues. often, assessments have vague instructions you need to waste time interpreting. during a quiz, asked a TA to confirm if no errors on question wording. "figure it out yourself". omg of course! it will all add up.

Wait to take this class until the spring with Klefstad guys, trust me. If you are very skilled in advanced data structures and coding them this class will be easy for you. Everything is full of typos, you lose points because of it. I have taken over 120 units and this is the worst professor i've ever come across.

He's the worst ICS professor I've taken. His lectures are vague & difficult to understand so you're basically self studying. His exams are unclear & terribly written; he makes you write down your assumptions on tests to avoid writing clearer questions. He said something wouldn't be on the exam, then made 1/4 of the exam that topic. Don't take.

(ICS 46) Lecture slides are unclear, so it's hard to do review outside of class. Requirements for labs/homework assignments are also unclear, so you may fail some test cases because you didn't word/output things the way he wanted you to. Test questions are unfairly difficult.

(ICS 46) first quarter teaching, but instead of focusing on grades, he should focus on actually teaching. Midterm was entirely from the last few minutes of last lecture. Weekly labs, homework, two in-class activities, and unclear with vague instruction quizzes. Lectures rushed through concepts with little to no explanation.Think Gassko BUT WORSE.

I won't say he is super organized and straightforward, but he also provides plenty of materials and resources to study. The exam problems were the same as the ones we practiced on. Why do you guys just never study enough but only complain?
ICS 46. This is absurd.

ICS 46 - Dont do it guys. Spare yourselves, take it with literally anyone else. Everything is full of errors and typos, and then you lose points because of HIS mistakes. No textbook, all you have is some vague slides that don't explain where the formulas came from.
ics 46. delay but dont take bruh
Ics 46 don't take.

(this is ics 46 i just couldnt wait till rmp updates) yeh is s obad at teaching its unbelievable. I sincerely doubt if he even knows the contents of ics46. BRO HAS US DO HOMEWORK ON AN AI REVIEW SITE. quizzes are super vague. lectures are super boring he just reads stuff off a slide. the homework he hands out are full of mistakes and not helpful.
I think he's pretty lenient, he drops a lot of the lowest scores across several categories. He also gives a lot of extra credit. I do think he tries his best to prepare students for future CS courses

Professor Yeh is caring toward his students - he dropped two quizzes, two labs, two lecture activities, and all quizzes have redos. His projects and tests can be difficult if you're brand new to programming, so if you have the time, give yourself an intro and practice Python a bit before you join his class.

Don't take his class unless you already have coding experience. All of the tests/quizzes are on paper, and the grading is pretty tough in my opinion. But he also drops some of the lowest grades you get in class, so it became much easier at the end.

If you feel like you've been tortured, you haven't taken ICS 31 with Professor Yeh. If you're new to coding, stay away from this professor, as he not only has the dullest lectures but also barely teaches the class and does not engage with his students whatsoever. He does provide multiple EC opportunities, but other than that, stay away.
Pretty bad at teaching, tough quiz and exam

This professor's class is extremely disorganized,  his quiz and exam is hard especially for beginners. All exams are on paper so you need manually write code,  and they use AI to grade your paper, thus even you have a correct logic but wrong syntax you will receive 0 points.
The courses arranged by the professor are full of tasks and very tight. The exam is very difficult.

The lecture content often doesn't align well with the textbook, and many topics that appear on quizzes and exams are either not covered in class at all or are only introduced in later lectures. While the professor does allow quiz redos, they are not available if you score below 50% or submit early, which feels a bit unfair.

The quiz was so hard, everyone try their best to do the quiz cause there is extra credit, and now he said you have to have a grade > 50% to get the chance to redo you quiz. But the quiz was so hard, the midterm as well. And I feels like on the test, testing about some material that we haven't learned, will learn in the future. try to avoid him.

Pretty good professor and gives a lot of extra credit. Project and assignments can be vague at times, but if you went to his lectures or office hours, you will be chilling. I can see that he is trying his best for his 2nd quarter teaching ICS 32 because he is very lenient with assignments. Overall, a pretty easy professor.

Makes some labs mandatory, instructions can be vague on projects/labs. Lack of organization with the class. The good side are the extra credit opportunities that he gives. Projects are worth a lot of your grade, so start early.

As someone who is new to programming, the class is tough. 5 projects, always start early, and READ ED posts, they contain guidance for labs/projects. Exams consist of knowing previous code from projects/labs, his exams are tough. Does not curve exams/class, only gives EC on most missed questions on exams. Gives extra credit on projects

CONS: His class relies heavily on nuanced instructions for mandatory labs and projects. Slides have little to no content and are not a good source to learn with even though there is no textbook. Yeh ridicules students on Ed for valid questions. Tests have errors, that he corrects mid exam. PRO: There is a lot of extra credit opportunities

He only posts lecture slides on google drive which means review by yourself after lecture is impossible because lecture slides contain only meaningless things. And project is difficult, the things you learn on his lecture is not enough to complete his project, and there is no way to learn by yourself without a friend who is good in computer science

Prof. Yeh definitely cares about his class and tries his best to be available. However, given that it was his first time teaching ICS 32, the class was definitely very disorganized and could've been taught better. 
Labs were mandatory twice a week, although that was reduced to once toward the end of the quarter.

Terrible behavior.
Lots of Homework.
Tough grader. 
Strict.
Forcing us to fill the attendance list

professor yeh was very kind outside of class, but his class was nothing short of a nightmare. to be honest, taking this class led me to going to regularly scheduled therapy due to how stressed i was at all times. i may potentially take a leave of absence just to recover from this class. great prof for those who are already great at coding.

His class is too disorganized, especially for labs/projects. We spent much time on issues that were not about programming skills but autograder issues/unclear prompts. However, there is much extra credit.
He cared about you memorizing lab + projects for exams, final was ridiculous.
His class is totally not organized. He usually changes the rubric, or adds more tasks when the deadline of the assignment approaches. The assignments are full of mistakes.

He was disorganized; he had to provide more instructions during the midterm and final due to how vague he made it. The projects determine almost your whole grade, which also sucks because they're very vague in instructions along with the grading criteria. Never curves and was hard to reach outside the classroom. Do not take him for ics32 if you can

The exams taken in this class aren't indicative of how much you learn. They consist of some written questions that ask you to recall lab instructions/code then write them word for word without giving you any other instruction.
As far as lecturing, Professor Yeh had nice interactive activities. Could use more structure overall.

He could definitely put more effort into it. A lot of methods used in the lab and project is not in slides and lectures... You must start them earlier and interact with the TA or his OH actively. It's very easy to get lost in his class since most of the code has to be learned by yourself. Exams are hand - writed, no cheat sheet. lab every week.

professor yeh is alright. i think he was nice enough during office hours. i met with him one on one when i was struggling in class, and he was pretty nice! this quarter was his first time teaching ics32, so he was tweaking the class while teaching it. midterms were okay, with hand-written code portions, and the avg was around a 70% no curve.

assigns so much pointless work, you'll have something due for this class 4 days out of the week on top of projects/midterms/finals. doesn't lecture clearly, had mandatory labs, condescending to students asking questions on ed discussion. only good thing about this class was the amount of extra credit opportunities.

Lectures were hit or miss; either you understood or were lost. Ask questions or go to OH. Attendance is required in lab sections for partial credit on labs and projects, include pre- and post-quizzes. Projects are fair with enough time given. He offers extensions and grace periods for late work. Midterms and finals have hand-written code portions.
tons of homework everyday, workload as much as 2 class,useless and boring lecture, mandatory lab, hand write exam, worst professor ever met

Thomas is an amazing teacher, always clearly explaining concepts and answering questions with full patience and never making someone feel like they're less than for not knowing something, I hope to take more classes with him. Projects and homeworks are very manageable as long as you start early, and the final project was the easiest of all.

I'm actually an ICS 32 student, and the experience is so bad. You have to spend a lot of time outside the lecture as his lecture is useless and boring. He would not tell you how to code, but give some very abstract slides which are hard to understand.

There are quizzes every week, but they're pretty easy. Although, there tends to be a lot of mistakes in the midterm. There's a lot of extra credit. One midterm or final could be dropped. The class is easy if you have a little bit of experience, but the projects would be pretty difficult for a beginner.
Wont recommend the course. He doesnt teach well and complicates simple things.

EZ exams and quizzes allows redo so as long as you put in effort every week, you can easily get full points on all quizzes. For the midterms, if there's some questions that a lot of people did it wrong, he will just turn that problem into extra credit. He also allows you to skip the final if you are already over 93% before final.

This professor is just so good. He cares about his students is willing to listen to his students, and constantly makes improvements. The grading is fair, the feedback is quick. All test/quiz material comes from lecture slides. Also, as long as you do the ZyBook & attend lectures you get a guaranteed A.  Those who hate him just did not study at all.

Not sure if it's because he's a fairly new professor at UC Irvine, but his lecture's and more specifically his midterms were extremely disorganized. During the midterms he would be trying to fix the mistakes he made when writing the midterm, while the class was taking the exam. His projects are extremely disorganized and created haphazardly.

DO NOT take this class if you have no experiencing coding. Prof Yeh is extremely disorganized he has unclear project guidelines and only makes corrections to them a week into it. Which, is annoying once you already made 25% of the code. He does provides quiz corrections upto 100 tho.During the midterm he was making correction to the test during it
The class was really flexible and the professor does try, but the organization was lacking. Easy class otherwise though.
Did not cater to DSC students correctly.
A little unorganized but overall, it was a great class. It wasn't too difficult, and the professor was flexible.

Prof Yeh is very caring about his students. He was always attentive on Ed discussion, and made sure to answer every single student's questions. Project instructions were always confusing and broad, and the organization of the class was lacking, as he would make changes to the project a week after it was assigned, or had to fix text typos mid test.

I didn't find the lectures as useful as the labs and homework. You can check out of labs when finished with the partner assignments. Some of the grading criteria for the projects were confusing, but he was fairly active on Ed Discussion. He drops a handful of assignments at the end too. Weekly quizzes and 2 midterms.

Cares a lot about his students and will provide lots of help regarding your problems. Slides were clear and organized. The tests are relatively difficult for beginner CS coders but he gives lots of extra credit.

I had a bad impression of Prof Yeh at first but I cut him some slack because it was his first time teaching ICS 31. His lectures were a little disorganized and there were some inconsistencies in grading. Projects were a bit heavy if you did not have prior knowledge to coding in python. One of my biggest issues is a lack of communication. 7.5/10
He's the goat. Curves tests (sometimes), cares about students. Tests can be a little hard but usually if u know ur stuff ur good

Professors Yeh's lectures are mentally draining as he is not interactive and just drills concepts down your throat. He also has a huge superiority complex and morally demeans students that do not understand topics. Class is really test heavy if you fail, you fail that class as they are worth 15 each

Its really not that bad of a class, put in a reasonable amount of effort and you will get an A, especially since the grades are so lenient with lowest scores being dropped and extra credit offered. Labs get kinda confusing near the end but thats what the score drops are for. Midterms/final make or break your grade, every other category is a free A

Tried his best to make a big class feel interactive. Come in reading the Zybook with the lecture as review. Quiz once a week, challenging midterms, but lenient on assignment drops (at least 1 per category). Quiz corrections but lots of mistakes he had to fix mid-test. Could be more clear on project instructions (like what a function should return).

Being it is my first semester and I did not put in a ton of effort (unlike a lot of *those* cs kids), prof yeh was alright. I do think he is inaccessible for office hours, which is overrun with speds who usually do well on the assignments. His class was challenging and he was unclear, not the best beginner cs class..

He's not bad at all. Pretty good lecturer imo just might be a bit rough for beginners I do admit that but doesnt matter which prof you get it's always going to be hard for beginners for intro to python. Super lenient and provides a lot of EC so it's very manageable. Start projects early though. His passive aggressive comments are lowkey funny.

I HAVE AN F IN THE CLASS MAKE THE FINAL EASY IM BEGGING PROFESSOR YEH (THE MOST AWESOMEST PROFESSOR EVER HAHAHAHAHAHAHAHA)

I regret even going to this class. Luckily my counselor let me drop after my first midterm because I struggled not knowing python
we scale
tough midterms and not enough help for beginners because office hours are flooded by kids who did well on exam and projects but like to ask dumb questions to prevent new programmers from seeking help
Awful in general at helping students, has a superiority complex it feels like.

Not very helpful during office hours considering crowdedness and priority to certain questions. Lectures were not very helpful, online interactive textbook was helpful and cost $92. Staff not as helpful, my TA however was very good and teachings were very effective. This class favors students with prior python experience, projects abit challenging.

For newcomers to python this course is extremally challenging considering there are students who already have lots of programming experience therefore leading to small curves. Office hours are crowded and not a very good way to get one on one help some questions are prioritized. I was fortunate to get a TA that was extremally helpful.

Take this class only if you had past coding experience, He will never curve since 40-60% of the class already has coding experience. He does not keep in mind that some students are beginners in coding His exams are not well prepared, there are tons of typos/errors and reading which takes of tons of time from your exams. A lot of self studying.
overall a decent class, wish he would recognize the fact that most are just beginners at python and only 20% of the people already have experience weighs everyone down in terms of grading
talks and types like an npc, not very helpful for any byineginner and I would recommend not taking him if you are actually trying to get better at python for future

Solid class. He's a good professor who does a good job teaching and going over material in lectures. Grading is lenient and he drops 2 of your lowest scores in different grading categories (ex. dropping your 2 lowest quiz grades). Projects are a bit annoying but manageable. I was completely new to coding but this class wasn't too challenging.
would not recommend for beginners, too much work and not a lot of learning python
Lenient grader, hard exams and not much help for projects, labs, TA's etc.

He's better than Alfaro. However, his projects are decided by lame strict autograders and helper functions that he makes you do, only for a 1% grade increase. His midterms are also rng as majority of your grade is determined by whether you know dictionaries. Lectures aren't helpful, it's better to just go for quiz then self-learn later.

Yeh's lectures are always very engaging, Midterms and final are fair. There is a small quiz almost every week but light and gives redos so we learn what we got wrong. He responds instantly to emails and ed discussions. All the learning really comes from zybooks. Overall def one of the best ICS prof in my opinion who listens to students' feedbacks.

From what I heard about other ICS teachers, Professor Yeh is by far the better choice. Yeh genuinely cares about teaching, its even his research project. You do have to do a quite a bit of reading to learn the material, but he goes over it in lecture. There are quiz regrades and he is a lenient grader and curves a lot. Essentially, he is the goat.

Call me crazy, but a professor for a programming class should actually program in class!!

Lectures were dense. Homework was incomplete. Midterm was straight up random, unlike the stuff she gave as practice.

Every lecture she mentioned how less people show up, I wonder why...

I feel bad for her TA's, but props to them for doing the heavy lifting.

Do not rely on the lectures + HW alone, LECTURES are helpful conceptually you need to practice it on your own time. Practice Linked lists, doubly linked lists, dynamic data arrays, pointers, addresses really well AND code them. Know what happens if you modify, add etc. Majority of the midterm. This midterm is not crammable, study early 2 weeks b4

Gave us 2 practice exams before the midterm. Of course the midterm was nothing like it, instead covering irrelevant details that we covered in class for 5 mins. 70% of the midterm was technical questions that logically make no sense since you don't code on paper. It's like asking people to do physics without a calculator. Utter stupidity.

Many of the bad reviews Professor Ahmed gets are what I expect from Professor Gassko's RMP. This is just not true about Professor Ahmed. Some things may be difficult, such as her dense lectures and odd exams, but that's it. She gives good projects, has helpful TAs, posts lectures, and genuinely cares. If you want to actually learn, take her class.
would not vote him for president. i personally would not trust him to be in charge of the us military

Professor Shindler is cool and wants you to do well, but his assignments and labs are extremely hard, especially for a transfer student from a CC. Attendance is not mandatory, but he goes over some stuff that can't really be found online.

Very caring individual, attempts to teach approach to problem-solving rather than specific algorithms. Materials were highly abstract, but tests aligned with materials taught during lecture. Overall, the class itself isn't too bad, lecture were a bit of a drag to get through though I can't lie...
Tough projects. START. EARLY. Exams were rough but you can really trust that not curve (he says "grade adjustments ... ". Great lectures, don't worry about calculating your grade, seriously.

Great class overall! Skiplists and Crumple Trees definitely were the most time consuming that unfortunately end up being due before a midterm, so start them early. Lectures were more guided problem solving rather than content dumping. I prefer his teaching style over Thornton (great professor as well), but it might not be for everyone.

Shindler is the GOAT. Keep up with psets (don't be fooled by them not being mandatory) and homework and you'll be fine. Projects require lots of testing to get full points, but most points can be achieved with only a few hours of work per project (w/ one exception). Practice tests accurately represent exam content. Beware the final. Attend lecture.

The class was insanely difficult as there were several esoteric data structures we learned. Exams were fair b/c he gives practice exams. If you put in a huge amount of effort, you will be able to get an A or B. I failed because I didn't put the effort into studying or projects. Great professor overall who clearly loves teaching and helping, though.

I think this course can be challenging especially if you're relatively new to DSA's (like I was) but I found the lectures to be extremely helpful for my understanding + the office hours. As long as you start on the projects not ridiculously late this class should be okay for you. Shinder is a fantastic professor and I highly recommend him

Work was relatively easy, exams weren't too bad. Projects might take a while if ur new to DSA but definitely super doable within the time he gives you. If ur new to DSA, lectures are helpful, otherwise u can skip every single lec (very nice). There are tons of resources for everyone and class is structured to support u. Lots of review sessions too

The class overall seems very fair. Projects if you start them early and read the textbook / extra resources are annoying yet doable. No other hw. Practice Midterms very very helpful but preemptive questions are annoying. Overall, the class is graded on a giant curve which is nice, yet extremely stressful. It took a year off me

Shindler's ICS46 is challenging but rewarding. The projects require strong C++ skills, but his lectures are informative. Attend class, use the textbook, and try Unstuck AI - it's a great supplement for mastering the concepts.

As a DSC student I really appreciated that he was quite accommodating. The class as a whole was difficult but worthwhile, and the teacher was great at explaining concepts. Projects are quite difficult and you must start them early. Great teacher but his content is not easy at all

The first project was needlessly hard. The crumple tree project was cancer. Lectures are helpful half the time and confusing half the time. Exams are fair, and he gives practice exams. The professor is nice, and I was able to learn from the course, but my aforementioned gripes bring the course down.
Waste of time
Hard class, but one of the most understanding and dedicated professor, truly cares about his students. Class was extremely difficult though, but learned a lot!
Bad lectures and grading system
Yeah pretty much
Projects are very difficult but his lectures are very entertaining. Tests are really hard as well, so use the study material he gives and review it often.

Definitely a difficult class but the lectures are not boring. Although the lectures are in the early morning at 8 am. Projects are relatively difficult and I don't recommend doing it the night before. Tests are very difficult but definitely use the study guides and the homework to review and practice.

Had him for 45c and for 46, he's great. His lectures are great, he keeps it entertaining and is very helpful in learning concepts. He has about 6 projects throughout the quarter and 1 or 2 tests. The projects were intimidating, but doable as long as you start early.

Knowledgeable guy, good person. Very high expectations for your abilities, but merciful when it comes to grading (unless you are caught cheating, dude has no mercy for that.) Don't expect the standard grade scale, a 50% doesn't necessarily mean you failed. His assignments are tough on purpose; community college probably didn't challenge you enough.

I may have failed but I do not regret taking the class for the experience alone.
