Interesting lectures, but does not answer questions and leaves quizzes and exams up to the TA (bad this quarter).

The course is quite straightforward and easy to understand. The midterm and final are somewhat tricky (and each occupies 35% of the final grade), and the homework sometimes can be tough and time-consuming. Pretty good professor for 6B.

Prof. Bic is great. His lectures are basically recorded from 2017, but they are clear. ZyBooks is required and it is a good resource when you still don't understand the lectures (not often though). Midterm and final are easy when you absorb everything 2 days before the exam. Easy A.

He's a pretty good professor for ICS 6B, atleast. Here's an example lecture (vimeo com/239023633/8fbfd4aa58). The class is pretty easy and all you have to do is binge and absorb the lecture videos 2 days before the midterm to get an A (that's what I did anyways). Midterm a bit tricky, but nothing you can't do. Zybooks wasn't really needed
The lectures are really clear and helpful! The tests aren't that hard and the curve is really generous. You should get an A.

Professor Bic's lecture notes (slides) are clear, tho his lecture (videos) are really boring. The course is 90% based on tests so study hard! The tests are online & supervised by ProctorU, which is really awkward, but study the slides & homework solutions helps. The textbook is not required but it does help, recommended.

Bic formalized and cleaned up his class a lot. Clear lectures and responds to students on canvas discussion. Tests (Midterm and Final) had a couple questions that were unclear and wonky, but rest was fine. Wait until your tests are regraded by the TAs before you panic about your grade. Midterm and final very close to HW.

The class is all online including exams, even the OH was skype sessions. He doesn't really teach, just read off the slides. HW is graded based on completing the assignment, not correctness. Study the HW as it will help for the exams (which are 90%). Also, learn the ways of solving HW based on his answers key.

Very lazy professor - basically an online class where "lectures" are discussion sections where he reads off answers to the HW, and actual "lectures" are videos uploaded online. Exams are fair, however, being based on the HW, so that's good.

Don't buy the book. I bought it and regret it dearly.   Class is practically online. The "lectures" merely go over the homework, but they are helpful and all you need to pass, as long as you can see past his lack of teaching ability and identify his chicken scratch. Study his answer keys, attend "lecture" if you're stuck, and you're gold.

Professor Bic's teaching ability is questionable. He can be a bit absent-minded at times in both his online and in-class lectures, and he is not very good at explaining things. However, his class is ridiculously easy, and class meetings only occur once or twice a week (most of the course materials are online). Exams and assignments are fair.

Its flipped classroom. Like an online course. You only need to go to lecture for quizzes but you can bomb 1 quiz, do a little bad on another and still have an A- no problem. Bic isn't the clearest guy but he's easy.

The class is easy. The HW is graded on effort and the quizzes are related to the hw so study his answers when he releases them! You do not need the book, i didn't buy it, and class is only mandatory on quiz days. Enjoy!

This class was flipped so we did the learning at home and class was not mandatory to attend only when there was a quiz. The quizzes were easy (related to the hw)and the homework is graded on effort not accuracy. It was an easy class but if you want more student-prof interaction do not take him. If you take the class you do not need the book .

He's a pretty good teacher. The class is easy if you study for the exams. A few people failed because the lectures were online, and so didn't go to class at all. Go to class and you'll get at least a B.

The good thing about this class is that there is only one meeting a week (to discuss the hw), and the workload is minimal (one fairly short hw assignment weekly). Lectures are all online. The bad thing is that Bic is a bad, confusing teacher. Tests can be tricky but are generally only a bit harder than the hw. Meh class overall... not THAT bad.

Bic is an alright lecturer, but his exams tend to go off topic from the lectures so he is extremely difficult when it comes to exams and overall grading. I'd recommend taking 6B with another professor if you're aiming for a high grade.
Class was very difficult, I recommend taking 6B with another professor. He's somewhat clear in lecture, but the exams are completely irrelevant to lectures.

The course was essentially an online class since he uploaded all lectures onto the website. It was nice having so many reference materials but he was also fairly aloof and not especially helpful to students.

Content isn't hard but class is insanely disorganized. Practice test answer keys riddled with mistakes and updated like 18 hours before the test. Slides are basically useless. Exam self-study is very doable though (as long as u do it on the last day cuz answer corrections released super late). HW and labs are ez. Lowest 2 hw and 1 of 3 exam dropped
Lectures do not prepare you for homework, labs, or exams, so you have to self-learn. TAs are okay but not amazing. I did not enjoy this class.

This professor's favorite hobby is watching students fail. it is ridiculous how terrible the structure of the class is. Professor lectures nonsense but TA's teach for assignments (discussion sections) and create exams/ final. Content on final is completely different from exams, hw, and study guides. Exams are doable and self study able.

I don't know if bro thought teaching was for vibes and giggles but he doesn't seem to have much organization in his slides. Once, he legit flew by like 40 slides in one lecture and kept flipping between them. His labs are all in assembly but he himself never teaches any of it and his midterms are wild
Holy i hate this guy

the lectures are theoretical and highly abstract, so you'll have to learn how to solve problems in the homework based on the textbook readings, which mirror the exams. 1 of the 3 exams as well as the lowest 2 hws out of 8 are dropped. While he is willing to drastically lower the grade for a C, he in-turn raises the standard for the higher grades

Poor communication throughout the entire quarter between TAs and professor, midterms had content that was not covered yet, misleading information, and to top it off, he curved the class down... take this class with another professor

Horrible experience. Poor communication between TAs and the professor, course material is disorganized and grading errors are everywhere. I highly suggest taking this class at CC if you want to preserve your sanity and GPA.
Terrible scale, half of the student got a C, will not follow general scale, it goes down!

An 84% was considered a C. He curves down and does not tell you until the end. Super disorganized class, from unclear guidelines to a very disorganized canvas. Expect to wait a week for your question to be answered or not answered at all. Learned more through peers' explanations than the actual staff.

Worst professor I have had so far at UCI. He had no idea what was going in the class and would literally give misinformation during lectures. The only way to learn anything relevant to the class was through the textbook. The TAs were frequently unresponsive. To top it all off, he curved the class down, even though people weren't doing that great!!?

Lecture material is often different from what is on the exams. Read the textbook. The TAs and professor are hard to get ahold of on Ed or though email. The curve in this class curved many people's grades down, as an 84% was considered a C, despite this being a reasonably challenging class. I encourage you to take this with a different professor.

Dutt is not a bad lecturer, but most material covered was unrelated to exams (btw Dutt himself showed up for a grand total of 10 minutes across all exams). First exam had decent practice, but for next two and final we had 0 clue what format was going to be. And to top it off, he curves people down (how is this even legal?). GL+Start early on Lab 3.
bro his grading scale is CRAZY, for the love of god don't take him

One of the most inconsistent professors I've taken at UCI. I'd like to point out that the curriculum is not synchronized between the professors and the TAs so do not be surprised if you see something you don't know on the midterm (made by TAs) and see it 4 weeks later in class (taught by Dutt). The grading scale is also so scuffed; why is 84% a C?

This quarter was awful, the TA's and the professor constantly contradicted each other on directions. They gave us a sample exam for the first midterm and just gave up after that. Most of the material that appeared on the exams wasn't taught properly since this class relies overly on self studying. Take 51 at CC if you can.

Was unlucky enough to endure this class having learned practically nothing of value. It was a profound lack of coordination and extremely uninspiring. This disastrous class should be scrapped entirely before subjecting any others to such an amateurish, incoherent debacle.

Seems like the professor is never in line with the TA, so what he lectures doesn't correlate to what's on the exams as it seems like the TA's make all the exams except for the first one. Highly recommend just reading the textbook and watching YouTube videos for your understanding.

Read the textbook and practice on your own or with friends, which helps a lot. Labs and homework every week, somewhat doable I guess. Exams every 2 weeks. 
      Me and others got a few answers correct on some HW's, yet were docked on them. Although they regrade, why the mishaps in the first place? Check Gradescope often!

Awful lecturer. Little to no resources outside of class. Minimal communications with students. Unpaid learning assistants (LA's) helped organize review for the final exam, as opposed to the professor or TAs.

Professor takes quite a bit of time to go through topics when he uses the whiteboard but they do cover what's expected on the exam. Absolutely terrible. Completely incompetent and makes me want to just take this class again with Thornton even though I'm passing. oh god for those of you who took ics 51 in spring 2003 you guys were lucky. she totally lashed out at the fall 2003 class. her midterm was bad but then her final was murder. she doesnt really seem to know her stuff and she never answers questions in class

she does seem to be trying hard to help us. Yes assigned seats, assigned groups, and her participation policy for  extra credit  really makes some people say the some truly lame things just because they are so keen for the participation points

5 projects, 4 quizzes, and.1 larger quiz (final). Projects were doable but his readings are very well made that they can be completed by just paying close attention to readings. Attendance not mandatory but worth if you need to see live demonstration. Quizzes doable & cover content more generally not too specific. Great prof & great feedback on ed

Amazing Professor! All materials and resources needed for the class were neatly posted on his class website. Take him!

Great professor! Has saved my experience at UCI. Very understanding and cares about his students. The projects are tough but there are plenty of opportunities to get help during office hours. He is very understanding and gives students 5 extra project days to use throughout the quarter. I would take his class again!

The professor has a very lenient late policy. You get 5 total "late days" where you can submit your project past the deadline. Projects were pretty simple once you get the fundamentals down. 4 quizzes 9% each, 5 projects 9% each, no midterm, final 9%. Quizzes are easy. Professor also gave extensions on projects around holiday breaks. Take him!!!

You definitely learn a lot from Pattis, but it's not because he's a good professor. Sure, he's very knowledgeable, but that doesn't mean that he knows how to teach. Wish ICS 33 came before ICS 32, after learning so many more in-depth python concepts I feel I could have done the projects in ICS 32 much better. This guy's lecture notes are crazy. doable if you dont fall behind. hw is easy project can be partner just follow his instructions. this class was a weird cult some people loved the Professor and sweared he was amazing. An amazing professor is Baldwin.

HE IS GORGEOUS
Best professor I have ever had at UCI. Tough course, with a lot of readings and homework. Very helpful!

Pattis is very passionate about teaching and strives to ensure that his students understand what is being taught. Although the concepts themselves arent very complex there is quite a bit of work required for the class. He has a lot of notes, but going to his lecture will essentially cover all that is needed to be known.

If you read 20 pages of his notes every day, you only need to read 3-5 days a week. Start working on the programs and quizzes the day he posts them. In-Labs are similar to quizzes. Use the midterm to study for final. Read his questions very carefully. Grades come out within a week of submission - you always know where you stand in the class.

Wow what a ride it has been in this class. An insane amount of work, and his notes will test you to your limit. However, I must say that I've learned a lot, and that Pattis genuinely tries to make his students learn. Prepare for no social life, especially during the first few weeks. It does get better though as you fully embrace the nerd lifestyle.

Pattis is a great professor, but don't expect him to baby you through the course. A majority of the points are in the projects, which you theoretically have infinite time for. You need to pass on either the 3 in-labs or the midterm+final to pass the class. Redo quizzes before every testing instrument and pray.

Pattis has been teaching for a long time so he knows what he is doing. All his assignments are really straight forward, but there is still a lot of work. Make sure to read his lecture notes before attending lecture.
My guy is old but goated.

Professor Pattis is a clearly passionate about computer science, which shows in his dedication to quality and accuracy in his lectures. While the material is undoubtedly hard, Pattis does his best to give students plentiful notes and fair assessments of their understanding through projects, quizzes, and exams.

You won't even find the time to read his 10 page long quizzes, and he expects you to do it. Even reading his quizzes takes 1 hour. Excess amount of programming assignments quizzes and midterms. This class should have 8 credits.

If you're reading this I'm sure you dont have a choice of whether to take pattis for 33 . The class is a lot of note reading and a lot of work. Honestly, if you're on your game this class isn't too bad. If you're a slacker like me the work piles up. I recommend taking bare minimum units outside this class if you're like me. Pattis is a great prof.

Pattis outlines exactly what you need to do well: START EARLY on every quiz/project, prepare for the inlabs well since the midterm/final are difficult, and READ. THE. NOTES. They are super long but trust me, reading them helps so much. Pattis clearly cares about the class and will teach you a huge amount of useful info on CS/Python. Use this.

Never thought to balance the criteria of Programming learning for freshman that should be taught. More than hundreds of pages for reading each week. You even need to read 10 pages for brief understanding his quiz and assignment. Programming should be a process of self-learning and exploring, instead of being trapped and limited by his requirements.

Not a bad teacher, but the outdated style of his course website and notes made this online class a tad harder, although his notes and lectures are easily accessible. You really need to pay close attention and study/practice the material thoroughly to do well, unlike me. Overall, you need to invest a good amount of time in this class.

Pattis is a very good lecturer. He goes very in-depth into the concepts, which is why his notes are long and the class can feel overwhelming with the amount of material that you have to learn every week. The projects are not too bad, but his instructions are usually very long and hard to understand. The quizzes, midterm, and final are hardest.

Pattis has a lot of restrictions on the way you should write codes. His lecture notes are not helpful and too long: 15k word count per week. You can learn better by browsing the web. His instructions for each assignment are unclear and you will spend hours just understanding his instructions and another few doing it. Avoid to have a life.

I'm aware ICS 33 is the weeder class, and Pattis sure runs with it. Nice guy, not exactly the teaching style I can vibe with, but it of course pushes you to a higher standard. At the end of the day, he's a man who works with numbers, but if the eyes of compassion rest on you, he occasionally reveals sunbeams of humanity.

I agree with a rating of 5 because he is an experienced professor and gives sufficient teach in lectures; I also agree to a rate of 1 or 2 because tests, lectures, notes, and homework are extremely difficult quantitatively and qualitatively. That's why I give a 3.

The best part of this class was how structured everything was. There was a standard formula of weekly take-home quizzes, biweekly projects, and a few exams. The readings were quite long and tedious, but did contain a lot of important information. As long as you can keep yourself disciplined, you will do fine in this course.

Prof. Pattis is very knowledgable w 40+ years of teaching experience, and he is accessible in OH as well. I think the reason he got bad reviews is because he really assigned a lot of assignment, and you do need to get ready to read. However, I found these programming assignments and his verbose lecture notes are what helps me learn the most.

I was a little nervous going into the class based on the other reviews. Having just finished his class, I can say that although it is a lot of work, I learned quite a bit. Overall, if you put in the effort, the class is doable, and you will learn quite a lot

This is a VERY difficult course. Good thing was Pattis had the entire schedule finalized on the first day, no confusion. His notes are ridiculously long black & white text files. The notes for instructions and projects are often unnecessarily difficult to understand. I learned A LOT here, but I would never take again.

He's mediocre at best, I don't understand all the people who praise him highly. His notes are useful if u use ctrl+f, otherwise it's an eyesore. Projects every 2 weeks, quiz (mini project) every week, in lab exams every 3 weeks. Pair programming allowed on projects, except last one. Midterm and final are impossible to pass, but he normalizes a lot.
get ready to read 20000-word notes with a ton of typos and illogical sentences. would suggest audiobook it as compared to reading it.

This class is honestly not very difficult, it's just time consuming. Don't get discouraged by the first project or the first week of notes, both took 2-3 times the normal amount of time to finish them. If you pass all the BSC tests, you'll probably get 100 on the projects. For every In-lab exam, do all the problems from the previous years exam.

There are three essential strategies to get an A in this class. First, do everything in one line..... JK. That is just a joke. First, read every single part of his note. Second, ctrl/command c Third, ctrl/command v Tested, they work great.

The Good News: The quarter gets gradually easier after the first couple of weeks. The Bad News: Good luck surviving the 2,000 line unformatted txt file notes, and did I mention you have to DO IT IN 1 LINE!

Teaches well, but he's a hard teacher. Definitely makes you work. He sends out updated grades on a spreadsheet so you can see everyone else's grade (but without names and what not though). Some people find that discouraging. Since I personally did well and I was able to easily grasp concepts I didnt find it too bad but it can easily get very hard.

First week's notes are 40.000 characters long and in text file, reading them all really helps you with the first two assignment, all future project writeups and quizzes are all at least 5 pages long and are packed with words. Would NEVER take pattis again but he teaches good, literally listen to it as a bedtime story.

Arrogant and may have superb programming skills but his writing skills are lacking. Everything, from projects to instructions to notes could be shortened 8 times by anyone who took a high school English class ever. He's stubborn and unwilling to change anything including the rules which are barely updated since pre-online. Avoid him if you can.
He said himself he's been teaching for over 40 years, and he wants us to do what he can do in ICS33, the third or second class for python.

he's very tough on his assignments, literally a long quiz every week, along with a very long confusing project. he's way too specific about the programs that he wants, which makes it hard because he butchers around the answer on piazza. also... he rather call you out for writing as anonymous than try to genuinely help you on the assignments. smh
The topics covered in his notes and assignments are pretty understandable but it doesn't change the fact that his they're are very long. Also comes off as arrogant.

Really great ICS professor. Read his notes! He emphasizes that technically you can survive from just the notes. 5 programming assignments, 3 in-lab programming exams, almost weekly quizzes, and a written midterm & final. Lots to do but if you turn it in early, you get extra credit that really adds up. He also normalizes test & lab scores.

He's a good prof - knows his stuffs and knowledgeable. He just gives A LOT of works; you get assignments back to back every week. His notes are very detailed but lengthy, and sometimes hard to understand too. I do learn new materials, but I wish the workload was lighter so I had time to read up on his notes. Overall, eh.

Don't last minute anything. Pattis is an amazing professor and you'll work for your grade. Project 1 was the hardest for me since you're getting used to how his class functions, so make sure you have time for that. And don't over stack your schedule while taking this course, otherwise you'll have no time

Pattis gives lots of work, you have weekly quizzes, biweekly projects, along with in lab exams, midterm, and a final. It is very overwhelming in the beginning because he gives the hardest assignments in the beginning of the quarter. But you get used to the workload. I learned the most in this class compared to 31 and 32.

I failed Pattis ICS 33 first time I took it with him I didn't take it serious. I ended up failing the quarter. 2nd time around I started working on the projects and quizzes the very same day they were assigned. Upward of 6+ hours a day for his class. I will never take another course with him, but he made me believe that no matter how hard I CAN!
Too many readings and assignments. The workload of the course will ruin your life.

If you are planning to take Pattis' course, PLEASE READ ALL his NOTES (you can find by Google) AHEAD OF TIME! It's useful but A LOT! Since you will have other heavy workloads on 20hrs+ projects, 5 exams (2hrs each), 10hrs weekly quizzes... All these force you to learn how to schedule your time. Pattis is a responsible but somewhat arrogant Prof.

His notes and lectures can be heavy but you do get a lot of useful insight into Python! He gives so many opportunities to earn extra points and the projects / quizzes are very doable. Put in the effort and you will be fine. He's also a pretty nice guy so don't be intimidated by him, he loves to share his stories

Heaviest workload class I have ever taken. Notes were hella long, quizzes and his programming assignments took hella long. Though excessive, I became better at programming because of this experience. Start assignments early! I personally learned most by doing this - gave me time to really understand the content. Final and midterm hard but curved!
Best computer science teacher. ICS33 is hard, but everyone could get a good grade if they make an effort.
Good professor. His grading criteria is very clear and there is a ton of extra credit. His notes are a little long and it's a lot of work, though.

He's a walking textbook. Honestly, his lectures aren't the best; however, I attended them because it cleared up any misconceptions I had with the notes. The notes. These notes are insane. Every detail about python are in them and you will have no problem understanding python if you take your time to understand them. Difficult but worth it.

Amazing professor who truly cares about what he is doing. Tbh most people say he is hard but it is totally worth it. You gotta put in the work but if you do you will be fine. His notes are amazing too. So if you ever feel behind, just read those. If you want an A you will get one.

I was so stressed about this class in the beginning by reading comments online. However, 33 is actually manageable as long as you make enough time. Larc helps but attending extra labs is the best strategy.

A very CMU professor who provides "ocean of materials." If you understand all the materials, no class can be easier than ICS 33, because Pattis provides you enough testcases and generous extra credit opportunities.

Pattis has clear thoughts in lectures. He writes lengthy notes but every word you read reinforces a concept that you absolutely have to understand to be a good programmer. Sometimes shares hilarious jokes that I even wrote down just not to forget it. He gives detailed instruction on projects, which is good but shortcuts the problem-solving process.

The absolute greatest professor I've taken here at UCI. Pattis is the gold standard for learning CS. Pattis has extensive experience teaching, well-structured no BS lectures and notes, and cool projects. In lab exams were the hardest. Stayed up nights for this class especially for the first project. It was worth every minute. I learned a ton.

Professor Pattis is one of the worst professors I've had at UCI. He's extremely unfriendly in class and in office hours. He doesn't understand the insane amount of workload that he gives students who have lives outside the classroom. Take his class if you want to ruin your GPA.

Lots of reading; had him for both 46 and 33 and despite the workload, I'm glad I took his class. Although his projects are somewhat repetitive in 46, it gave me a better understanding of each data structure we talked about. Even though he mostly reads off notes, he covers quite a bit of useful material in class (esp. visualizations in 46).

Long notes, old fashion professor, but I think you would like this course! It helps you understand deep inside Python. Heavy workload in the beginning, be prepared to work hard at the beginning of the quarter. If not, be sure you take less units that quarter. Over all, I would give Professor 9/10, 10/10 if he make the transition to PyCharm.

Pattis throws a LOT at you, especially be careful if you take 46 in Fall (recruiting). That being said, I definitely learned sooo much, especially compared with Shindler's 46. If you want to learn a lot about C++ and Data Structures take Pattis but Shindler (or another prof) will be a lot easier.

Great lectures if you are focused and interested in the material. Class is well organized and the project/quiz instructions are clear. Start early on assignments and actually read his notes, and you'll do well.

This class for me personally was SUPER hard. Still, a lot of people pass so if you are on top of your work, you should be fine. The notes have everything you need, but are a pain in the ass to read. (its literally on a notepad doc or whatever). Make sure to read them religiously the first time so you don't have to come back and cram for an exam.
Probably the best professor in the ICS department. Read his notes carefully and try to solve all the programming assignments and quizzes by yourself. It's definitely a worth taking class.
great professor, lots of work. dont slack youll regret it

This professor talks a lot and will go circles when giving lectures. He will usually mention Carnegie melon and will usually never finish the notes because of his tendencies to talk in circles. His projects are structured well and are easier to improve from. I appreciate his project format but do not enjoy his lectures.

A really unfriendly Senior instructor(he is not a professor) with really wire attitude towards to his students. He seems doesnt understand the concepts that students usually have to multiple classes at the same time and his assignments will consume most of your time.

Never have I used every curse word I could think of while taking a test to describe a professor and also found reason after reason to appreciate them after the fact. 33 definitely weeds people out. It also gives you the confidence you need to conquer any class afterwards with maybe the exception of ICS53 (which is the only CS class more difficult)
pretty hard to be honest

My favorite ICS prof in UCI, Give a lot of extra credit for homework and in the exam. The difficulty is fair and homework is doable if you read the notes. Professor Pettis give good feedback and love to share with his students.

I was skeptical coming into this class but I have to say  Pattis makes damn sure anyone who passes his class has mastery over the material he teaches. He gives lots of extra credit which you can get easily just by turning stuff in responsibly and on time. He curves heavily and lets people replace in lab and midterm scores. Lot of work but worth it

personally really enjoyed his lectures but everyone I know fell asleep every time, project directions are super clear just follow them and you'll do fine, extra credit policy is super generous, in lab exams are super easy, midterm and final can be hard if you haven't understood the projects
Great course materials and quick grading, but horrible lecturer

Boring lecturer and does not get through his own notes. Notes are too long. There is a quiz every week and a project every 2. Workload is very high, but the material itself is not very difficult. He is not underrated, he is just not a very good professor.

He's a strict, old-fashioned professor. Extremely clear on grading criteria, EXTREMELY anti-cheat(will report you without hesitation), and assigns a lot of work. This is quite the heavy workload of a class, so try to take this with some easier classes. Pattis is a great professor-lectures well, has BOOK LONG notes, and really gets you to work.
Most underrated professor in UCI CS.

if you're not a natural at coding, prepare to work hard. if you are a natural, still prepare to work hard. the material is not what's difficult, what's difficult is the density of the material and the amount of practice needed to really understand it. this clas will likely take up most of your time, so schedule accordingly.

This class is structured very well and organized. It's a hard course, but gives you EVERYTHING you need to know in his notes, but his notes are very long. Your grade is distributed pretty evenly between tests, homework, and program assignments. You got to put in work to understand everything. His tests are pretty difficult but curved fairly.
Couldn't imagine not taking ICS 33 with Pattis. Definitely would take him over any other professor for 33

I really respect Pattis; it's obvious he knows what he's talking about, and he cares about teaching. He makes his expectations totally clear. No surprises on tests or homework. Everything is well-structured, but the lectures are a little boring. The workload is manageable if you don't wait too long to start.

1 programming assignment per 2 weeks, 1 quiz per week, 1 midterm and 1 final. Lecture notes are dry and long but very informative and helpful in doing the homework. He is very responsive on Piazza and he answers email quickly. The material is very difficult but it is worth it because those would be asked in job interviews.

ICS 46 with Pattis is structured very similarly to his ICS 33 class, so if you're familiar with that and liked it, I would recommend ICS 46 with him. Data structures involve some of the most fundamental topics in CS. Take this class with Pattis if you want to really learn what's going on in depth; this is the stuff that comes up in interviews.

This class is very similar to Pattis' ICS 46 but in C++. He gives lots of homework and makes you think. His lectures can be a bit boring but he explains the concepts in detail and clearly. Midterm and final had averages of about 55%, but he normalizes them to 75%.

Honestly, he's not a good lecturer, but he knows how to run a class better than anyone. His class is organized and what he wants is clear-cut. He gives second chances if you don't do well on the first exams, but there is TON OF WORK. Your grade will be proportional to how much effort you put into the class. He cares a lot about CS and teaching.

Pros: super fast grading, gives you a tool to check ur code for quizzes and projects, responsive on Piazza, v organized, lots of extra credit, you will def learn something, v generous & clear grading, he's a cool guy Cons: v long notes (you can get away w skimming tho), heavy workload (start early and work w a partner)

Pattis is the most helpful professor I've ever had. He personally gave detailed answers to at least half of all Piazza posts, and he has lots of office hours. His notes, while long, are worth reading the entirety of. He does assign a lot of work, but it's totally manageable as long as you start on it early enough.

Not as good of a lecturer as Thornton, but more transparent grading. ICS 33 rewards the personalities who don't forget deadlines and manage their time wisely. The content is about the same as 32 but there's a ton more work. Exams are hard, not because Pattis designs the questions to be hard but because there's so much crap to study. Work hard.

Prepare for a tik tock tock schedule every 2 weeks, 1 major hw, 2 medium hw's called take home quizes. This does not break for midterm, then right after midterm you get an unexpected break, then slammed with all 3 in 1 week, with tik tock tock continuing after. You must team up, or don't bother taking the class. Hw's are NOT simple one nighters.

If you like a CS prof to type 1 word per min, then this is the guy for you. I had no idea what was going on in lecture because he's so dry. If you like reading 30 page novels for notes, then this is the guy for you. But his in-lab exams weren't that bad tbh

Notes are LONG but VERY informative and Pattis explains concepts really well. Class is organized, instructions extremely clear, and grading fair. Lots of homework BUT worth it. The key to doing well is to read all the notes, and start EARLY on assignments. HIGHLY recommend because you will learn a lot! Best professor I've had so far.

All professors should be like Pattis, very well organized , gives you all the knowledge you need in his very long and specific notes, his website has all the due dates and he is always in constant communication with the students so youll never not know whats going on. A TON of work but It is worth it in the end , you walk out knowing a lot more.

Pattis is a great professor. Despite all the work he gave throughout the quarter (5 Programming Assignments, 8 Take-Home Quizzes, 2 Lab-Exams, Midterm, Final), he actually makes you learn. All the work is aimed to help you understand Python a lot better which will be very useful.

Overall a great CS Professor. Workload is heavy, quizzes nearly every week, programming assignments every 2 weeks, 2 in lab exams usually around week 4 and 8 and a midterm and final. Although workloads heavy, it makes you master the material and become a better python programmer. Midterm and final are fair. If you put in the work, youll get an A.
Long notes. Heavy load. Unreasonable policies. Avoid him if you can.

The course is not bad, but the workload is relative heavy. About 2 coding assignments need to do pre week, and 4 Test (2 in-lab, midterm, final). If you do not have good skill in coding before taking this class, your enthusiasm for cs will reduce after this class. The midterm and final is not hard, but you will lose point easily.
A lot of work but help you learn a lot...
If you are planning to take the class, DON'T. All your free time will be spent coding :). Your life will revolve around this class Funny guy, loves Pinterest. You is welcome
Awesome sauce!

Pattis's classes could be good, but he's no Klefstad. He's uncompromising, demanding, and unforgiving. His class isn't HARD -- merely stressful and unpredictable. If you're well-organized and good at meeting stringent deadlines, you'll probably pass easily. I fell into major depression the quarter I took his class, so long story short, I wasn't.

Pattis is an inspirational professor. His lectures are worth going to, you can't miss those days when he cracks a legendary CS joke. He genuinely understands the students and his grading scheme is quite generous.
Organized, knows what's he doing, knowledgable. Boring though.
What a god. Best prof at uci.

I loved ICS 33 with Pattis. He is very clear with how he grades your work; he gives you all the tests to run for your code. His notes are ugly, but super informative. I genuinely feel like I learned so much about Python after taking this course. You need to put in the work (weekly quizzes, a project every two weeks, etc), but it pays off.

Lots of hw,yes. But everything else is fair. He gives you all the tests that he uses to grade your hw and quiz. If you really work hard, how can you get a terrible score on these parts? And one below who said lab exam is hard---did you even do the sample exam? Mid and final are not easy but he curves a lot and only about 35% of your total grade.

Lots of tests: 8 take-home quizzes, 2 in-lab exams, one midterm and one final. Attending lecture is not always required (sometimes you have to hand in some stuff in the lecture); Pattis just reads out his super long notes in the lecture (although the notes are useful). If you did well in ICS 32, ICS 33 will not be hard.

Professor Pattis is the pinnacle of ICS at UCI. This man has an incredible class structure and is very organized. People consistently talk about his workload, but it is easily manageable if you start early and don't procrastinate. Help is easily accessible if you need it. Midterms and Finals are more than doable if you actually read his notes.
Pattis' class is really organized. Lecture is not much more than reading the notes, unfortunately. Fair grading and testing criteria.
Heavy but consistent workload, which allows you to get into the "flow" of work. Planning ahead is a must, and everything else will be manageable!

Heavy workload but you'll learn a lot. Very organized and clear on expectations - can guarantee 100% on programming assignments by checking against the provided batch self check tests. Written exams are dense, but in the end due to the written exams not weighing heavily around 40% of the class ends up with As.

The class is a ton of work, largely due to the reading material. However, the reading material really feels purposeful and valuable, explaining key Python concepts better than almost any other reading material I've read. If you always start reading and working on assignments WELL in advance, you'll do fine. He's very knowledgeable and it shows.

Heavy workload in this class but it's really unavoidable with any 46 professor. Very tough tests, programming assignments are implementations of c++ STL and he provides you with google tests that help a lot. I gained a lot from this class but it also seems like a bit heavier of a workload than Thornton. Take-home quiz every week. Lecture optional

Best ICS professor I have met so far. His basic self check program is really helpful for project. It's easy to keep track of your grade in his class. I did not feel any difficulties writing code in this course. However, written midterm and final exam need to be treated with cautious.

Only some of his lectures are somewhat helpful, but not many. However, he provides more than enough resources to do well in the course. His website is like an encyclopedia, but you get used to it. Overall, the amount of detail and work is overwhelming, but if you can get past it, you will become a great python programmer.

It's a lot of work, but you learn a lot. The grades are heavily skewed towards if you put in enough time into your assignments, around 50% of the grade is based on programming assignments & take home quizzes. So it's pretty easy to get a good grade in the class, if you put in the time. Not good at lecturing though, just reads off notes
Very touch exams. You will be asked to write several functions on paper and pencil on midterm and final exam.

Very tough class! Quizzes are mind wrecking, programming assignments are long, in lab exams are not very easy either and written exams are quite hard. Lecture is not very helpful because he only reads through his super long notes but his notes are important for written exams. I am glad I passed his class in one go. It was very stressful.

He made everything so difficult for students. Lots of homework, quizzes, in lab exams, midterm, final...... It doesn't feel like this is a 4 unit class. Maybe 8 units looks like more reasonable. lecture doesn't help on anything. Notes are super long and not straightforward.

His class is A LOT of work. There's a quiz nearly every week and the program assignments are lengthy, just like his lecture notes. I do like how he provides code so you can check whether or not your programs are doing what it's supposed to do. The in-lab exams are easier than the written tests for this reason. He's definitely knowledgeable.

Pattis' class is difficult, but his teaching is very good. His notes are super long, but they have all the info you need, so read the notes!! Individual assignments and tests are curved. He provides pictures and in-class stuff for some concepts, which is nice. Office hours get super packed tho. A lot more work than other classes, but still doable.

I dont like him. He gives the way too many works and it makes students hard to breathe. Especially for me who is not very good on programming. However, I have to read the notes very fast in order to submit my homework on time. I devote all of my times to this course. I always finish my work by midnight, but I got a very bad grade. I am so sad.

Professor Pattis has really really really long notes and you will receive a passing grade just by reading his notes. His extra credit policy encourages students to work on problems early, and students who submitted early actually have higher grades. His exams are hard, but if you understand course material very well you should be able to get an A.

Professor Pattis is an amazing lecturer. His lectures are clear and if you have questions, he's very helpful during his office hours. His grading criteria is very clear and his notes are amazing. All of his notes are in .txt but still are very well formatted and complete. Read his notes and you won't regret it. His tests are fair.
Very very hard class! Be ready to study extremely hard. The work takes you most of free time!!!

If you're a committed reader and notetaker, you can pass the class without going to lecture since lectures are dull. With that said, Pattis's class covered topics that I have been asked in many of my interviews for jobs. He teaches material thoroughly (though his notes are loooong) and in a way that you retain the knowledge for a long time.

Pattis and his long notes are very informative, and I did learn a lot. The quizzes and projects are not difficult but the class is a constant grind and there is a lot of material to go through, so it will be easy to fall behind. The midterm and final leave no time for thinking so you need to know your stuff

I took Pattis for my first quarter at UCI. I had failed to learn anything useful at my community college and, through no fault of his own, was completely lost at first, but after attending many office Pattis helped me become much more confident and I felt so much better prepared for the coming quarters.
It's really really hard, I will never take this class before

I loved this professor. However, It helps that I love computer science. If you come ready to learn, Pattis will teach you so much and you will become a lot more confident in your coding abilities. Do all the work and projects and the class is easy! Although the notes were a bit intimidating, I enjoyed every lecture. Loved this professor!
I liked him for ICS 33 for the most part, but then taking him for ICS 46 was terrible. Glad he doesn't teach upper div.

Read his notes.    Pattis gives you all the information that you need to succeed in the course in his massive course notes.  They are dense, but you can use CTRL + F to search specific terms.  The programming projects can be difficult but he gives you the tests he will run so you can know exactly what your score will be.

Pattis is more cut out to be a researcher than an instructor. Although he knows what he's talking about and tries to inform his students the best he can, his notes and lectures are convoluted and extremely cumbersome to read. Additionally, he will assign labs and quizzes at the same time (like ICS31), but it will feel like a VERY heavy workload.

ahPattis with his 99c whiteboard. Pattis honestly was born to teach, really puts in the effort of preparing his materials, his lectures were,lets just say, not the most interesting. batch self checks make everything clearcut if not easy. does care for students though cynical at times. work is needed but rewarding, and doesn't take insanely long.
Amazing and respected professor. The class needs daily work and can't be learned just before the midterm. The final was a bit harder than expected and should not be taken lightly.

His lectures are bloated and boring (and he is in desperate need of a whiteboard that doesn't look diseased), but his assignments and quizzes are pretty easy - if you follow along with his overly long notes online, you should be able to get the assignments done and pad your grade with the early turn-in extra credit
Reads off of the 8-font lecture notes in large blocks of text and does his best to explain things that aren't obvious. Guy doesn't smile much. Class is fair and a little tricky, but not impossible.

Had him for 33 ,46. My opinion of him improved from 33 to 46, even though the class structure is the same.  If you can keep up, you will learn so a lot, but the workload is intense (quizzes take time, but aren't outrageous.  Programming assignments (for 46) are pretty hard.) I REALLY wouldn't recommend taking a heavy course load with him.

Attendence is optional, but you better show up. His lectures weed out the massive manual that he calls "lecture notes" down to what you need to pass the class. Yes, he is a jerk sometimes, but I highly respect him because he is a walking encyclopedia. If you are passionate about coding, it will be very possible in getting a high A. Otherwise... gl

He is a lousy lecturer with an off-putting attitude. His lectures just consist of scrolling through and reading his verbose plain text file notes. Heavy workload, with a weekly take home quiz and biweekly programs. It is pretty easy to get an A in the class if you do the work - the grading system weighs the homework heavily (also batch self check)

His lecture notes are the primary source of content, but are massive walls of text - his writing style is INCREDIBLY verbose, and his lecture notes have no formatting beyond ASCII drawings. So they are a pain to read. There is also a constant stream of work - labs, quizzes, in-lab exams, written exams. You will learn, but it will be painful.

I took this class along with Math 3A and Informatics 43. All my attention and time went into this class. Must read notes to pass. Didn't really like his lectures too much since he just read over the the novels for each week.

be prepared to spend a lot of time in this class. he assigns a programming assignment that is long and then there are also quizzes every week. he doesn't provide much help when you ask. you dont get a lot of time when you do the midterm. he is just a hard professor who doesn't take into consideration how many other classes you're taking.
you have to read a lot and there is no summarized version or note. I like coding but I had hard time reading his stuff and it was extremely boring.
After taking 45c with Klefstad and 51 with alfaro, I felt that Pattis is one of the best professors in CS. At least, we have notes to read and clear assignment instructions :)))

Pattis is a clear professor, and gives students a lot of work. The students should not fear the workload he gives, especially if you are passionate about programming. He gives you the chance to expand your knowledge beyond what was learned in 32 or 31. His challlenges easily made me a better programmer by far. Get ready to read (or skim) his notes.

Beginning of the course there was a ton of reading to do, however as the course went on the amount of work lessened. The same goes for the programming assignments and quizzes that are due every other and every week, respectively.

Reads from his notes during lecture so it really isn't necessary to go. How you really learn is from sorting through the notes yourself to do the quizzes and programs. If you have a mostly clear understanding of how to do them, you'll be fine. It's not hard to get a good grade since bsc tells you exactly how your code should work.

Pattis has a way of explaining his core points in each lecture, and they are full of information you will use in the exam and labs. Honestly, the biggest lessons do not come from the readings (although there is A LOT of dense information), it comes from doing all the exams and programs correctly and understanding what is going on.

The guy is an egotistical jerk. AVOID AT ALL COSTS! Falsely accused of cheating (exonerated from all charges) heard from others that he tends to falsely accuse people so be careful when you code. He also reads from his notes in lecture so theres no point in showing up. The work is alright, just a lot of work.
A lot of reading, even during the class. Yes, he just reads his notes during the class.

Do the quizzes on your own. Sorting through the information on the readings while trying to find the answers to them really helps you in the long run.  Having those checks on the programs makes it easy to get an A on the projects. I would've taken more care to read if I could. Be sure to at least skim the readings before written test. GO TO LECTURE

This class itself is not hard. However, with his fantastic teaching skill, I understand xxxx in this class. I participated in some online programing training programI.  benefited a lot from it and I gained confidence of programming.  However, with Pettis ,I lost all my confidence. He  just bullied you academically by using his authority.  Great !

Professor Pattis is a good professor if you actually listen in class and read his lecture notes. Although they are quite dense, his notes provide very useful information for quizzes and programming assignments. The workload was very intense with weekly quizzes and programming assignments every two weeks. And asking questions really helps a lot!

Easy class, but boring. Pattis is the type of guy who does a lot of hand holding and writes long ass instructions for each assignment; but because of this, a lot of people don't even read them and might have trouble with the labs/quizzes. His online notes are long and disgusting, Google is way more useful.

Somewhat dull lectures. Insane amounts of notes, so finding important things or knowing EVERYTHING you should isn't really feasible. Most of class is not based on paper tests, and assignments can be gauranteed to 100% (batch self check). So, getting an A is rather easy, since most of grade is free. Quantity  quality in examples unfortunately

Be ready to work many hours for this class. It's called ICS 33 because it will take 33 hours of work per week from you to get through it. Do well on the in lab exams and you should be good based on program 1 and 2. Midterm was alright. Final was super hard.

Worst teacher ever.  Let's not talk about his quizzes, assignment or exams, because these help students with their growth. However, his notes are very hard to understand due to his grammatical errors and writing style. He also have some ridiculous policies regarding his class. I highly suggest avoiding this teacher.

Hardest class I've taken in my undergraduate class and a lot of students will blame it on Pattis but in reality they just couldn't step up to the plate. Pattis cares so much about his students, and was so reassuring when I visited office hours. Rare to find such genuine professors. He knows his material and the notes kill but you learn so much.

Amazing lecture, you can learn everything by just going to the lecture. Not much assignments, they have really clear instructions and they are not hard at all. Midterms and finals are easy As, as long as you go to his lectures. His notes are straight, short and simple, make sure you read them WORKD BY WORD. Great teacher! Can't wait to take ics 46!

pattis is a homie. gives a lot of work, but you'll learn so much from the class. each lecture he publishes a separate novel worth of notes. which you HAVE to read in order to do the quizzes and the midterm. my god the midterm. was like 9 pages long in 50 minutes. btw his c++ is nooby af he never deletes anything, but pattis is very intelligent

People are cheating their way through the class whether it is by addy or through past solutions. This guy is evil. People are taking drugs to pass this class.  Students are not learing, they are just memorizing and taking test. No wonder UCI ICS students don't find jobs after school. Apple and Google are recruiting from cal polys and UCSD and UCB

His detailed notes (skim them) are mostly what you need to do well. If you skip lecture, you can make up for it by reading, but it saves time to just attend. You can find most of what you need for quizzes/programs in the notes. Give yourself at least 3 days to work on them. Use bsc! Grades fairly. Written exams test concepts, in-lab tests debugging

He writes a TON of in-depth notes that may save your ass during the quarter, making the textbook essentially useless -- don't buy it. Our class had weekly "quizzes" aka homework, bi-weekly programming assignments, 2 in-lab exams, 1 midterm, and a final. Overall, expect a lot of reading & work in general. Pattis will take up a lot of your free time.
Quizzes are so hard. Exams are even harder. I cannot handle it. But the professor is very nice.

Be aware that Pattis is super anal and may accuse you of cheating regardless of if you cheated or not. Be prepared to spend lots of hours outside of class finishing assignments. Good curve and gives a little bit of extra credit. Provides notes which is helpful. Google is truly your friend in this class.

Pattis is not a good lecturer but his notes are comprehensive and you can learn A LOT by reading them.  Doing so will get you a good grade in the class and it won't be necessary to attend his lectures.  Also, his class is a lot of work, so choose classes with a lighter workload.  His class is fun except the weekly quizzes can be annoying at times.
Program 2,3,4 are too hard(1 and 5 are easy). Tests and quizzes are fair. A lot of work but worth it.

You are expecting taking two classes at once with extremely unclear quizes, programs and exams. This guy literally is reading his lecture note during lecture. You will spend your entire life doing his program assignment and not even 10% of it is gonna be on the exam. It's not a hard class, but he makes it extremely confused with his own error/fault

This class can be frustrating and there is a decent amount of work. If you want an A, you need to follow all of his IDE (Eclipse) setup instructions, read all of his lecture notes (make sure you highlight all the important parts for reference),  and start programming assignments as soon as possible (there will be a lot of bugs). Have fun :)

Be ready to deal with buggy code, and spend more time figuring out how to get his library to work than actually programming. If you are not an expert in linking c++ libraries, you have to use Eclipse on Windows or you will double your headaches. If you can, take any other professor for this class. Also class is not curved.
TOOOO MANY WORK! HARD EXAMS! MEAN ATTITUDE.

This class was a challenge. 8 quizzes, 2 in-lab exams, 5 projects, a midterm, and a final. He tells you exactly what he wants by giving a self check program. Projects are fun. The midterm and final are going to be tough. the in-lab exams are basically knowing how to program without google. The quizzes were the worst, they were a nightmare.

I fell in love with programming after taking ICS 31 and having Pattis introduce me to it. He takes you from never having used more than Microsoft word to being somewhat decent in Python.  Dont get me wrong this class is by no means easy at all its very time consuming, but it is clear, fair, and you will come out of it KNOWING what you learned well.

Pattis is a very knowledgeable professor. He is very helpful. But his lectures are dull and boring.  And his notes are way too big to read. This class is not hard, but it is too much work for 4 units. 8 quizzes, 5 projects, 2 in-lab programming exams, midterm and final. Quizzes will haunt you the most.

Tough class, I'm second language, so it's like hell. Advice: Read, summarize the notes, do ALL assignments. Love: All the materials he taught, really cool and helpful. Hate: Everything else. My feeling: sometimes I like him, sometimes I hate him so much I feel like I'd better drop the class. Thanks god I go till the end.
Definitely a tough class. Pattis is a pretty good teacher, but sometimes rambles in lecture. Make sure to pay attention because plenty of students failed this class.

Lectures aren't very fun, they tend to drag on and most people get distracted. A lot of the compsci taught in the class is more abstract than previous ICS classes. Weekly quizzes, along with a lab program due every 2 weeks. Regardless of the work load and lectures, Pattis is actually REALLY good at teaching and you will learn a lot.

Pattis' ics33 is really tough, but CS is a tough thing itself. His quizzes are helpful but some of the programming assignments are not related to the lecture material at all. He is not a fair grader. He only grades according to the number of incorrects. But you can really learn a lot of things if you pay attention to this course. I love Pattis.

The lectures are really boring for a majority of the time. He never writes any actual code. Just reads through lecture notes an sometimes draws some diagrams. WAY too much homework. If you take ics33 with Pattis, make sure the rest of your classes have a fairly easy workload. You need to dedicate most of your time outside of class to his homework

Ok, I have already read some reviews about Pattis for ICS 33. Even though there are a lot of bad reviews about his class, I still think he is one of the best professor who teaches in his own way. His lecture is decent, but his notes are AMAZING!!! Like seriously, if you read the notes at least 2 times, you will learn a lot and do well in his class.

Can't recommend. He's not bad; you can tell he loves what he's doing but I feel that he's really inefficient at teaching it. He takes pages to teach about a topic that could have been explained in a few paragraphs. His lectures are really boring and maybe 25% attend. Maybe he should've been a writing professor because this guy can write for days.

Never have I been more frustrated- his assignments are scary. Weekly quizzes and labs. He REALLY likes to write. There's a lot to read, and you've got to read very closely or you'll miss out on crucial details. Can I stress HE WRITES A LOT. YOU WILL BE READING. A LOT. THIS IS A STRESSFUL CLASS.

Long notes that aren't very clear. Assignments and quizzes are very wordy and can be misinterpreted easily especially for non-english speaking students. Boring lectures. Class is not impossible to do well in but it will consume a lot of your daily life so be prepared for that. Very useful office hours but lectures can make you fall asleep.

By no means is this an easy class. There's lots of works so if you can manage it whilst doing the reading, you'll be fine. Reading his notes is essential as most of the questions on the final are based off those readings. Assignments took a lot of my time, but it was well worthed at the end. Take only if you have time to spare!
Pattis seems to love teaching and he's really good at it. Assigns a good amount of work, but it never feels unfair.

The more times I take a course with Pattis, the more I begin to appreciate what he has to offer as lecturer. His notes are thorough, his grading criteria is clear, and he is quick to answer any questions you ask him. Yes, he is very traditional in terms of teaching style, and his exams can run a bit long, but he does his job and he does it well.

Good luck, that's all I have to say. Thankfully the notes help immensely with the quizzes and programming assignments, but they are novels in and of themselves and written in plaintext. His lectures consist of him literally reading his notes from the website. Make sure to start the assignments EARLY as there will be many bugs in your code.

His lectures aren't very interesting but he makes up for it with his very thorough notes. If you read his notes, you can do all the assignments for this class. Assignments are reasonably challenging but his tests expect you to do a lot in a short amount of time.

Garbage class. Taught material not even relevant to the course, and built his own data structure library to use for the course, which barely worked and had multiple issues. The course should have been named "How not to make Data Structures and algorithms".

Usually dry lectures, but he can be funny if he wants. His whiteboard demonstrations really help visualizing concepts, so I recommend attending lectures for them. Assignments are doable, although 3 out of 5 of them are basically the same thing. Exams are very difficult. You can get by with his notes, but be aware they're long (albeit thorough).

His notes are dry but more easier to follow than his lecturing. He answers emails quickly and is always willing is to help. However, there's weekly quizzes and long assignments so be prepared to put time into the class if you don't pick up things smoothly. Eclipse is awful but you need to use it for testing your programs in this class.

This class should just be called Pattis Structures and Algorithms, bc of the assignments alone. Your basically implementing a linked list version of every array structure that he gives you. Pattis also has really poor C++ skills. Memory leaks everywhere for the sake of shortening code. You might learn some theory, but no applicable C++

Here's the bottom line. This course's name should be changed from "Data Structures" to "How Eclipse Gives You Depression." Don't get me wrong. The actual concepts you learn in this course are pretty useful, but the real challenge is trying to use the awful (and I mean AWFUL) Eclipse environment.  And if you have a Mac it's about 1000x more painful.

Lectures are very boring.  Weekly quizzes that are like mini programming assignments. In addition to large programming assignments due every 2 weeks, usually having to do with implementing a data structure. He uses Eclipse, which is very annoying to work with! I had so many problems using Eclipse on my Mac and some programs wouldn't even compile.

This class was honestly one of the easiest classes I have taken here at UCI. If you had Professor Kay for ICS 31 and thought he was easy, you have not seen ICS 33 with Pattis yet. This is an easy A. I took this to fulfill my GE's and it was a breeze. Would take again.
tough teacher, tons of work to do like we dont have other class

One word: dry. But if you can get past this, then he is very thorough. If you pay attention, you will learn A LOT. As for workload, it's pretty tough. Programming ain't easy, but if you make use of the message board he has and really get in the zone, you will do well.

Very difficult class if you enroll without any prior knowledge to programming. His pace is very quick and gives large amounts of work that will keep you busy either doing his work or studying for the exams.

Honestly not impossible to pass. Just that between his take-home quizzes and labs, he gives an WAY too much work. His workload (as well as work from other classes) makes being able to go through all of his extremely verbose (yet helpful) online notes impossible. He could teach the class in a much simpler way, but is instead wordy and ambiguous.

Professor Pattis is an excellent teacher. His assignments and exams are very fair, and he does a great job answering any questions you have and making sure you have access to all the materials you will need for the course. The only real problem I have with Pattis is that his attitude makes him not very likeable, despite his ability to teach well.

Lectures are dry and gives lots of assignments but gives lots of chances to improve; lots of extra credit and replaced midterm score with final score. He gives you the test script they grade programs with so you know you're right. If you're new to or not serious about programming, you'll probably be mowed down by his timed in-lab programming exams.
Very very boring and pointless class, avoid at all costs if you do not have programming experiance. You will not do well.

I came into this class to spend time on programming not to spend time trying to understand his labs. I have lost all interest in programming this quarter because his lab assignments are not clear at all! All the time spent understanding his assignments on top of all the work he gives leads me to believe that he doesn't think we have other classes.

WARNING! DO NOT TAKE! This professor is the WORST! The best analogy of this class (as described by multiple successful upper division computer science students) is like "teaching algebra to a kindergartener". His bar/pace is so high that it is literally impossible to pass without cheating or having prior experience. Avoid at all costs.

This class wasn't the easiest, but I think Pattis is an excellent teacher. It was challenging in a good way. The tests are hard, but he gives plenty of opportunities for extra credit here and there. He always keeps students updated, which is nice.
Boring class.
Lab assignments are confusing. I do not know what he wants.

This class will keep you busy throughout the week but you will learn a lot. Do not procrastinate on lab assignments and do well on quizzes and you'll pass. Nice prof but dry lectures. LARC helped me through those topics I didn't understand in pattis' lecture.

Very fair grader. Extra credit opportunity if you turn in assignments early, curves well. Exams are tricky but studying is minimal. He tests mostly on how well you understand the main topics he outlines for each exam. He responds to e-mails in minutes. Very nice guy. Programming projects (except for the last one) were boring, long, but rewarding.

Charismatic professor with an incredible amount of knowledge, and not just in his field.   Can seem a bit abrasive in lecture, but is a nice guy if you get a chance to talk to him.   If you understand the material, you're fine. If not, make a point not to fall behind.
Lectures are super boring.

Thorton is amazing! Explains introductory CS concepts really well and understands the students' background. He writes VERY clear notes, exercises, and project guides on the ICS 32A website; it's your own effort that will earn a good grade in his class.
None of his lectures correspond with lab assignments. Lectures were always a week behind of what we had to do in lab. I learned more in lab than during lecture. Lectures were 100% useless.

Being new to Python, programming is honestly one of the hardest classes I've ever had to take. No matter how much I try, it's just really hard for me to get it. I dislike how what's covered in lecture barely correlates at all with lab, if you're going to give hard labs at least guide us with stuff RELEVANT to lab.

From a difficulty standpoint, Professor Wang's Java course was quite a breeze. The first half of the course is practically review, with the second half reserved for the more peculiar aspects of Java like Android and interfaces. Exams often employ trick questions, but lab assignments are easy, though pair programming is required for all of them.

Professor Wang is certainly one of the more approachable professors at UCI, but as a writing instructor, his skills are questionable. Workload is low (5 written assignments and 2 short presentations) but instructions are often vague, grading is inconsistent, and most of the lectures are useless. It is an easy A, but do not expect to learn much.
It was awesome

Richert is by far my favorite professor at UCI. I took 45C with him and he is super helpful at office hours if you decide to go, his notes are incredibly clear, his lectures are very informative, and his labsexams are do-able! 1010 would take his class again.

He was overall a great professor though he's one of the newest. His lectures are great. He's very enthusiastic about teaching and is very chill. His notes are extremely clear and helpful. Study using his notes and you will pass his tests! Best ICS professor so far at UCI. I hope to have a chance to take him again.
His lecture is crystal clear. i wish he would teach 46

Let me put this way: he's extremely clear in his lecture and I would take any class that he teaches! Only 2 tests midterm and final : medium-hard level. You should read the book that he recommended and you will be fine. His projects are hard, but come to his office hour + TA will help + know how to google for the project's hint. LoL

Don't pick this professor's class. He writes all the code on the black board and his writing is too small to see when you sit at back. His lecture is boring. The lab assignment does not relate to what he taught in the lecture.  If you don't have any experience in JAVA, it can be a hard class.

One of the most condescending and unhelpful teachers I've ever had. Anytime a person asks a question, he appears to take it personally and give you a smart-ass answer to make you feel stupid. Quizzes/HW are pretty straightforward. Don't take him if you expect a teacher that is easy to approach for questions/help. Very arrogant and patronizing.

Very rude. If you're brave enough to ask a question, expect to be looked down upon with a very condescending answer.  Other then that, this class is decent.  Weekly quiz's (40% of grade), homework (10%) and final (50%!).  As long as you do the homework and understand the material, the questions on the quiz's and tests are fair.

All lectures are done on the whiteboard. There is very little lecture info online so while you are not graded on attendance it is a must if you want to pass. His lectures are great and he makes sure students understand the material as he goes. When you are stuck on your code just go talk to him! He will clearly guide you to fixing the problem.

The labs and weekly homework are difficult and definitely require attendance and detailed notes during lectures. His lectures cover all topics needed for the assignments, but I still found it necessary to use Google a lot since the homework usually goes more in depth and he often leaves a few small but important details to the last minute of class.

I took this class over summer and I thoroughly enjoyed taking 45C and learning C++. The professor was not very helpful and this class would be much better off taken during the school year because there are more labs and more time. It definitely didn't help me with any interview questions about data structures...

I took the 5-week summer session with him. The class was hard-core writing since there was always something due almost every day (either discussion posts or essays). There was no lecture and I basically learned from fixing the rough drafts based on the TA's feedbacks. Better have strong writing fundamentals from your lower-division writing classes.
Quizzes were more complex than the lab and lecture.

Professor Kay does a really good job of introducing Python, especially since I had no prior background to coding. The assignments were fairly easy, but they do get more challenging towards the end. He does release previous midterms, so use those to study as well as the weekly quizzes. Overall, this class is very manageable.

Professor Kay is awesome. ICS 31 is an intro course thus it is not a hard one. Be sure to ask questions when you don't understand any lab assignments and remember to REALLY do the quizzes. Study the past midterms and you'll be fine.
Professor Kay is awesome.
That was an easy class
Easy A, amazing professor

His teaching was very easy to understand, and the midterms aren't difficult if you study the previous midterms he posts. The labs were difficult towards the end of the quarter, but nothing compared to what you'll see after ICS 31. However, he's a great professor.

Overall explains concepts well enough. Midterms are very easy because they are almost exactly the same as the previous midterms, which he posts with answers. Quizzes are also easy because they come with an answer key, though you should do it without the key if you actually want to learn. Lab is  a bit harder, but not impossible. Would take again.
For an intro CS class, ICS 31 was jokingly easy. Slow pace, extremely easy exams,  but forced to do pair-programming for the programs.
Easy teacher. Calm and somewhat indifferent. For ICS 31, you have to *try* to fail the course.
Class is ridiculously easy. Exams are way too easy, and labs can be completed very quickly, though you are required to do pair-programming.

David Kay is a perfect instructor for those going into their first programming class ever. He structures his midterms and tests in a comprehensive manner, and they're heavily based on the material covered in class, in labs, and sometimes in the readings. The labs themselves are VERY straightforward, almost designed cook-book style.
Really nice professor. Very patient in answering questions. Although he usually do typings, that is totally fine for intro-programming.
Very easy class. Good professor.

He is really an amazing professor. His lecture is really clear and he is really helpful. Grades only depend on quiz per week with credit if you did it, pair-programming projects, one midterm and one final.

Easy A. Lectures available online so attendance isn't mandatory. Clear explanations of basic programming concepts so you can have no prior programming experience and still get an A. Labs are easy and can be finished within 2-4 hours per week.

Material taught in class is organized but not always related to lab. Labs are the most difficult part. Pair programming can be disappointing if you are paired up with people who aren't prepared. Midterms are very easy (just take the previous exams). There are online quizzes and partner evaluations that contribute to grade too. Final wasn't too bad.
Helpful lecture, great professor, easy A. To be honest, you will get A only with class notes.

Do yourself a favor and read the textbook in the beginning if you are a beginner to programming in Python. He uploads recordings of his lectures online, but sometimes some will run into errors. I was in his 8am class so I relied heavily on them. Study them for tests. The last program (bed and breakfast) was long, so start early if you can.

Lectures felt long and boring (quiet lecture hall while he was typing out the notes). Lab assignments were fine, but they got harder later in the quarter. The two midterms were very easy (just study past midterms), and the final was easy as well (let's you bring a page of notes).

I honestly learned more in labs than in lectures. His notes are sometimes really confusing. The TA taught more than he did, so go to labs, they're essential for passing. Two midterms and final are all doable. I'm new to programming, but I still got an A.
Kay is a good lecturer. He will teach you the the Computer Science fundamentals. Overall an intelligent and good lecturer.

Took ICS31 w/ Kay Fall 2015. Lab attendance required, forced to do menial programming problems with a partner. Only went to first 2 lectures, skipped the rest. Terrible at lecturing, changes his tone/volume spastically, poor at explaining things. Actual lab work is easy beyond belief. Tests are relatively easy (30 min)  TL;DR bad teacher, easy A
pretty good lectures. Explains things really well. exams are fair. Can give you more advice besides studies.

Go to lecture, learn stuff, do labs, get A in class. Tests are very easy as long as you aren't slacking. I didn't read any of the book, missed online points, and got a solid A in the class because I understood the labs well.  Lectures are boring, but VERY informative, so don't miss them. Bad lab partners are common (sucks), which helps you learn.

Professor Kay teaches ICS 31, and he is experienced. Labs take up a huge part of your week, so beware of that (destined to non-comp sci majors)! His attendance isn't too great, and a lot of people are missing on concepts. The two midterms and final mainly test your attention to detail, so be careful with that. However, they are relatively easy.

Professor Kay is a really helpful and clear lecturer. He truly wants you to succeed so go to lectures. However, if you can't, it's okay because he sends you emails of the lecture notes and replays. The labs are pretty doable, but get progressively harder and you might have to spend a lot of time on them. Overall, a pretty easy class.

Enjoyable class! It is extremely easy to get an A on both midterms if you look over the past midterms. The final was easy too. If you genuinely try to complete the labs with your partner exactly how Professor Kay wants you to, you'll learn a lot of things that will make you think differently and outside of the box.

Having Professor Kay for ICS 31 was pretty great. The class was really easy, especially if you have previous experience in coding.  If you do have previous experience, the class is essentially a courter long review, and if not you will catch on quick with his lectures. You will have a lab every week with a partner, that covers the topic for the wk.
Amazing Programming teach 11/10 IGN. He's papi AF
He was a great professor who allowed an equal opportunity for each student to pass.
Great teacher! Helped each everyone into the python language!

The labs and lecture are really long. But he posts recordings online which is nice. A bad partner in lab can really put a downer on your week. Pair programming required though. Assignments are clear, but he doesn't give you a grade breakdown. Gives you a page of notes for the final.
