ICS 31 is an easy course for computer science. If you follow his steps during lectures, and do his lab assignments carefully and thoroughly, you will get a great score for this class.

Tests are pretty easy. Get ready to spend about 10 hours per week on labs. Kay gives away lab questions in lecture. The book is a must for all newbies. Few people actually show up to lecture. All labs are done with a partner. Kay is clear with material and grading. Highly recommend.

Perfect course! I have calculated that over 40% classmates got at least A- in fall 2014. Nearly the best choice for GE II! Labs are easy to finish even without your partner. DO NOT forget to do your quizzes! Good luck for getting an A!!!

This is the easiest course I have taken at UCI so far. Not only because of the fact that the labs are pathetically easy, but also because of how Kay teaches. He does a very good job of easing you into the Python language. This is also great prep for future ICS courses. It might be a little more difficult if programming isn't your thing.

An easy introduction course to Python; however, ICS 32 is a big jump. Lectures aren't necessary, as what Kay talks about is in the textbook. Labs are all done with a partner and aren't too difficult at all (the last lab though is a doozy). 2 midterms, which are easy if you study from the practice midterms online. Final also isn't too difficult too.

I am new to computer science and that it was a good introductory class. It is about introduction to python. During lectures, Professor Kay would code which is useful for the labs, so it is useful to go to class. He is a good professor overall and very helpful if you go to his office hours.
He was pretty helpful in understanding for lab assignments. Got me excited for computer science.

Labs are very difficult for those who have no experience whatsoever in programming.  Midterms AREN'T open note but are very easy since there are sample midterms to study off of. They're exactly like them, careful of multiple choice. Lectures are boring but are very clear. Difficult of labs  easiness of lectures. Textbook VERY useful for newbies.

Professor Kay is an excellent professor! However, the class is incredibly hard. I had to retake this class twice before I managed to get a C- . Out of the ICS 30 series, this was the hardest one. I took ICS 33 with Pattis and got an A+, but I failed this one twice. Professor Kay is overall a great professor though.
Excellent professor, worth taking his class

Super easy, lectures are a bit boring as the material is quite basic. Manageable weekly labs that are done using pair programming, requires little time outside of your lab period to complete. Midterm and final are also clear-cut and easy.

Professor Kay is a bit boring. His lectures drag on for too long and he takes forever to explain even the simplest concepts. It is very easy though; I came in with no programming experience at all and did very well on all of his exams. Labs were a bit difficult and take a long time to complete, but they were fair.

As long as you do and the labs (not have your partner do them for you), go to lecture, and do the practice tests he posts online, the midterms and final are a breeze. Most labs can be completed during the lab sections, so there is minimal outside work. Kay is a good professor and will teach you a lot despite the relative easiness of the class.

ICS 31 with Kay was a breeze for me (had some prior programming experience). He explains things well and it was a piece of cake for me taking his class. Relatively easy midterm and final. Takes time to make sure the class understands everything and answer questions.
Great professor who was fair and cared about his students.  Frequently stops to answer any questions and overall a great introductory course to programming.
Very helpful during midterms and exams, Also very understanding toward his students. Great class to start learning coding
He's a great professor for Intro to Python. Definitely helpful and clear in presentation. You will learn a lot from him. Such a nice guy.
Great first CS professor!

Very helpful professor! Easy class, he really treats Intro to computing as intro to computing! Make sure to attend labs, and use those to review for the midterms and final. Very easy midterms and final if you know your stuff. Also, use the practice textbook problems. It's actually helpful to read the book.

Probably one of the easier ICS professors. You can tell he's really interested in teaching the subject and making sure everyone understands. This is not the class to just try "getting by" in. You should really try learning the material!

Very great professor. He really shows how he cares a lot about his students. Open note final, extremely easy midterms, interesting lab assignments. His lectures can drag on at times though. He's very friendly and very approachable for any sort of help. Definitely recommend!
Great teacher, Goes off topic sometimes but really knows what he is doing. His midterms are way too easy. Recommended probably the easiest teacher in the 31 series.
easy class. good professor. Learned a lot in his class. Take notes and quizzes are important in order to get good test scores.

Wu is a great professor, and he's always willing to offer help during his office hour. You will get a good grade in this course and definitely learn useful and important knowledge. After all 45J is just a basic programming course in Java, of course you can learn it by yourself but I'd say Wu is very helpful for me.

Even though Wu said we are only expected to know basic knowledge about Java, this class is MOSTLY provided for non-CS majors. Just like this is my LAST class of Computer Science. Wu has humor and respect, and he has office hour after every lecture for only 30+ students in his class. His homework is easy but includes most of the important knowledge.

Took ICS 45C with Wu. He didn't cover much about pointers whatsoever, which means you would be screwed in 46 unless you self-studied a lot or had a friend helping you out. Tests and projects were fairly straight forward - not a hard class overall - but actually learning C++ is pretty useful, which doesn't happen if you take Wu.
Wu's class is really skr awesome!

Really bad lectures. Really Bad Lecture. Don't go to lectures because they are really bad. I have taken Wu for ICS45J a few quarters go(Fall 2017) and it was one of the worst professors I've taken. The lectures are hard to comprehend and very monotonous. The class was very unorganized. For one of the midterms, he spent 20 minutes to them out

This man released his rubric the night before the due date. I have no idea why he doing this. The only explanation might be that he just want to screw you up before he is fired. BTW, he give unexpected quiz twice this quarter, which is not mentioned in the first lecture. If you want to graduate, stay away from him.s
After a quarter, I found that I was taking ICS 45C: programing in ppt
Sauce code lecture. AndJava-doc style function comments for all functions and member functions that you use in your homework.

Wu's class was heavily critiqued because his assignments were trivial. As a "fix" to this issue he, VERBATIM, comments and all, copies Prof. Klefstad's project specs, all while giving 0 of the direction or resources Klefstad provided for his students. It is astounding he is still allowed to teach at UCI given the impact (or lack thereof) hes had.
This man keeps saying "Interge"

Professor Wu's lectures are so amazing that you can barely learn nothing from them. I really respect him for his courage since he is brave enough to teach stuff that he does not even know. My experience with him inspires me to become a college professor in the future because I think all TAs can do much better than him.
He actually inspired me that I want to become a Professor in the future, because I thought, If someone one like him get to teach at a University, I can do better.

The class uses homework from another teacher but Wu only teaches you basic stuff. Like imagine ICS 33 with Pattis but without the notes. Here's what I know so far: if (lecture_slides  homework_material) good_class(); else bad_class();

The homework material outpaces Wu's ability to teach the required knowledge because he is borrowing bits and pieces from other professors that presumably actually teach C++. Apparently this was an easy class in previous quarters because he gave trivial homework. Not anymore.

Wu is legit one of the most awful professors at UCI. You gain absolutely nothing from attending lectures but he expects you to do Klefstad's project. He changed his curriculum but not his teaching style, which leaves all students unable to complete any projects. Bobak is our only saving grace.

I'm just glad that I'm done with this class. Stopped showing up to lecture after the first week or so. I get that having clean, well-documented code is important, but it was so tedious and annoying to do for each HW that were already simple enough. Makes you hand-write JavaDoc comments for the code you write on exams as well. ANNOYING

I think he took the negative feedback to heart because this quarter things ran a lot more smoothly. The midterm was multiple choice with a hand-written coding question. The final was of a similar format. He's not a good lecturer though; it's straight from the book. His homework isn't as hard as other classes, but they're not super easy either

Professor Wu's class didn't do too much to help me get a grasp of C++ concepts. His projects are nothing more than lists of coding problems to solve. Only the last project was a serious assignment (code an AI for tic-tac-toe). His lectures are boring and each slide is cluttered and messy, not to mention he scribbles all over them in class.
Garbage. Covers less than half of what's needed to truly know C++. Easy class, trivial assignments, but you learn close to nothing.

Yeah soooo... "UCI spent a loooottttt of monnneeeyyy on the canvas system". Just know that when a teacher passes tests up the column (not down the row) thinking that the seats are not staggered, well he might not be the teacher you want to take. Lets just say he's not really a good teacher and you won't learn anything.

45C with this professor is kinda an easy A if you learn C++ like you are supposed to (focus on practical aspects of programming NOT the theory). Exams are basically writing code on paper. Class is too easy compared to the other professor, I don't feel like this class is UCI level, it is basically a cal state class imported to UCI, too easy...
Vague and unclear guidelines for everything
Everything from lectures, tests to grades is unorganized. Lots of guess work because no clear guidelines provided.

Worst professor ever. For the whole quarter, he taught only half of the materials compares to other professors. And since his made his midterm too easy, he changed the percentage of midterm and made final worth 50% of the grade and then gave a super hard final focusing on nonsense details. I don't know why the school wants to hire him.

He's average at best. He is very disorganized but is improving. Projects are very open ended and no proper specifications but we get docked off for stuff we didn't even know we had to do. My prior java knowledge immensely helped during tests compared to what he teaches. Hope he improves in the future but I wouldn't take his class again.

Just took his final today. The questions are extremely deviated from what he talks about in lecture. Instead of giving tests on important knowledge bases, or general java techniques, he seems to be a lover of those minuscule knowledge points that we may not encounter anymore later. Don't ever take him if other options are available.

His class is boring, not clear enough and useless. His assignments won't help you understand C++. His class may be easy and you won't get a terrible grade, but the knowledge is more important than the GPA. Take his class if you want to know how boring programming can be.
Very slow, easy class. The pace is ridiculously slow, it's week 5 and he has barely begun covering functions in C++... for a 4th quarter programming course.

Great professor: Good lectures, great sense of humor, very kind to students. Easy to reach outside of class and really goes the extra mile to address student questions/concerns. His Jupyter Notebooks are extremely helpful and detailed. A far less stressful alternative to Pattis: I really enjoyed Watkin's ICS33, wish he taught outside of summer too.

Honestly the most positive cs experience I've had. Lectures are based on notes given at the beginning of the week. Full page cheat sheet on both the midterm and final. Quizzes and projects are a huge part of the grade so if you do well on them you don't have to worry about the tests.

This teacher was seriouosly awesome. He really cares about what he's teaching and very flexible and understanding with his turn in policy if you make a mistake or accidently turn in something late. His assignments aren't hard at all and VERY straightforward. I would definitely recommend if you're looking for an upper division writing class.
absolutely the best.
David is an excellent tutor and very passionate about programming.
Very useful and extremely nice. Responds timely to emails, provided practice midterms, made sure we understood concepts before moving on. Would highly recommend.

On one hand, you have to code PRECISELY to pass the rigid auto grader.
On the other hand, instructions are VAGUE and ask you to be CREATIVE, which contradicts with the auto grader.
Parts of assignments don't provide auto graders to you, so you're essentially guessing. 
Giving many extra credits doesn't make irritating grading acceptable.
goated professor, assignments are hard but it prepares you for 33. ALOT of EC so you should end with a good grade as long you do your assignments.

Krone-Martins is a passionate guy, and I respect him for it. The assignments are difficult, yes. But there are plenty of extra credit opportunities to offset this balance. He also makes the final VERY easy. Room to learn and room to get a good grade!
Very kind person and understanding professor. Although the content could be hard but it is very useful for future class~~~

Professor's a chill dude. Lectures were boring and I couldn't find myself to pay attention. Labs are easy and are a good setup to assignments. Assignments are difficult but not impossible. Ask LA's and peers for support. Auto-grader is bad, so go to lab to get regraded when possible. TA's respond inconsistently. Easy final. Lots of EC opportunities
good teacher, hard projects, autograder is a nightmare, work hard and its an easy A .

#1C continue - 5% ec not hard to get, can drop 10/18 labs. final not too hard, randomly extends "assignments" (they're legit full on projects). projects themselves aren't bad just v tedious. ok thats all the good things i can think of. more cons that i didnt think of earlier: everytime i get a grade back like i have no idea if i failed or not.

#1B continue - labs not helpful, vague feedback, just pray ur TA is nice cuz they can give points back (i got 1/100 points back :/ while my LA got like 20 his year), waited like 3 hours to get my proj regraded just to tell them they cant do anything. workout projects are "optional" altho most ppl didnt know thats only true if u do ec. ok onto pros.

#1A - Instructions UNCLEAR, took off points for no reason, lowest on project was -0.1???, TA never respond, finished grading project done in w2 in w10, grades stuff so late and messes up your grade so that you have no time to fix, lectures not helpful, evrythng unorganized, autograder faulty at times hello??, unspecified criteria..
Krone-martins is a passionate professor. Projects are cool but the autograder is strict so make sure to follow the prompt carefully.

There is office hours, 5 hours total. He gives you two weeks for each project, and you have 2 weeks to ask if you r not clear with the instructions. FOR REAL, hes not that bad, those who rate him 1 prob never tried to study in this course. is dropping 10/18 labs and all the free and easy extra credit not enought for you??? why are you complaining.

i like him a lot!!! very nice and friendly person, cares about student a lot, useful office hours, just make show to do the labs and start your project/assignments early, dont wait till the last minute to do it!!!

This guys lectures do NOT correspond to the projects. Vague instructions mainly graded off an autograder we do not receive. Currently sitting in lecture before final typing this and I still have zero idea what my grade is going to be since he has only graded 3/5 projects. Very nice professor but his class is unnecessarily difficult.

I was originally try to comment something about this cuss. Then I finded out that is impossible for me describe my experience for this class without using curse words. But one of the TA and most LA are nice

Prof doesnt make sense, not just content but you literally cannot understand due to accent. It is currently finals week and we dk our grade...since he disabled it. No communication.55% of grade is from projects, through autograder(not given to us) which is trash so one small error and its wraps. 3/5 projects graded so far and its finals week...how

i go to his classes and i cant understand him tbh. all the assignments, they're cool and all but so unnecessarily difficult. and then the autograder sucks. maybe provide it to us so we at least are guaranteed some poitns instead of realizing we "missed" something you didn't even point out in your rubric.

I would like to keep this short.

1. Autograder sucks | Horrible grader
2. Never has office hours
3. The TAs are unresponsive (yeah, you know which TA you are. Took 5 days to respond, and only responded with "No").
4. Difficult spike from ICS 31
5. Thick accent. Lecs don't help. You're better off watching YouTube videos.
6. VAGUE INSTRUCTIONS.

Horrible grading... expect to get a failing score of an autograder that throws a 0 at you. Expect to wait in lab for hours to get the assignment regraded from a TA. Expect to spend a long time understanding vague instructions. Expect for the server to crash near deadlines. Don't expect anything good.. but do expect to learn how to manage your time.

Little to no feedback is given on grades, and paired with a strict autograder giving tons of people zero's, its bound to leave students in a downhill spiral of failure. Overly strict autograder has constant errors and flaws, little feedback on grades, and getting NO email responses back from TA's or the professor.
What other class do you know has 2.1k ed discussion posts before the course is even over
no

Professor Krone-Martins seems like a chill guy, but his class has some serious issues. The grading criteria for the assignments are very unclear. Instructions are incredibly vague, so much so that it becomes a serious issue with the autograder. He also takes ages to release grades, to the point where it is problematic.

The use of a strict autograder (accompanied by unclear assignment instructions) could screw you over, even if your program works gracefully. Students had to ask for regrades which took up everyone's time along with grades being released until week 6. Lecture material may not always be helpful, and it's hard to get ahold of the professor. It's messy

Be prepared to spend a lot of time, lots of work including labs during the week, workout projects as well as your other "assignments" (more of like actual projects). Lectures are optional as he posts slides and recordings. He does seem to care about his students, but overall his teaching methods aren't the greatest for a lower-division CS course.

He has a lot of workload but if you work hard you'll get well in it. He also count the 5.5 bonus points towards A+ and make me jump from A to A+. I am very scared at first but after a quarter I find out that he is quite a good professor nonetheless.

As a person, he's not a bad guy. However, it was clear that he didn't know how to teach ICS 32. Most of the assignments are vague at best, with grading being even more unclear. There were many times when grades had to be regarded to the point that even our final grade had to be changed because of calculation errors. Hopefully, it gets better.

Really huge amount of homework and I spend on average 20+ hours each week on this class. The final is quite easy. But in order to get A+ extra credit cannot apply. This quarter's ics 32 really makes me tired out.

Class was very difficult considering this was many students second quarter coding. Assignment instructions were unclear, grading involved autotests that covered things not in the instructions. Assignments were cumulative but grades weren't released until week 6. Lectures/Labs were not helpful and TAs were oftentimes confused too. Final was easy tho

Pros: 1. Willing to work overtime to teach struggling students. 2. 5.25% Extra credit. 3. Helpful office hours.

Cons:1. Vague homework criteria (no Autotrader for students)2. Lots of homeworks.3. Blurry lectures heavily focused on implementation.
Conclusion: Take this professor only if you already knows programming, or else you will Google a lot.

Posts lectures online and attendance isn't mandatory. Assignments were kinda vague in description but he was very fair and caring and allows for regrades. 5.5% extra credit, easy final, drops 10 (out of 18) lab and 2(/5) workout project grades. He gives a reasonable amount of time to complete the projects which weren't too difficult.

In the halls of learning, there stands a sage
Whose wisdom and teachings fill each page
With passion and knowledge, he imparts his skill
And guides his students towards the path of thrill

Professor Krone-Martins, a name that rings
With excellence and mastery in all things
His lectures are clear, his explanations sound

The professor is so good that we can ask the TA to regrade our Assignment grade and we can get higher scores, because his auto-grade is so stupid, he do not send his test to use, and ask us to write a test for our code, it is useless, but the Final is too easy, and we can get 15 points free.

real quick imma give you a non-biased rundown. i heard that he was given a week's notice that he was going to teach this class, so it makes sense that everyone doesnt like the work
scale is heavily assignment heavy, 55% assignment and they all build on each other. if you fall behind like I did, good luck
ta's are terrible graders
take upper divs

Best ICS 32 professor ever. He gives you up to 5.5% for extra credit on your entire course grade. And assignments are easy to do and have clear instructions. Autograder is fantastic; give me all the points I need! His finals are so easy as well. I LOVE KRONE MARTINS!!!

Every 5/5 rating is unironically has to be fake / written by a bot or his TAs / troll students because everything they say is literally opposite of the truth. If you can, stay away from ICS 32 with Martins, maybe you can take him for upper div, but stay away from him for 32. Useless lectures, difficult assignments with vague instructions.
Amazing professor! Very caring and easy instructions. Super chill and tells jokes sometimes! I 100% recommend him for ICS 32! Gives a lot of extra credit and made me love coding!
Great Professor! He teaches the course carefully. Every assignment is based on previous assignments. I learned a lot on myself!

Overall I think he is a good/caring professor especially from the reviews for upper division CS. Unfortunately ICS 32 is really unorganized and I did know that he was told to teach this class last minute, but due to this unorganized class it has caused a lot of stress for many students (especially the auto-grader and grading issues that occurred).

just no. Gives clarifications after due dates and won't clarify for assignments bc he thought that it was "obvious". Won't tell you what he wants you to implement but expects it. Terrible instructions, slides don't help much. Tells students to be better time managers but constantly pushes deadlines/ changes due dates. this class is a joke

I really want to like this professor. I really do. Not sure if it's his fault or if he's only following curriculum guidelines, but the jump between ICS 31 and this class was huge. He sounds passionate and funny during lectures, but it's hard to keep up and even harder to understand how he grades his assignments.

like prof cuz he's passionate and we can tell, but not good at teaching. I understand this quarter had a lot of students in the course, but if better structured, there would be not as much questions and dislikes. Like you should understand that if your instructions are bad in a class with over 300 students, it'll only be chaotic and have questions

I'm sorry, but this is the 2nd intro class. Students haven't polished up their coding skills and many barely started coding a quarter ago. How are students suppose to understand instructions and follow through if they don't know what you are talking about in an intro class where they're still practicing basics? Kind of setting up for failure...

WORST PROFESSOR EVER! When you think you have all the requirements checked off for each assignment, the autograder or some hidden requirement that wasn't in the instructions completely destroys your grade for your assignments. Oh and we don't get our grades back for an assignment until about 5-6 weeks later. DON'T TAKE HIM!

DO NOT TAKE THIS PROFESSOR. He assigns so much work. He grades on an auto grader that fails half of the students in the class, even when their code is completely functional and follows the (incredibly vague) instructions. His office hours are impossible to get into. TAs and LAs never understand what's going on and skip labs regularly.

This class is recommended if you enjoy lectures consisting solely of PowerPoint slides, ambiguous assignment instructions, low grades due to unclear instructions and weird autograding, and long waits in the lab to be re-assessed for each assignment. And you will get your project 1 grade in Week 10. Definitely love this class ^

"wants the best for his students and he does want to help us which I do feel bad..." yes, most students can see that but it's not oh this class is good because he cares so A for effort to him. This class has genuinely been confusing for a lot of students especially to those whose coding skills were introduced in ics31(not the best foundation)

syllabus-"The teaching team will not answer EdDiscussion posts during weekends and holidays." the only question(1/1.6k questions) answered by a TA so far was on the Tuesday before finals week... Don't get me wrong, Prof is a passionate man, you can tell by his enthusiasm during lectures, but him teaching this course has been a mess to say the least

"Feel free to implement your code any way you want" but then the auto grader will give you a zero and you will not know until the last week of the quarter so your assignments all get low scores despite producing the required outputs.

Martins is a chill dude and passionate about what he does but doesn't teach ICS too well. The assignments are worth a significant portion of your grade (55%) and the release of these grades come out extremely late. So if you want your grade to be a surprise by the end of the quarter, you should definitely take this professor.

Krone really wants the best for his students and he does want to help us which I do feel bad about since these reviews make him seem heartless. This was his first time teaching ICS32 and he didn't have much instruction on how to teach. 32 is hard in general but krone as a prof is not too bad. You definitely will need to use some outside sources tho

Professor Krone-Martins since week 1 had terrible assignment instructions. His lectures are simply not enough for the content covered in assignments, you will find yourself googling or using YouTube videos to help clear the content covered. Professor NEVER answered my emails, and clears up instructions AFTER the assignment was due.

Don't take him for ics32 if you have a choice. Takes slides and projects straight from other professors and makes them worse. Gives extremely vague instructions on assignments yet uses an autograder. Also does not return grades in time but each assignment builds off of another so you never have an idea if ur doing things right. TAs are clueless too
If his lectures were better and instructions were clear, he'd actually be a great professor for this course. Unfortunately, that's not the case. Take him if you like challenge, not easy class

Assignment grading&instruction=unclear. long time to release grades that build off of one another. Not impossible to pass, he's passionate, but not a good professor. Makes the second INTRO class much harder and complicated than it needs to be. Grade is based not on code quality or understanding, but more on an autograder and whether that passes

"always answers questions outside of class" is a stretch considering he's primarily only available after lec during which students line up to ask questions, won't get to him if you have another class after. meeting requires you to book in advance which seems almost pointless since you wouldn't get your questions answered when you need it

Lectures are boring but contain some good info on how to do assignments SOMETIMES. Assignments are copied from another professor, but instructions somehow got much much worse and vague. Unclear on grading criteria. Release grades late even though assignments build off of one another... can't fix something if you don't even know what's wrong...

encourage students to participate in ed discussions, but it's just a bunch of people giving unhelpful answers over 50% of the time for xc. I have not seen a single question on the discussion board answered by the professor or the TAs. Just confused students "helping" more confused students.

One of the standout qualities of Professor Krone-Martins' teaching is his ability to make his classes engaging and interactive. He encourages students to participate actively in discussions and debates, and fosters an environment of collaboration and learning.

Professor Alberto Krone-Martins is a skilled and dedicated teacher, who has a passion for imparting knowledge to his students. He has a wealth of experience in his field of study and is able to communicate complex concepts in a clear and concise manner.

OBJECTIVE REVIEW: It IS possible to pass. Lectures are basically useless so don't bother going. HOWEVER, very generous grader. only 8 labs held against ur grade. Often extends deadlines. Optional labs, but I don't recommend going (TA's are useless). While instructions are often vague, everything needed to pass is in lec slides / discord.

Grading criteria is unclear.
Posts scores once a week since week 5 or 6.
Lectures and slides have little help on the projects.
Changes deadlines every week (because his plan never fits the reality) and claims himself having good time-managing skills.
Avoid him if possible.

Krone-Martins is very caring and always answers questions outside of class. Although his assignments can be difficult, the slides used in the lecture are a great starting point and can help get a general idea of how to start the projects. You May have to do some research on your own, but overall nice guy and passionate about what he teaches.

People like to hate on him cause his lectures and grading criteria are 'vague' t, but you have to realize that the vast amount of material that you have to learn, understand, and apply is a lot and he just doesn't have time to go over every detail meaning that he provides you with the tools to succeed but it's up to you to sharpen them yourself.

Excellent professor, you will seriously learn a lot. He knows his stuff very well. Yes, the assignments are difficult but he posts the slides with the code as well and provides lecture recordings. As long as you are diligent and listen during lecture + do the labs you will learn a lot.

Take any other ICS 32 professor even if it means taking this class on a different quarter. His instructions are so unclear to the point where confused students are answering questions for other confused students on ed-discussion. On week 6, we're at 800 posts. TA's are LOST during lab, they don't even understand what's asked.
Gave very vague instructions for assignments, assignments were graded at 55% of the grade with there only being 5.

Treats the class like it's a "professional working environment" even though its the second course within an introductory series and ignores the fact that students have other classes and commitments that have an equal, if not, greater workload. It doesn't help that ICS 31, the prerequisite, didn't have the best foundational building skills -(1/5)

It's week 5 of the quarter and he still hasn't released ANY of the grades. This especially sucks because our assignments build off of each other. How can I build off of a code I don't know is right?? He assigns a lot of work, labs 3 times a week on top of assignments and workout projects. He also expects us to already know how to do everything.

Literally does not teach and doesn't reply to any emails... Do not take him if you're doing under-div classes! He expects you to literally know everything and barely teaches in his lectures, he doesn't even grade anything nor teach how to do assignments.

Out of all the CS professors I've had, it's no doubt that Professor Garcia was the best. He gave lots of extra credit, stayed hours after class to help students with assignments, and was willing to negotiate grades if needed. He has become my favorite professor at UCI, and I would HIGHLY reccomend y'all take him. He's great.

This professor changed the final grade weight ONE week before finals. He was messy, disorganized, and the assignment specifications changed often. DO NOT take his class. He is one of the most unclear professors I have ever taken at UCI.

His lectures were SO funny. One homework assignment per week in a group of around 4-5 people. One journal entry per week. If you can't submit in time, email him, he gave extensions. Lectures were so awesome, awesome professor. 100% recommend taking 139W with him.

Lectures consisted of reviewing bad examples of writing IRL and project work time. Assignments are relatively easy and you are given quite a lot of freedom for some of them, especially the weekly journals. Lectures were always funny and engaging. Very accessible during for students to ask questions and get feedback.

Not much of the 'ICS' in this class besides submitting our resume but we basically went over what to write, what not to write, and real-world grammatical errors examples. Lot of freedom in writing in class, especially the weekly journals; helped me get my thoughts off of things besides taking heavy classes. Attendance is mandatory but chill class!

The lectures consisted of reviewing real-world examples of bad writing and working on group assignments. I recommend finding a group early, as the main assignments are group-based. There were weekly journal entries about anything, no midterm or final. Denenberg knows how to make lectures both informative and entertaining.

Not many assignments in this class. Just weekly journals and a "project" that you work on through the duration of the class. No midterms, no final, no abnormally long essays. The assignments are generally pretty easy to complete because they're not boring like the other writing classes. Denenberg is really funny and makes 139W a breeze.
Easy class, homework every week but none of it takes a long time. Professor is very willing to help and ask questions. No midterm or final. Work in pairs most of the quarter.

This class was a lot of fun! I enjoyed Prof Denenberg's lecture videos and they didn't feel like a chore to watch. He has a good personality and it felt like a creative writing class. This is definitely a good course to take if you're stacking it with more difficult courses. Not a ton of work, and overall enjoyable class.
Really easy class. I would do the whole week's work in under an hour. Grading is easy, just basically do the assignment. Probably the easiest writing course I have ever taken.

Not sure if he still teaches this class but definitely an easy A. You won't learn anything though and it will not prepare you for Thornton so be ware. Overall a nice guy but doesn't seem to care about his students much and what they're learning. You'll learn more by skipping his class than by going to the lecture..

Respectfully, this class will not prepare you for ANY future coding class, lectures are unhelpful and quite frankly a snooze fest largely from him just reading off the slides, which is evident from the empty lectures after week 2. Apart from the last two projects you don't really learn much, I highly reccomend just reading Thorntons 32A notes.

No final during finals week (just two open note midterms, weeks 5 and 10) [EDIT: he changed this, apparently there's a final now for future quarters]. If you've coded before then this class is super free and you can get an A with almost no effort (no lecs/labs req). Also, extra credit is generous. Class can be super disorganized/scuffed tho
projects and tests ez

At week 8, our 100 person class had less than 10 people show up to lecture because everyone understood that the lectures are useless as all he does is read off of slides(no code). He also says ed discussion is the best way to contact him, but him and his team pick and choose who they reply to and never answer questions due improper course planning

Course is graded by a few things and its heavily based on the peer reviews. Work is daunting towards the beginning of the first half of the quarter. Professor doesn't communicate well at all though, emails get no replies and you have to rely on TAs or EdDiscussion for course communication.
Coming from someone who never coded before 31, you'll get an A for sure. However, Thorntons 33 will COOK you unless you self study ALOT.

Really disorganized class and his lectures barely helped. Had to self study the entire quarter. exams are fully programming and was difficult. if ur code doesnt work/run, u get a 0. labs made up 60% of ur grades so go to all the lab sessions and get help from the TA's.

Apart from projects, the class isn't very time consuming (I never attended any lecs, only watched lec vids). The 2 midterms (no final) involve writing programs and are open notes and autograded (which means 0% if your program fails to compile). Projects make up 60% of your grade, so doing good on them almost guarantees a solid grade in the class.

Mixed feelings about this course/professor. In the first half, he was completely MIA. The course was badly paced, with a lot of assignments in the first 6/7 weeks then it slowing down in the final half. I don't think it was necessarily difficult, it was just a lot at once. Just be ready for a lot during the beginning of the class, like a lot.

The course was a bit disorganized due to a lack of information. The pace of the modules will go very fast until around week 6 which will slow down over time. So make sure you keep up on your assignments.

Labs make up most of your grade and they get really hard as the course progresses and the instructions are always super vague and sometimes contradicting, so start ASAP. 2 timed coding exams, which are moderately difficult. Autograder feedback is useless so be prepared to spend hours testing code without knowing where the mistake lies.

i got an A but highkey struggled LMFAO youre gna struggle regardless but his instructions and lack of help sometimes got to me man... the TAs carried and i spent so much time in lab/asking friends for advice. BUT his lenience is so underrated: recorded lectures, xtra credit, and decent amount of time for projects

Prof was pretty much AFK the entire quarter. Very unorganized and didn't really care about the class. TA's were the same way but can't blame them for an incompetent teacher. The assignments were pretty easy though. If you follow the rubric exactly and ask clarification questions, 100%. It's primarily busy work, I'd say I invest about 2-5 hours/week

He would tell you that he would not come to class before 3 hours and just posted the past videos. The final is auto grader, and has a lot of problems with uploading it. In the final week, he tries to let us reupload the final with some mistakes which would influence other exams.

The class structure was extremely disorganized. He did not pace the assignments well, making several major assignments due a few days apart. In addition, peer reviews were a big part of this class and we never got to see them before the final draft was due.

This class was very easy but set me up for failure in ICS 46 with Shindler. Ibrahim is good if you want an easy A, but be warned: you will not learn anything. I have taken away absolutely nothing from my quarter with him, besides a GPA boost. Now I am struggling in 46 and need to put in twice the effort just to keep up. The easy A is not worth it!

Lectures were horrible, he canceled all the time and always had lame excuses for canceling class. Tried to appease students and be accommodating with extra credit, but that does not make up for the fact that we learned very little about Cpp in this class.

Rough quarter. Lectures do not really teach I mostly self-studied. He missed many classes. He tested us on material on the midterm that he did not teach in class. Made the students take the final three times bc he messed up times, not considering that students might have finals at that retake exam time. He just doesn't care about students at all.
always cause unnecessary troubles because he is lazy. He's going to mess up the rest of your exam week. Even TAs are better teachers then him

Worst ICS professor at UCI.  Does not set you up for ICS 46. He is so lazy and does not know how to code in C++ at all. Keeps referencing Python for no reason. Lectures are useless since slides are vague and coding examples are trash since he can not code. Never take this guy, you will not learn a single thing. I had to learn from videos online.

WORST professor EVER. For the final exam, he did not explain what we should do clearly, and many people were struggling on submiting for the auto grader. All the things he did was just posting the wrong extension time (he said it was 10:00-11:00 but on canvas it was 10:55-11:00) and NOT OPENING the window for submiting the extension code.

ics32 is difficult but for labs you have enough time to finish them. The thing is that instructions of exams and labs were extremely confusing, but professor Ibrahim hardly answer to your question. Final programming starter code was given with a wrong filename. It took time to fix but literally wasted my time during final week

I am a thirdyear student taking this course for a minor, so Ive taken much harder material courses than this one. However, Professor Ibrahim makes actually learning the material and being able to pass with an acceptable grade the hardest I have ever had to deal with. If you have the unfortunate luck to take him, labs are required even if "optional"

This is by far the worst teacher I have ever had. His lectures have little to nothing to do with the work that he is grading us on other than for exams. The labs are worth a huge portion of the grade and doing poorly on even one of them will irreparably destroy your grade without a makeup. Take this class if you want to teach python to yourself. :)

His class structure is abysmal. Lectures, which are constantly canelled without warning, provide next to no information useful for assignments. The class has only 4 assignments worth 70% of the whole grade. If you screw up on one, your grade is quite literally irraperable. I do not recommend.

Great parent, horrific teacher.

Dude doesn't understand half the stuff he's teaching, cancels lectures the morning of, discusses topics all over the place, and midterms are insanely confusing. Also no practice midterms, and he doesn't pass midterms back either.

He's kind but I doubt anyone learned much from this class.

You better learn everything by yourself, the assignments are time-consuming but doable. However, the midterm is HARD, it is no longer all mutltiple choice questions and there are things that he NEVER talked about. DONT recommend taking his class if you want to have a good grade or to actually learn something useful from the lectures.

Lectures are completely useless and do not apply to the work that determines your grade. The labs are completely different than what is taught in the lecture, and the professor seems lost for what we are even turning in. Hope that your TA is good bc the professor will not do anything for you. Midterms do not apply to labs/homework. Awful. Have fun!

Super super chill professor. He even joined our discord and answer our questions as a STUDENT. Especially DURING final, he was so eager to help us that he seems to want each of us get full marks. He even gave us an extension because gradescope was frozen. Love this guy forever! Extremely easy A

The only "hard" part about this class is the labs if you decide to start later. Besides that, Ibrahim is a very chill professor. Lectures only really cover the foundation of concepts so learning outside of class is a must. The TAs were great help too.

He was a very chill professor. He is a good lecturer and I felt like I learned a lot from them. The TA's were great and attend Office Hours when you need help. The projects were fair and as long as you start early they were easy. He even gave extensions for every project. The final was super easy too and only took about 20 lines of code to finish.

His projects are challenging but very doable and teach you a lot if you START EARLY, which many students don't do and then struggle and complain. TA's are helpful, go to labs for help on projects. Lectures are straightforward and he talks about how we will use the Python libraries in real life and industry. Super chill and generous.

This is definitely the worst professor I have ever met at UCI. His lecture is completely useless, you can literally read the slides after the class by yourself and have no problem understanding them. His project is much more difficult than what you learned from his lecture. The complement on your project is highly related to your TA not profesor

Professor Ibrahim doesn't answer emails as fast which in my experience affected my work. His lectures are confusing and most of the time you will probably google everything yourself. His projects are alright, not too hard, but the instructions for the projects are confusing. If it wasn't for the TA's help other students and I would've failed.

There is nothing super bad about this class. My only complaint is the amount of learning we have compared to other ICS 32 classes. To the second complaint, I feel like we are learning "less" than other 32 classes with Baldwin or Thornton. We have less projects and the other two professors seem to go more in depth into the material than Ibraham.

Lectures give a brief overview of the material, so be ready to google. Grade very dependent on hw/projects whose instruction can be vague at times. The conceptual midterms can be tricky, but are MCQs. Final is a project. I'd say take him if you want a class where you can go brain-dead mode, but for learning I would avoid. EDIT: bad planning/timing

Good, solid choice for ICS professor. He was always easy to reach and had quick and nice responses to emails. We had 2 midterms, 4 labs (3 of which had helpful starter code), and a programming final. I didn't have any problems with the grading, but some of my peers did. Start early on labs and TAs are always the best resource for help.

His lectures put me to sleep but had good info. Majority of the grade consists of labs. Start early on the labs that come up later in the quarter as they can take up a lot of time. There were also two easy midterms and a programming final.

Not awesome, but also not a bad choice under remote learning. His lecture is not pretty clear all the time, but helpful for your homework on projects and preparation for exams. His projects are not really difficult if you watch the lecture carefully. His exams are difficult, however: MCQ, but un-returnable, and hard to make a certain choice usually

Two noncumulative midterms and a programming final. Prof doesn't go in-depth into C++. Lecture videos often not posted on time, lecture slides usually had less than 4 slides per topic, and programming assignments are not really rigorous. Conceptual midterm questions are straight from the slides. Overall easy grade, but left wanting more about C++.
He is a good guy. He is the only human being in ics.
Very good guy. His project is not as hard as the projects on ics33. He really cares about his students.

Professor Ibrahim is the GOAT. I feel Ibrahim is the only 45C professor who teaches and gives good projects. He doesn't give too hard projects like the others because harder leads to more stress and stress leads you to just googling the answer/not actually learning. Thus if you want to take a class where you learn and get the grade take him!

Good remote teacher. Class was taking during summer 10wk. He recorded lectures that were available for viewing later. Also coded examples during class each lecture to help show and explain topics. Credit in the course consisted of 4 projects and a midterm and final. Projects got harder as class went on, but very manageable if you start early.

I do not understand why people think Ibrahim is bad. His assignments are fair enough to build basic c++ programming skills. The exams are divided into two parts: programming and concept. The tests are not that hard if you study his lecture slides and understand the coding examples. Overall, he is great.

Really caring professor. For remote instruction, he spend extra effort to record the lecture, edit it, and post it for the students, all while responding to Piazza regularly. Optional textbook. Tests aren't bad, and neither were the programming assignments, but I needed to do some outside research to understand some of those assignments.

Fair tests with relevant content, decent lectures (really good to watch at 2x speed), interesting and challenging labs. My only real grievance is that the some of the lab guidelines could stand to be a lot more specific and have more example i/o. Let the class have a say in logistical matters (async lectures) and is very clear about test content.

He's very understanding and listens to his students about any concerns that they have. I would definitely take this writing course with him again. As long as you're putting in some effort into the work, you'll get an A.

I don't take the time often to give reviews to professors but reading the other reviews doesn't do the teacher justice, this was during the 2020 Spring quarter where every class online. He cares about his students, working around the clock for the class, very active on Piazza , and great at showing examples after the usual short lecture slides.

Super lenient class. The difficulty of projects is far less than ICS33. Lectures are not mandatory. However, that also means you won't learn much from his lecture and projects, while he will test you some stuff that you never saw, which will harm your grade. If you already know C++ well, easy class. Otherwise, stay away from him

ICS 45C was a very disorganized class. The professor was trying to figure out how to teach/code while in class. There was a lot of down time while he debugged the code he was trying to show in front of the class, very often. He also canceled lectures semi often. It was very boring and I barely learned anything in this class.
He's a pretty solid lecturer kept up the jokes and his test weren't too bad. Nothings mandatory so it's pretty easy to not go to class and just study off of the slides to do the projects.

Ibrahim is a very fair teacher. His projects were relatively easy, his midterm was fair (testing us on coding recursion, understanding try catch, etc), and his final was alright it was very conceptual a little bit more difficult because we had to know specific topics and methods. Overall he was a funny/chill dude, so I enjoyed the course.

He only uses slides for material and they are pretty minimal making the info straightforward. He does a good job at explaining concepts. Study labs bc youll have to hand write segments from labs on the tests. His review sessions before tests gave a good gage as to what would be on there. He is kind and definitely willing to work with students.
Easier than Thornton. Easy projects but midterm and final are more difficult (B average). No curve because 85 percent of the class passed. Said that he would make next quarter harder.

He's a decent lecturer and the projects are definitely fair. However, the midterm and final are worth most of the grade and they were both very conceptual (didn't test the stuff on the projects) so they were pretty difficult. It's pretty easy to pass but very difficult to get a high grade since the tests are so specific and conceptual.
Lecture is not mandatory. Homework is quite easy. Exams are regular; no strange questions.

Prof. Ibrahim is the most sincere and very intelligent. He is humble, caring and like joking. He gives extra credits. His lectures and notes are amazing; learned a lot and he explained very well. He is the best Prof. I've ever had and always willing to help his students. Prof. Ibrahim is an amazing Prof. and very kind and very understanding!!

Lecture isn't mandatory, and the hw is very easy. The midterm and final were pretty weird though, he never tells you what you need to know. Final had alot of random things on it and the class average was really low. Ended up getting a B+ because the final, but the level of work you need to put in is extremely low. I feel like I didn't learn Java.

The class felt VERY disorganized overall; lectures were difficult to follow along with -his example codes often contained buggy portions and did not work properly when he tried to explain them in class. It seemed as if he wasn't familiar with his own coding examples.. 1 midterm and 1 final, 4 labs (solo or pair-programming). Pretty disappointed.
Had Ibrahim for 45C. Really enjoyed his style. Wish he taught more lower division classes :(

This class had me spending a few hours writing every week, so it definitely improved my writing abilities. Must have 2 or less unexcused lecture absences to get an A. Discussions are mandatory as well. The lectures had me on the verge of falling asleep in class, but maybe you'll find them more engaging.

Very solid 139W class graded by specification - as long as you meet the criteria of the contract, you get an A. This means minimal late homework, mostly showing up to class, etc. Very chill but this class also improved my writing more than I expected. Excellent professor to take 139W with.

Baldwin doesn't teach ICS 32 the same way as the other professors which I enjoyed. He has five projects in the quarter that build onto each other to create one fully functional program in the end. His lectures through Zoom weren't always the most interesting but online videos were informative. Hope to see him teaching the course again!

Definitely will take his class again! Such a cool and awesome professor! Lots of extra credit opportunity. The lectures are very helpful. Professor Baldwin is also very willing to meet outside of class if you need extra help.

Prof. Baldwin made it super easy to ask questions on a class-specific platform called zulip. My favorite projects were the ones where we got to work with partners. Make sure you get a partner for the first partner project (I found mine on zulip) as there were three partner projects and it's easier to stick with the partner you've already got.

Easily one of the best professors I've ever had. He's able to explain difficult and convoluted concepts in an relatively understandable way, has realistic and practical assignments for the class, is incredibly understanding & caring, and overall teaches the content in a very effective way. Would give 6 stars if I was able to.

Class is based on 6 projects that you either work on by yourself or with a peer. You learn the work throughout the week which makes doing the projects not that bad. There are labs 3 days a week which is basically simple mini-projects, you don't have to go to all. Professor Baldwin is super nice and such a great teacher, he responds fast too

He is pompous and thinks pretty low of the students.  He makes that clear when he grades your papers.  No constructive criticism.  He criticizes your paper for the sake of criticism.  Not a great teacher as some would lead you to believe.

Very very sweet professor. Great office hours. I didn't really show up to lecture, most of the material you can learn on ZyBooks. 4 exams, homework, zybooks reading were pretty much your whole grade. The exams were exactly like the problems in the zybooks and he let us have a cheat sheet so it was pretty easy to do well on the exams.
very easy class despite having 4 midterms. just do your homework and zybooks and you are fine. also attend your TA office hours and discussions for practice. Those help a lot!!!

Tests are very easy and directly reflect the homework's and ZYBook problems. His lectures are structured with slides that he goes over including multiple examples and explanations, but they aren't necessary to do well in the class.

The class begins with grading on hw half completion half accuracy, then just leads to fully completition. Professor tries and gives u as many practice problems with zybooks and then grades the midterms very, very nicely. Optional final to retake a midterm. Overall, since i took stats classes i didnt show up for the last two weeks and did good mid4.

I think the class content itself is just hard, but the professors and his TAs make it a good experience! Make the most of it and I think a majority of it just self learning through the zybooks, but the grading and testing experience was exceptional!

he's a terrible lecturer, but the tests are fair and not overly difficult. ended up with an A without going to class and studying the zybooks exclusively. the zybooks teaches well and is better than jarecki's lectures
10/10. best professor i've ever had.

92% of your grade came from the tests, and the other 8% came from readings and evaluation. There's an optional final, but initially, it could harm your grade. Luckily, Jarecki was considerate enough to make the final only benefit you. Homework and discussions helped me succeed in this class so I recommend you do them.
I can't tell you how much relieved I feel after finishing this course. Finally, done! It was too much work. You have to study independently because the lectures do not make much sense.

The grading scale is horrendous with 4 tests being 92% of your grade, but the tests were so hard. Average for one of the tests was 60%. He changed his grading scale for the tests and the optional final so much due to how much kids are struggling in his class. If you are a bad test taker do not take him bc your life will depend on your test grades.

This class made me miss 6b with Gassko. The exams were very difficult, lectures made things more confusing, and discussions presented difficult problems too. Each test I thought I failed even tho I did the discussion questions, Zybooks problems, and the hw. Test 2 and Test 4 were very difficult (with little time to learn the topics).
I regret so much by taking this dive into tragedy!

Honestly, his lectures are very useless because he just mumbles stuff and rushes slides. The course was planned very poorly, and midterm score averages were completely awful... I wouldn't recommend taking him...
He doesn't know how to talk and lecture! Not good at all at sentence structure. He speaks for 1 hour 20 minutes and everything he says goes over my head.
I just cried the entire quarter!
Everything else is good except his worst lectures. He needs to get training on how to teach. Organization is fine!

Glad I held off on taking 6D with Gassko. All you have to do is do ZyBook questions and make a good cheat sheet your're set. The ppl who complain about his structure are those who don't do ZyBook problems (exams are literally variants of them). 6D is hard, but we have the materials needed to pass. We have it exponentially easier than Gassko IMO.
He won't prepare for his lecture, his accent makes the lecture worse. A wise man but not a good teacher, sorry.

I think this class was different for everyone who took it. Personally, doing zyBooks questions and the practice tests were enough. I think keep up with his lectures if you find zyBooks not as helpful but sometimes even his lectures can be confusing. Beware that some test questions will be worded a little weird. Huge curve at the end.

without a doubt one of the hardest professors to talk to outside of class, especially in regards to regrading. Once his mind is set, there is no talking him out of it. a really "end of discussion" with no discussion kind of person. Tests are hard and hardly related to practice tests (do the homework and talk to your TA instead. helps way more).

Jarecki does pretty well at explaining the concepts. His tests can be very difficult, but the practice tests and his homework can prepare you well. Tests are usually more concept-based, so I would watch his lectures as they are more conceptual. Lectures are quite boring but they are very good.

Jarceki is noticeably passionate about teaching, especially once you get to the cryptography part. He cares about the students and making a fair environment (he wants you to work for your grade, but listened to students nonetheless). His lectures and explanations may be hard to understand; ZyBooks, the TAs, and practice tests are great resources

For our quarter the averages on tests 2 and 4 were lower. Really the only thing you can do is lots of practice problems and all the practice tests. 4 tests total and an optional final. Test 2 and Test 4 are the hardest (recursion and counting problems). He's a nice guy but a very poor lecturer. I do recommend watching his lectures, however.

Professor Jarecki cares a lot about being fair with exams and giving as much partial credit as possible in a uniform way- which is good because 4 exams are worth 88% of your grade. Lectures are okay but you'll likely have an easier time just learning from the ZyBooks assignments (so do them before each exam instead of waiting until the end).

A poor lecturer for a class that relies heavily on understanding abstract concepts for a lot of the work. A lot of the time he doesn't seem to really know what the heck is going on and his tests aren't exactly easy. As long as you do the practice problems, you'll probably be okay for tests, but I wouldn't take him if there's a better alternative.

Solid. Grade is determined by 4 tests and the reading. Tests are easy as long as you understand the (optional) hw. The zybooks is good. There is an optional final. Lectures are bad and are skippable as long as you do the (mandatory) reading. Reading grade is counted at the end of the quarter. There was also a large curve (A- was 85.5% my quarter).

Very understanding and smart teacher but lecturing isn't one of his strong suits. His lectures on induction in particular were very hard to follow. Grades can also be very volatile since most of your grade is determined by 4 tests. Just get ready to read the Zybooks and do the extra problems.

Did a very good job given the virtual remote instruction - would help coordinating exams at convenient times. The most open minded and nicest professor in CS. Class is based on 4 exams and ZyBooks completion - exams very straightforward and easy, very similar to HW's(I'd say are even easier). Do additional ZyBooks exercises and you'll be good.

His lecture is unprepared and not clear, explaining the easy concepts in a hard way. Homework is optional but really hard and questions are ambiguous, even hard to understand the lengthy and vague solutions. Some solution sheets from TA are also not clear and hard to relate to the lecture concepts. Stressed a lot for taking extra time on solutions.

Cares about his students and will listen to your input! ZyBooks textbook is mandatory but very clear and helpful, his lectures have interesting material too. Tests were similar to HW rather than ZyBooks, but were fair game and not too difficult. Overall pretty solid professor and pretty easy class! Do your HW and you'll be fine :)

A good professor with good lectures, he's obviously pretty interested in the subject. Did a great job adapting given the new circumstance and environment. Homeworks are graded for correctness and are pretty tough, but not worth too much. The class gets a fair bit easier (and more interesting imo) once you finish doing induction.
His lecture is very clear and rigorous about on mathematical definition. Homework is helpful to understand the course material. Cryptography part is my favorite.
He let you use cheat sheets for the tests. And the test is a lot like the homework questions.

Professor Jarecki is kind and cares about students, but he is not a naturally skilled lecturer. That said, he is clearly intelligent - you will just have to tolerate him stumbling over his words every now and then, and English is not his first language. ICS 6D with Jarecki was not nearly as difficult as some would say, but it wasn't great either.

Very helpful as others have said. He seemed to change the difficulty of the class starting this quarter, Spring '18. 4 Tests worth 88% of your grade and each was pretty fair compared to what others in the past had said. They were basically taken from the hw. So I recommend you study hw problems first and then similar textbook problems for practice
Always respond to questions. Detailed explanations of the concepts in the lecture. But, hard to understand what's he's talking about. No Final

Professor Jarecki is a nice guy and is always responding to student's questions about the class and the course material on piazza. The grading guidelines for this class are very clear; there are 4 tests worth 88% in total and the rest is homework and the reading, both of which I highly recommend doing as the tests are similar to HW and textbook.

Jarecki is one of the nicest professors I have had so far. He cares a lot about his students. Sure, he isn't amazing at lecturing but the Zybook really covers everything you need to know. There are 4 quizzes, each worth 22% and homework 6%, reading 6%. I didn't put effort into this class, but if you spend the time on it, I'm sure you can get an A.

Jarecki is a nice guy, and definitely seems to care for the students, but just happens to be a terrible lecturer (so you'll have to teach yourself) Homework can sometimes be challenging, but tests are very fair and straightforward. He realizes he's not very good at teaching, and as a result gives a very generous curve at the end of the course.

Jarecki might not be as great as a lecturer. But he's probably the nicest professor I've had at UCI. He's really caring, respectful and very responsive. His exams are fairly hard, but he gave tremendous curve in the end. No one knows how to teach ics6b & ics6d (except for prof Irani), but at least it was a pleasant experience taking 6d with him.

Lecturers are just a waste of time because half the time you don't even know what he's talking about. Explains relatively easy concepts in really complex ways so it just confuses the student. Take Irani or Gassko if possible.

Smart (MIT) and approachable guy, but awful at lecturing. Stutters and explains things confusingly, and can't seem to figure out PPT slides... probably the last person you want to be teaching a class. Course is very disorganized. Tests are different than but easier than the HW.

Really bad lectures, and doesn't know how to use his power points, resulting to him using the chalk board, which for him is a terrible way to teach students. Not respected at all by his student, and often got talked over by students. He shows many unnecessary proofs, making the class slow. I left class confused and didn't learn much in lecture.

Honestly he's a really nice guy, but would avoid having him as a professor. Discrete math is a difficult subject and his lectures are hard to follow. All you hear from him is "uhm uh, ok so um here uhhh we have um...". I don't think I've ever heard him make one coherent sentence. You're better off just skipping lecture and learning on your own.

Incredibly smart guy, but not a good professor. He's a researcher first and a teacher second - his lectures are confusing and he doesn't explain things very clearly. The material itself is moderately difficult, but A's are rare due to unfair exams. He teaches you to get from apples to oranges and back, then gives you grapefruits on the final.

Although i think he's a really sincere professor and does try really hard...but i have to say that he's the worst teacher i have ever had in my life. He doesn't explain well in class, and when he tries to, all that comes out are "uhh..um..yeah..okay" and you see most of the students thinking "no, it's not OK" i would not take him again.
Although his lectures are unclear, the notes posted are useful and he is approachable for questions and regrades.  Writes quizzes and exams fairly.

I swear every time I see him I think his brain is going to explode out of his head. I don't really go to lectures but the quizzes and exams are pretty easy and do follow what he's teaching. Will need to read text though since his powerpoints leave out some stuff.
